Title: This Alaska Mine Would Destroy the World’s Largest Salmon Fishery
Abstrace: The state’s governor has asked the Supreme Court to resurrect a widely opposed plan rejected by the federal government.

Title: Cleaning Up a Legacy of Pollution on an Alaskan Island
Abstrace: On St. Lawrence Island, a former military listening post in the Bering Sea, native residents believe pollution has contributed to their poor health.

Title: Searching for Signs of Lingering Pollution in Alaska
Abstrace: A group of researchers traveled to St. Lawrence Island in Alaska and withstood difficult conditions to study pollution caused by military sites from the Cold War days.

Title: Searching for Signs of Lingering Pollution in Alaska
Abstrace: A group of researchers traveled to St. Lawrence Island in Alaska and withstood difficult conditions to study pollution caused by military sites from the Cold War days.

Title: National Briefing | West: Alaska: Pollution Settlement
Abstrace: national brie

Title: Alaska Gets Tougher On Cruise Ship Pollution
Abstrace: New Alaska law expands state's authority to inspect cruises ships and to fine companies that pollute waters; Gov Tony Knowles had pressed for higher measure after voluntary tests last year found almost none of waste-water samples from ships met federal standards for fecal coliform bacteria and other pollutants; International Council of Cruise Lines promises cooperation (M)

Title: Hunting for Oil: New Precision, Less Pollution
Abstrace: Oil drilling sites like those in Alpine field on Alaska's North Slope are using cutting-edge technology that reduce environmental damage; changes are being highlighted by the oil industry, Alaskan elected and Bush administration as evidence that oil quest should be allowed to expand east from Prudhoe Bay into coastal plain of Arctic National Wildlife Refuge; drawings; photo (L)

Title: A Far-Reaching Fire Makes a Point About Pollution
Abstrace: Terra and Aqua, National Aeronautics and Space Administration satellites, track sooty remains of large Alaskan fire across United States; path of air pollution points out global implications of regional pollution (S)

Title: How Big of a Climate Betrayal Is the Willow Oil Project?
Abstrace: The world wants to have it both ways on fossil fuels.

Title: Into the Gyre
Abstrace: A team of artists and scientists traveled to Alaska to document water pollution. Carl Safina, an ecologist and Mark Dion, an artist, talk about their observations from the trip.

Title: Science at the End of the Earth
Abstrace: A team of scientists spent five days collecting and dissecting fish on remote St. Lawrence Island in Alaska to study the effects of pollution from old military installations on the habitat.

Title: National Briefing | West: Alaska: Battle Over Cruise Ship Dumping
Abstrace: Alaska officials and lobbyists reach agreement on bill intended to crack down on sewage dumping and other pollution by ships (S)

Title: Alaskans’ Cost of Staying Warm: A Thick Coat of Dirty Air
Abstrace: When temperatures drop around North Pole, Alaska, wood smoke that goes up comes down again, causing dangerous pollution to hover at lung level.

Title: Alaska’s Quandary
Abstrace: Alaskans are set to vote on whether to allow the mining of large deposits of copper, gold and other metals at the possible expense of the state’s strong salmon industry.

Title: On Our Radar: Shipping Paths Redrawn Off Alaska
Abstrace: Melting ice has opened or widened so many corridors that NOAA has prepared new charts.

Title: National Briefing | West: Alaska: Diesel Fuel Leaks
Abstrace: Fishing vessel that sank in Alaska's Prince William Sound is leaking 35,000 gallons of fuel (S)

Title: Shell Seeks to Weaken Air Rules for Arctic Drilling
Abstrace: Shell says its rig Discoverer cannot meet the emissions requirements of an air permit granted by the E.P.A. in January.

Title: Shell Violated Air Permits for Arctic Ships, E.P.A. Says
Abstrace: Its ships allowed excess nitrogen oxides to escape during the abbreviated 2012 drilling season last summer and fall, the agency says.

Title: National Briefing | West: Alaska: Group Tracks Oil And Gas Spills
Abstrace: Environmental group Cook Inlet Keeper says more than 50,000 gallons of oil and gas is spilled into Alaska's Cook Inlet each year; evaluation of seven pipeline companies' performance ranks Unocal as having worst spill rate (S)

Title: National Briefing | West: Alaska: Oil Spill's Effects Linger
Abstrace: Study finds that although most of big environmental effects of 1989 oil spill from Exxon Valdez tanker quickly dissipated, oil's toxic effects on various species around Prince William Soung persisted far longer than expected (S)

Title: National Briefing | West: Alaska: Captain In Valdez Spill Pays Debt
Abstrace: Joseph J Hazelwood, former captain of Exxon Valdez responsible for country's worst oil spill, finishes paying his debt to State of Alaska with $50,000 check; restitution was part of sentence issued in 1990; photo (S)

Title: House Passes Energy Bill For 3rd Time
Abstrace: House Republicans again pass $31-billion energy bill that has failed in Senate over objections to legal immunity for producers of gasoline additive blamed for water pollution; hope record gas prices and election season will push bill into law; leadership also hopes to push through new proposal to allow drilling in Arctic National Wildlife Refuge (S)

Title: Court Upholds E.P.A. Role in Alaska Case
Abstrace: Supreme Court, narrowly divided on question of federal versus state regulation, upholds Environmental Protection Agency's authority to insist that factories and power plans use 'best available' anti-pollution technology and to block construction of those that, in agency's view, do not; 5-to-4 decision comes in dispute that arose when EPA overruled Alaska's acceptance of technology that Red Dog Mine, world's largest zinc mine, proposed for use to control additional pollutants that expanded facility would emit; Red Dog Mine, 100 miles north of Arctic circle, is largest private employer in northwest Alaksa; Teck Cominco Alaska Inc is mine owner (M)

Title: Spawning Salmon Haul Toxins to Alaska Lakes, Experts Find
Abstrace: Dr Jules Blais, University of Ottawa assistant biology professor, forms team of mostly Canadian scientists to study rising PCB levels in Alaska's fresh water lakes; findings, published in journal Nature, show link between concentration level of PCBs in lakes and number of salmon spawning in them; emphasize need to explore ways pollutants are transmitted around globe; PCBs, along with 11 other highly toxic chemicals, were banned by 122 countries in 2000; map; photo (M)

Title: Reckonings; Smog and Mirrors
Abstrace: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column contends that Pres Bush is trying to dispel doubts about his legitimacy when he blames pollution controls for California energy crisis and uses crisis to argue for opening Arctic tundra to oil drilling; asserts that that by winning series of striking victories against moderates Bush hopes he can create an 'illusion of a mandate' that the election did not give him (M)

Title: Oil Giant Acts and Skeptics React
Abstrace: What's Online column; critics post comments on Meta filter.com and Desmog Blog about BP, which introduced targetneutral.com program that enables drivers in Britain to determine how much carbon dioxide pollution they helped create and to offset it by supporting green energy initiatives; program comes at time when Environmental Protection Agency is investigating accusations that BP manipulated data to avoid having to replace pipelines in Prudhoe Bay oil field, which BP shut because of corrosion; Forbes.com, following complaints from bloggers, withdraws two articles by executive editor Michael Noer warning against marrying 'career girls'; Milwaukee Journal-Sentinel (jsonline.com) recounts incident in which workers added cocoa butter to vat to thin dark chocolate that trapped worker at chocolate factory in Kenosha (Wis); drawing (M)

Title: Time for Exxon to Pay
Abstrace: Editorial says Judge Russel Holland was not being excessive when he imposed $4.5 billion in punitive damages on Exxon Mobil for Exxon Valdez oil spill in Alaska's Prince William Sound in 1989

Title: The Dirty Little Deals That Would Foul the Environment
Abstrace: Republicans are adding measures to appropriations bills that would gut protections of the air, water and landscape.

Title: Congress, After Years of Effort, Is Set to Pass Broad Energy Bill
Abstrace: Congress, after coming up short for years, is preparing to enact mammoth energy plan that would provide generous subsidies to oil and gas industries, encourage new nuclear plants, try to encourage renewable fuels and give federal government new power to override local objections to terminals for LNG imports; Pres Bush will go to Capitol Hill to rally House members; Energy Committee chairman Joe Barton accepts Senate's refusal to go along with easing of air pollution rules he sought for his Texas district; bill sidesteps oil drilling in Arctic National Wildlife Refuge; would extend daylight savings time in 2007, from second Sunday in March until first Sunday in November; list of key provisions; Barton estimates direct spending of up to $12 billion; Taxpayers for Common Sense sees potential $80-billion cost; conservation groups also are critical of proposal (M)

Title: A Canadian Threat to Alaskan Fishing
Abstrace: Mining projects endanger the state’s salmon rivers.

Title: Appeals Panel Cuts Award in Valdez Spill by Exxon
Abstrace: Federal appeals panel cuts $4.5 billion punitive damages award against Exxon Mobil as result of Exxon Valdez oil spill in 1989 to $2.5 million; says company's negligent conduct had not been intentional and had not warranted maximum financial penalty that lower court imposed (M)

Title: Biden Administration Moves to Protect Alaska’s Bristol Bay
Abstrace: The bay, home to a key sockeye salmon fishery, sits atop a massive gold and copper deposit, pitting environmentalists against mining companies.

Title: National Briefing: West
Abstrace: NEVADA: Gold Producer Accused; ALASKA: Prohibition Returns;.

Title: Fishermen Express Dismay Over Exxon Valdez Ruling
Abstrace: Alaska fishermen who have lost hundreds of thousands of dollars income since Exxon Valdez despoiled Prince William Sound in 1989 are dismayed by appellate court decision that $5-billion verdict was excessive; Herb Jensen and others discuss their plight (S)

Title: What’s Killing Pacific Whales?
Abstrace: Emaciated gray whales are washing ashore dead. Scientists are trying to solve the mystery.

Title: Arctic Refuse
Abstrace: David Masiel article on pollution of land and water that is everyday part of working oil fields of North Slope (M)

Title: Lawrence Rawl, 76, Exxon's Chief in Valdez Spill, Dies
Abstrace: Lawrence G Rawl, who led overhaul of Exxon's operations in 1980's and shaped company's response to Exxon Valdez oil spill, dies at age 76; photo (M)

Title: For Planet Earth, No Tourism Is a Curse and a Blessing
Abstrace: From the rise in poaching to the waning of noise pollution, travel’s shutdown is having profound effects. Which will remain, and which will vanish?

Title: A Dwindling Catch Has Alaskans Uneasy
Abstrace: Red salmon, a summertime pleasure that feeds residents through the winter, has failed to show up this season in most rivers.

Title: Alaska Oil Spill Takes Toll on Animals and Fisheries
Abstrace: Estimated number of amimals killed or injured by oil has sharply increased as rare break in rough Bering Sea weather allows officials to gain better sense of damage from large spill in Aleutian Islands; more than 355,000 gallons of fuel oil are thought to have spilled from freighter that ran aground on Dec 8; biologists have so far counted 109 bird carcasses and more than 600 birds coated with oil in area around wreck; they expect thousands to have been killed; local crab-fishing season has been canceled (M)

Title: Pipeline Crews Tackle Huge Oil Spill Caused by Shooting
Abstrace: Workers struggle to contain one of largest spills in history of Trans-Alaska Pipeline, caused by drunk men who fired bullet into 4-foot-wide structure; at least 150,000 gallons of oil spill onto tundra north of Fairbanks; photo; map; Daniel Carlson Lewis, who has long criminal record, is arrested in Livengood (M)

Title: Clashing Opinions at Meeting on Alaska Drilling
Abstrace: Oil companies, conservation groups and Alaska Native communities square off before panel of scientists in Anchorage, presenting clashing visions of impact of expanding oil and gas drilling on North Slope; oil industry claims new techniques will minimize pollution and harm to wildlife; conservationists fear irrevocable damage to one of nation's wildest and most fragile landscapes; photo (M)

Title: Alaska Gets to Choose
Abstrace: An initiative intended to strengthen protections for the headwaters of Bristol Bay should get the overwhelming approval of Alaskans.

Title: $92 Million More Is Sought for Exxon Valdez Cleanup
Abstrace: Justice Department and state of Alaska will seek $92 million from Exxon Mobil to clean up stubborn patches of oil that have not dissipated since Exxon Valdez spill in 1989; map; $900-million settlement in 1991 allowed for reopening case up to 15 years later in event of unforseeable damage (M)

Title: $4.5 Billion Award Set For Spill of Exxon Valdez
Abstrace: Alaska federal Judge H Russel Holland imposes punitive damages of $4.5 billion on Exxon Mobil Corp for Exxon Valdez's spill of 11 million gallons of crude oil into Prince William Sound fifteen years ago; lawyers for 32,000 fishermen and residents say total with interest is about $6.75 billion; appeals court rejected two earlier awards as too high (M)

Title: How Do You Fight the Coronavirus Without Running Water?
Abstrace: Entire communities around the country face this terrifying virus without being even able to wash their hands.

Title: For These Americans, Clean Water Is a Luxury
Abstrace: In some places around the country, families rely on buckets, bottles, even animal troughs.

Title: Sea of Trash
Abstrace: The world’s oceans are filling with bottles, wrappers and other flotsam. Is there anything better to be done than picking it off the beach, one piece at a time?

Title: Court Overturns Jury Award In '89 Exxon Valdez Spill
Abstrace: Federal appeals court rules that $5.3 billion in punitive damages Exxon Corp was ordered to pay for 1989 Exxon Valdez oil spill, worst in nation's history, was excessive; vacates 1994 jury award to 33,000 commercial fishermen, Alaska Natives, property owners and others and tells judge to set lower amount (M)

Title: Testy Sea Hampers Response to Alaskan Spill
Abstrace: Potentially worst oil spill in Alaska since Exxon Valdez spill in 1989 is near Aluetian Islands in Bering Sea, in some of most punishing waters on planet; Capt Kevin Bell, ship operator for Alaska Maritime National Wildlife Refuge, is not optimistic that he can ferry biologists close enough to truly assess impact of spill; freighter went aground, with six crew members missing and presumed dead and unknown amount of its 470,000 gallons of viscous fuel leaking; photo; map (M)

Title: Are We Experienced | Governing Happens
Abstrace: I believe it is what one does in office, not the holding of office, that prepares one for future public service.

Title: How to Protect Bristol Bay’s Salmon for the Long Haul
Abstrace: E.P.A. action, legislation and land conservation together can permanently protect Alaska’s Bristol Bay, the salmon and a way of life.

Title: Pasturing Sablefish in the Pacific
Abstrace: First sablefish fingerlings are introduced into two fish farms along coast of British Columbia, and more than 40 new farms have been permitted in last year along Pacific shoreline; first fish will be ready for market in year and half of so (M)

Title: The Arctic Drilling Countdown
Abstrace: The interior secretary is on his way to Alaska, but Obama administration officials caution that this doesn’t mean that permits are imminent for Shell.

Title: Biden Aims to End Arctic Drilling. A Trump-Era Law Could Foil His Plans.
Abstrace: The administration suspended leases that were auctioned in the waning days of the Trump White House. But a 2017 law requires another sale.

Title: Bush, in Energy Plan, Endorses New U.S. Drilling to Curb Prices
Abstrace: Gov George W Bush proposes wide-ranging $7.1 billion 10-year energy plan to curb rising oil and gas prices and limit nation's vulnerability to international oil market, speech, Saginaw, Mich; calls for more domestic fuel output, better ties with foreign oil suppliers and opening Alaska's Arctic National Wildlife Refuge for drilling; also proposes incentives for developing alternative energy sources and clean-burning fuels; charges Clinton administration and Vice Pres Al Gore failed to develop energy policy, forcing them to release oil from strategic reserves; Gore and running mate, Sen Joseph I Lieberman, rearrange schedules to deliver own remarks on energy and environment; environmentalists reject Bush's stand that limited oil exploration in Arctic refuge can be done in environmentally sensitive way; excerpt from Bush speech; table of candidates' energy proposals; photo (M)

Title: A Land So Wild, It's Getting Crowded
Abstrace: Timothy Egan travel article on $1 billion tourism industry that threatens Alaska with overcrowding and is raising environmenal concerns; photos; maps (L)

Title: Measuring Greenhouse Gases in Alaska
Abstrace: Working in a harsh climate isn’t easy, but the job is important and there’s fun to be had.

Title: Gold vs. Salmon: An Alaska Mine Project Just Got a Boost
Abstrace: The Trump Administration, rejecting concerns over the risks to Alaska’s fishery, cleared the way on Friday for the Pebble Mine.

Title: In Alaskan Islands, Fearing a Spill That Comes on Legs
Abstrace: Wildlife biologists are working furiously to protect millions of exotic animals after freighter runs aground few hundred miles from small island in Bering Sea and begins oozing oil into ocean; fear is that rats on board freighter will get near St Paul Island, which is still rat-free, attacking birds there; photos; map (M)

Title: A Mysterious Spiral in the Alaska Sky Had an Earthly Explanation
Abstrace: A large blue swirl that appeared in the night sky and within the aurora borealis did not have to do with aliens but was probably a fuel dump from a SpaceX rocket launch.

Title: The Lieberman Method of Dismantling Opponents: Subtle as a Ton of Brickbats
Abstrace: Sen Joseph I Lieberman, using Houston oil refinery as backdrop, scores Gov George W Bush's environmental record in Texas and his proposal to allow oil drilling in Alaska wilderness; displays his talent for making attacks that do not come across as attacks; photo (M)

Title: Shell Vessels Sidelined, Imperiling Arctic Plans
Abstrace: The company’s ambitious oil exploration program in the Arctic has been hindered by delays for the last seven years.

Title: More Cruise Ships Are Calling in Alaska
Abstrace: Cruise lines, anticipating less demand for Mediterranean cruises because of September 11 terrorist attacks, move record 25 ships to Alaska for summer season, including new 2,600-passenger Star Princess; North West Cruise Ship Assn expects some 730,000 cruise passengers this year; Alaskan merchants worry that tourist spending will not keep pace because of weakened economy (M)

Title: 7 Travel Stories to Help You Celebrate the 50th Anniversary of Earth Day
Abstrace: Confined to the great indoors on Earth Day? These stories will help remind you of the natural world’s many splendors — and why environmental protections are of crucial importance for the future of the planet.

Title: IN ENERGY PLAN, BUSH URGES NEW DRILLING, CONSERVATION AND NUCLEAR POWER REVIEW
Abstrace: Pres Bush offers energy plan that calls for easing rules on oil and gas exploration, conservation-minded efforts like review of gas mileage standards and $4 billion tax credit for new generation of highly fuel efficient cars, and reconsideration of ban on reprocessing of nuclear fuel; warns America faces most serious energy shortage since 1970's, threatening its economy and security; orders sweeping review of public lands to determine whether more energy resources can be extracted; will issue energy report outlining 105 initiatives; plans executive orders directing federal agencies to weigh effects of all new regulation on energy production and to expedite permits for all energy projects 'while remaining mindful of protecting' environment; releases report overview holding federal regulation has unduly inhibited energy production and raised prices; report repeats Bush's commitment to explore for oil in Arctic National Wildlife Refuge; urges revision or reinterpretation of major Clean Air Act provision that requires long government review of any modifications of power plants that affect emissions; photos (M)

Title: ANWR And Peas
Abstrace: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column says Senate vote rejecting proposal to raise mileage standards on cars was result of alliance between conservatives and union leaders, same alliance that led House to support drilling in Alaskan wildlife refuge last summer; says fighting conservation gives Teamsters union leadership opportunity to look powerful; says union leadership surely knows that there will not be 700,000 new jobs in Alaska drilling, but union members do not know that; says union leaders also surely know that higher efficiency standards will not cost any auto worker jobs; says this alliance between showboating union leaders and conservatives could do much damage to nation's future (M)

Title: Joseph Hazelwood, Captain of the Exxon Valdez, Is Dead at 75
Abstrace: The tanker spilled millions of gallons of oil when it ran aground, causing one of the nation’s worst environmental disasters. He accepted responsibility but was demonized.

Title: Administration Expected to Endorse Limited Drilling in Alaska Project
Abstrace: An environmental review expected soon would effectively signal that the Willow project proceed, according to people familiar with the report.

Title: Interior Dept. Expedites Review of Arctic Drilling After Accidents
Abstrace: Officials said an assessment could halt or scale back Shell’s program to open Alaska’s Arctic waters to oil exploration.

Title: National Briefing
Abstrace: WEST

Title: Trump Administration Releases Plan to Open Tongass Forest to Logging
Abstrace: The effort to open the Alaskan wilderness area, the nation’s largest national forest, has been in the works for about two years.

Title: Tsunami Debris Strains Budgets and Patience
Abstrace: States along the Pacific Coast worry that vast amounts of trash will wash up and are concerned about invasive species.

Title: Starving Orcas and the Fate of Alaska’s Disappearing King Salmon
Abstrace: With the fish numbers at historic lows, scientists, chefs and others are asking whether we should be eating them anymore, and what it means for the future of all wild salmon.

Title: Walkout Sours Global Whaling Conference
Abstrace: Joined by allies, Japan, Norway and Iceland leave a whaling conference when countries try to call a vote on creating a whale sanctuary. Usually such decisions are made by consensus.

Title: Biden Administration Approves Huge Alaska Oil Project
Abstrace: The administration also announced new limits on Arctic drilling in an apparent effort to temper criticism over the $8 billion Willow oil project, which has faced sharp opposition.

Title: Biden to Restore Protections for Tongass National Forest in Alaska
Abstrace: Former President Donald J. Trump invited mining and logging to a vast wilderness of bald eagles, black bears and 800-year-old trees. President Biden is reversing course.

Title: On the Water in Alaska, Where Salmon Fishing Dreams Live On
Abstrace: Each summer, salmon begin their journey back to the rivers where they were spawned. Alaskan fishermen, along with whales, eagles and bears, share in the abundance.

Title: Biden Administration Offers an Offshore Drilling Plan. Likely Backers: Very Few.
Abstrace: The five-year plan for America’s coastal waters, required by law, risks angering both the fossil fuel industry and environmentalists.

Title: Obama Makes Urgent Appeal in Alaska for Climate Change Action
Abstrace: President Obama said at an international conference that “we’re not acting fast enough,” challenging leaders and citizens to reduce emissions to “protect the one planet that we’ve got while we still can.”

Title: Rig Runs Aground in Alaska, Reviving Fears About Arctic Drilling
Abstrace: There are no signs of spilled fuel, but that remains a concern as long as the Shell Oil vessel is stuck; the Coast Guard hopes to get salvage experts aboard to assess the damage.

Title: Biden Administration Defends Huge Alaska Oil Drilling Project
Abstrace: The administration says the country must pivot away from fossil fuels but backed a project set to produce more than 100,000 barrels of oil each day for 30 years.

Title: OBSERVATORY
Abstrace: University of Helsinki researchers study sand goby, small shallows-swelling fish, and find mating habits change when water is cloudy; study, published in Proceedings of the Royal Society B, shows larger fish do not have advantage over smaller fish in attracting females when female fish cannot clearly see through water; Dr Robert Bleiweiss of University of Wisconsin leads study that suggests two species of mountain tanagers are distinguished by UV reflectance of their plumage, not outward appearance, which can be almost identical; study is published in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences; Leonid meteor shower viewing is expected to be at its peak around 2 am on November 19 on East Coast of United States; Dr Paul Matheus of University of Alaska discovers bear jawbone in Edmonton, Alberta, museum which he dates at around 25,000 years old; find suggests that bears made it farther south into Alaska and Yukon earlier than originally thought; Mathews speculates that bears were trapped below rather than behind ice front during their migration; drawing (M)

Title: Trump Imperils the Planet
Abstrace: Endangered species, climate change — the administration is taking the country, and the world, backward.

Title: Shell Oil’s Cold Calculations for a Warming World
Abstrace: What the company’s Arctic drilling plans say about how it and the Obama administration see the future of energy.

Title: Gore Expands on Clinton's Forest Protection Plan
Abstrace: Vice Pres Al Gore wades into one of nation's most contentious environmental debates, pledging to prohibit logging and road building on 43 million acres of undeveloped national forests if elected President; trumps recent proposal by Clinton administration that would bar road building across same broad swath of roadless land in 155 national forests and grasslands that accounts for approximately quarter of entire forest system and includes many of its most pristine areas; addresses criticisms of Clinton plan by environmentalists that it did not go far enough since it would still allow logging in undeveloped forests and explicitly exempted Tongass National Forest in Alaska, nation's largest; Gore strongly suggests he would extend same protections to Tongass, where conservation efforts have been opposed by Alaska's influential Congressional delegation; he wins endorsement of League of Conservation voters; photo (M)

Title: Biden Administration Expected to Move Ahead on a Major Oil Project in Alaska
Abstrace: The decision would allow an enormous $8 billion drilling project in the largest expanse of pristine wilderness in the United States.

Title: Trump Administration Finalizes Plan to Open Arctic Refuge to Drilling
Abstrace: The decision sets up a fierce legal battle over the fate of a vast, remote area that is home to polar bears, caribou and the promise of oil wealth.

Title: Biden’s Fossil Fuel Moves Clash With Pledges on Climate Change
Abstrace: Over the past month the Biden administration has defended three significant oil and gas projects, raising concerns among environmentalists that climate policy is being undermined

Title: PBS Series Explores ‘A New Wild’ Sustained, Instead of Wrecked, by People
Abstrace: In a new PBS series, a conservation biologist explores how people can be a nurturing presence in what used to be called “the wild.”

Title: CHENEY PROMOTES INCREASING SUPPLY AS ENERGY POLICY
Abstrace: Vice Pres Dick Cheney says oil, coal and natural gas will remain America's primary energy resources for foreseeable future, and that Bush administration's energy strategy will aim mainly to increase supply of fossil fuels, rather than limit demand; dismisses as 1970's-era thinking notion that rationing and conservation are answers to nation's energy problems; says only solution is government-backed push to find new domestic sources of oil and gas, including in protected areas of Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, and all-out drive to build power plants; comments at annual meeting of Associated Press in Toronto is most comprehensive comments to date on energy task force he is heading on behalf of Pres Bush; seems partly combative response to Democrats and environmentalists, who argue that administration is using California's electricity shortages as pretext to enact energy policies favored by industry executives for many years; photo (M)

Title: How Biden Got From ‘No More Drilling’ to Backing a Huge Project in Alaska
Abstrace: High gas prices, a looming election and fears of a costly legal battle seem to have shifted the political calculus for the president.

Title: Alaska Thaws, Complicating the Hunt for Oil
Abstrace: Warming climate in Alaska's Arctic tundra has reduced number of days seismic vehicles can search for oil reserves to only 103 days compared to 189 days in 1969; Harry Bader, Department of Natural Resources land manager for North Slope, has begun two-year testing process to redefine guidelines for exploration of tundra; current test to determine if vehicles can drive on tundra without harm to ecosystem is six inches of snow and one foot of frozen ground; Bader maintains that more precise measurement of ground conditions and extensive testing and observation of limited area of tundra under pressure from vehicles will yield new ideas that will protect environment and foster exploration; Alaska Conservation Foundation executive director Deborah Williams warns of damaging America's only Arctic region by making policy changes during period when North Slope is already experiencing warming and change; map; photos; graph (L)

Title: In Pristine Alaska, an Oil Giant Prepares to Drill for Decades
Abstrace: Scientists say nations must stop new oil and gas projects to avoid climate catastrophe. But after the Biden administration greenlit the $8 billion Willow project, ConocoPhillips is racing ahead.

Title: Too Soon Gone – Gary Braasch, Visual Chronicler of Climate Change
Abstrace: A photographer roaming the globe to chronicle global warming dies exploring an imperiled reef.

Title: A BIG PUSH IS ON FOR NATURAL GAS UNDER THE ARCTIC
Abstrace: Plans are under way to build one, possibly two, subterranean pipelines to carry Arctic gas to North America's pipeline grid; $10 billion undertaking would take seven years and faces environmental problems and opposition from some conservation groups; for last three decades geologists have been mapping largest known untapped reserves of natural gas in Alaska and Northern Canada; until recently, with gas prices low, indigenous opposition high and environmental issues looming, energy companies have been unable to find way to build pipelines to send gas south; now, with wholesale prices for natural gas doubling in year, with Energy Dept forecasting that demand for natural gas in US will rise 40 percent in next two decades, and with native groups dropping their opposition as they see opportunities for royalties and jobs, push is on to tap Arctic reserves; map with proposed pipeline routes (L)

Title: Ferries in Alaska. Rail in Oregon. States Dream Big on Infrastructure Funds.
Abstrace: The infrastructure bill could reshape priorities across the country, jump-starting critical projects that stalled over funding. These are some of the possibilities.

Title: A Wrenching Choice for Alaska Towns in the Path of Climate Change
Abstrace: Alaska is warming about twice as fast as the rest of the nation. So what are the dozens of villages at imminent risk of destruction to do?

Title: New and Frozen Frontier Awaits Offshore Oil Drilling
Abstrace: Despite lively opposition, Shell will start testing wells in northern Alaska, in a moment of major promise and considerable danger.

Title: 52 Places for a Changed World
Abstrace: The 2022 list highlights places around the globe where travelers can be part of the solution.

Title: The Wreck of the Kulluk
Abstrace: Three years ago, Shell spent millions to send a colossal oil rig to drill in the remote seas of the Arctic. But the Arctic had other plans.

Title: Since the Oil Spill
Abstrace: Letter from ExxonMobil vice president Kenneth P Cohen says company has been penalized for ExxonValdez oil spill, worked to prevent future accidents and made whole those directly affected

Title: Toxic in Brooklyn
Abstrace: Letter from Marty Markowitz, Brooklyn, NY, borough president, says Brooklynites applaud cleanup effort from Exxon Valdez oil spill (Jun 2 article) but want ExxonMobil to clean up 'long-ignored' oil leak between Greenpoint, Brooklyn and Queens

Title: Big Oil and the Arctic
Abstrace: Susan Alexander letter opposes oil drilling in Arctic National Wildlife Refuge (Jan 30 article); drawing

Title: Energy, in the Arctic and California
Abstrace: Letter by American Petroleum Institute president Red Cavaney says that oil exploration does not automatically lead of corruption of areas like Arctic national wildlife refuge, and adds that industry has never maintained that development of coastal plain should be first step in solving country's energy problems (S)

Title: Polluting Industries Say the Cost of Cleaner Air Is Too High
Abstrace: As the Biden administration prepares to toughen air quality standards, health benefits are weighed against the cost of compliance.

Title: In a U.S. First, a Commercial Plant Starts Pulling Carbon From the Air
Abstrace: The technique is expensive but it could help fight climate change. Backers hope fast growth can bring down costs.

Title: Gazing Into the Past and Future at Historic Observatories
Abstrace: As ever-larger telescopes are launched into space or built at high-altitude sites, these observatories still have wonders to share with visitors and astronomers alike.

Title: America’s Disaster Recovery System Is a Disaster
Abstrace: The help Americans receive after disasters isn’t just inadequate; it’s complicated to navigate and painfully slow to arrive.

Title: California Governor to Sign Landmark Climate Disclosure Bill
Abstrace: The first-in-the-nation law will compel major companies to publicly disclose their carbon dioxide emissions and could have national repercussions.

Title: California Lawmakers Vote to Require Disclosure of Greenhouse Emissions
Abstrace: Under the measure, companies would have to publicly report their climate pollution. Gov. Gavin Newsom’s office would not say whether he plans to sign the bill.

Title: Holiday Fireworks Worsen Air Quality Nationwide
Abstrace: Seattle, New York City and Los Angeles were among the places with high air quality indexes after fireworks celebrations.

Title: At the Front On Pollution
Abstrace: News analysis of California's move to once again set lead on environmental policy in US, as its Legislature approves bill to require cuts in tailpipe emissions of greenhouse gases by cars and light trucks; law would be major defeat for auto industry, which fears curb on sport utility vehicles, and victory for environmental coalition and Democratic supporters such as Sens John Kerry, John McCain and Joseph Lieberman; attempt in Senate to raise fuel standards failed in March; bill directs state board to decide 'maximum feasible reduction' in emissions by 2005, with effective date of 2009 car model year; photo; chart on states with highest carbon dioxide emissions, showing Texas first, California second (M)

Title: Fighting Pollution From Microbeads Used in Soaps and Creams

Title: New Tactic in California for Paying Pollution Bill

Title: For Cruise Ships, A History of Pollution

Title: California Builders Fight Air Pollution Fee

Title: White House Prepares to Revoke California’s Right to Set Tougher Pollution Rules

Title: California Builders Fight Air Pollution Fee

Title: U.S. Will Get Power, and Pollution, From Mexico
Abstrace: Two huge power plants under construction in Mexicali desert near US border will generate billions of watts of electricity for State of California, handful of jobs for Mexicans and pollution on both sides of border; Mexico's Energy Sec Ernesto Martens says they will be first of many built in Mexico specifically to provide power for US under terms of North American Free Trade Agreement, and will mark new phase in relations between both nations; plants will represent new way of generating wealth and power by capitalizing on economic and legal differences between both nations; will be powered by natural gas piped from Texas and cooled by Mexicali's sewage; will be part of California's power grid by 2003; are being built by InterGen and Bechtel Corp; map; photo (M)

Title: California Lawmakers Move to Fight U.S. Pollution Rules

Title: Automakers Tell Trump His Pollution Rules Could Mean ‘Untenable’ Instability and Lower Profits

Abstrace: Even distant fires can send dangerous, imperceptible pollution to your doorstep.

Title: Faced With New Air Standards, California's Earthbound Farmers Are Wary

Title: Wildfire Smoke Is Poisoning California’s Kids. Some Pay a Higher Price.

Title: California Air Is Cleaner, but Troubles Remain

Title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Protection For Salmon

Title: California Rules

Title: California Lawmakers Vote To Lower Auto Emissions

Abstrace: The disaster in the gulf has strengthened opposition to oil drilling in California.

Title: Trump Gave Automakers What They Wanted. Biden Shouldn’t.
Abstrace: Trump gutted emissions reductions. The president must make up for time lost.

Title: How Growth in Dairy Is Affecting the Environment
Abstrace: Industrial-scale farms in California — and their pollution — are at the center of a global debate about how to tackle global warming.

Title: Cocktails and Fist-Pumping: California’s Ballot Battle
Abstrace: An unusual alliance of environmental activists and financiers try to enlist minority voters to defeat the repeal of California’s global warming law.

Title: The Silence of the Leaves
Abstrace: Editorial praises Los Angeles area's South Coast Air Quality Management District for encouraging landscapers to replace old, polluting leaf blowers with new machines that run cleaner and more quietly; urges politicians, including Greenburgh Town Supervisor Paul Feiner, to follow suit

Title: Electric Cars May Lose Push In Northeast
Abstrace: New York, Massachusetts and Vermont may postpone until 2007 requirement that electric cars be sold, and may promote use of other emission-reduction technologies instead; state officials claim change could actually produce deeper cut in tailpipe pollution in first few years, while giving car companies needed flexibility; environmental groups question that claim and say retreat by Northeast states would damage efforts to make electric cars commonplace and economicaly viable; move leaves California as only state requiring sales of electric cars over next several years, cutting market for them in half; New York's environmental conservation commissioner, Erin Crotty, says postponing electric car mandate is state's recognition that automakers are not yet ready to produce them; automakers have said they would be unable to make commercially viable electric cars in time to meet California mandate that begins with 2003 model year (M)

Title: In the Race to Produce More Power, States Are Faced With Environmental Tradeoffs
Abstrace: Article describes crash construction projects in West, in states such as Arizona, to build new electric power plants; push began well before problems in California, which is suffering rolling blackouts and sharply rising electricity rates; photo (M)

Title: California Sues 6 Automakers Over Global Warming
Abstrace: California, which has battled the automotive industry over new global warming regulations for years, sued the world's six-largest automakers yesterday, demanding that they pay for environmental damage caused by the emissions of their vehicles.     ''Global warming is causing significant harm to California's environment, economy, agriculture and public health,'' said the state's attorney general, Bill Lockyer.

Title: ‘Pit of Infection’: A Border Town’s Crisis Has Nothing to Do With Migrants
Abstrace: Noxious sewage contaminated with feces, industrial chemicals and other raw waste crosses the border through the binational New River.

Title: How California Can Save the Amazon
Abstrace: The state should help preserve rain forests through its cap and trade system for reducing greenhouse gas emissions.

Title: E.P.A. Takes a Major Step to Roll Back Clean Car Rules
Abstrace: The Trump administration formally submitted its plan to permit more tailpipe emissions, moving closer to a legal clash that could split the nation’s auto market.

Title: Editors' Note
Abstrace: Editors' Note on July 11 item about Clean Beaches Council, which rates US public beaches for cleanliness and safety; article said council president Walter McLeod, when asked why California had not been included, speculated that heavy use of state's beaches was major factor; e-mails from Huntington Beach Conference and Visitors Bureau and California Coastal Coalition note that council charges communities $2,500 to be listed and $1,250 a year to remain certified if they continue to meet other criteria (M)

Title: E.P.A. Sued Over Mercury in the Air
Abstrace: New Jersey and eight other states file lawsuit challenging Environmental Protection Agency rule that they claim does not do enough to control dangerous mercury emissions from coal-fired power plants (M)

Title: General Motors Sues California Over Quota for Electric Car Sales
Abstrace: General Motors Corp files suit seeking to invalidate new California rule that would require automobile manufacturers to sell thousands of electric cars in state each year starting in 2003; GM contends rule violates state laws requiring regulations to be reasonable and prudent; says battery-powered cars are impractical and that rule will bring about only minuscule reduction in air pollution at cost of hundreds of millions of dollars (M)

Title: 24 Governors Call on Trump to Halt Rollback on Rules for Clean Cars
Abstrace: The governors, including two Republicans and governors of four states that voted for President Trump in 2016, are urging his administration to halt his rollback of clean car rules.

Title: California Requires Plastics Makers to Foot the Bill for Recycling
Abstrace: The landmark legislation also restricts single-use plastics. Because California’s economy is so big, experts say, the law could have far-reaching effects.

Title: E.P.A. Says 17 States Can’t Set Emission Rules
Abstrace: The E.P.A. said the proposed California rules were made moot by the energy bill signed into law by President Bush on Wednesday.

Title: Flying Through Fire With a Notepad and a Prayer
Abstrace: When I learned of a scientific mission to study wildfire smoke by flying through fires on a jet plane, I immediately asked to join the trip.

Title: Trump Muddies the Air
Abstrace: To dismantle the Obama climate legacy, he’s taking on California, the auto industry, the Clean Air Act and public opinion.

Title: Reckonings; Smog and Mirrors
Abstrace: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column contends that Pres Bush is trying to dispel doubts about his legitimacy when he blames pollution controls for California energy crisis and uses crisis to argue for opening Arctic tundra to oil drilling; asserts that that by winning series of striking victories against moderates Bush hopes he can create an 'illusion of a mandate' that the election did not give him (M)

Title: I Live in California. How Do I Know It’s Safe to Go Outside?
Abstrace: A high-tech sensor network brought me closer to the natural cycles of my environment.

Title: California Orders Low-Sulfur Fuel for Ships
Abstrace: California ordered the 2,000 big ships calling on its ports every year to switch to low-sulfur fuel whenever they were within 24 miles of the coast.

Title: California and Quebec Near an Agreement for Trading of Carbon Permits
Abstrace: Businesses that exceed their allowances of greenhouse gas emissions would be able to buy excess allowances from companies across the border.

Title: Federal Judge Upholds Law on Emissions in California
Abstrace: A federal judge in Sacramento upheld a California law regulating greenhouse gas emissions from cars and trucks, another in a string of legal defeats for the auto industry this year.

Title: The American West’s Haunting, Smoke-Filled Future
Abstrace: Wildfire pollution is threatening the health gains of the Clean Air Act.

Title: Ten States With a Plan
Abstrace: Until Washington takes more responsibility for addressing global warming, the states should take the lead.

Title: Justice Department Drops Antitrust Probe Against Automakers That Sided With California on Emissions
Abstrace: The Justice Department has told four carmakers that they violated no laws when they negotiated a fuel economy standard with California that is more stringent than Washington’s.

Title: Don’t Roll Back the Vehicle Fuel Standards
Abstrace: These benchmarks are the most important action the nation has taken to reduce its dependence on oil and address climate change.

Title: A Bay Area Community Wants to Protect Its Dark Skies
Abstrace: West Marin is hoping to become a Dark Sky community.

Title: Trying to Breathe in the Bay Area
Abstrace: My neighbors are wearing gas masks to pick lemons in their back yard. Is this the new normal?

Title: As Warehouses Multiply, Some Cities Say: Enough
Abstrace: Several municipalities in California’s Inland Empire have halted new projects to study their impact on pollution and congestion, but labor and business groups have warned that moratoriums could cost the region tax revenue and jobs.

Title: Why Gavin Newsom Rejected These 5 Bills
Abstrace: California’s governor vetoed a mandatory kindergarten proposal, as well as an effort to reduce light pollution.

Title: Honda Urges Toughening of Fuel-Economy Rules
Abstrace: Honda Motor, in unheard of request from an automaker, urges federal government to impose tougher fuel-economy regulations; request follows decision by Honda and Nissan to join industry lawsuit against California, which is seeking to regulate car and truck emissions that are said to worsen global warming (S)

Title: Suit Dismissed on Rules Limiting Trash in California Waterways
Abstrace: Judge Saundra Brown Armstrong dismisses lawsuit by 22 cities in Southern California challenging regulations to reduce trash in local waterways; National Resources Defense Council lawyer notes that while littering is illegal in every community in Southern California, as much as 3,000 tons of trash makes its way onto ocean beaches in any given year (M)

Title: A Reminder That Science Can Override Pressure
Abstrace: The death of an ozone researcher brings to mind the work of Arie Jan Haagen-Smit, who did seminal work on smog. The attacks that both suffered before they were vindicated raises the question of whether climate scientists will one day be widely appreciated.

Title: California Adopts Limits on Greenhouse Gases
Abstrace: The new system includes cap-and-trade market incentives to encourage polluters to clean up their plants, an approach much of the rest of the country has resisted.

Title: National Briefing: West
Abstrace: CALIFORNIA: Leaning Toward Emissions Bill; CALIFORNIA: Accident Kills 4 In Family; CALIFORNIA: Appeal In Dog-Mauling Case;.

Title: California's Message to George Pataki
Abstrace: Editorial on California's new landmark law requiring automakers to reduce emissions of carbon dioxide; urges New York Gov George Pataki to sustain momentum of Gov Gray Davis

Title: California Law to Curb Greenhouse Gases Faces a Legal Hurdle
Abstrace: Judge Ernest H. Goldsmith of San Francisco Superior Court issued a tentative opinion saying that the rules creating a cap-and-trade system were adopted without proper analysis of alternatives.

Title: California Air Board Moves to Increase Presence of Zero-Emissions Vehicles
Abstrace: The California Air Resources Board introduced a package of regulations that would mandate significantly higher numbers of the vehicles, as well as a more stringent smog standard.

Title: California to Require Half of All Heavy Trucks Sold by 2035 to Be Electric
Abstrace: The state is setting strict limits to try to eliminate carbon dioxide emissions from transportation, the sector of the American economy that generates the most greenhouse gases.

Title: Air Quality in California: Devastating Fires Lead to a New Danger
Abstrace: A week after the most destructive fire in state history ripped through this small town, the flames have been replaced by a new danger: the air.

Title: California Is Ready for a Fight Over Tailpipe Emissions. Here’s Why.
Abstrace: California officials have said they will fight in court any attempt by the Trump administration to revoke or bypass their power to set their own auto emissions standards. Here are three big issues for the state.

Title: Quietly, Trump Officials and California Seek a Deal on Car Emissions
Abstrace: Behind-the-scenes talks could preserve some rules targeted by the Environmental Protection Agency for elimination.

Title: California Bill Calls for Cuts in Emissions
Abstrace: Legislation is introduced in California State Assembly that would make state first to impose limits on greenhouse gas emissions; bill would require carbon dioxide emissions and other gases linked to global warming to be reduced 25 percent by 2020, bringing emissions back to 1990 level; legislation could have national impact because California has often led nation in pollution-control efforts (M)

Title: Will California Ever Let Sierra Nevada Forests Burn?
Abstrace: In the Sierra Nevada, California’s main forest fire problem lies in not letting forests burn.

Title: Toyota’s Support of Trump Emissions Rules Shocks Californians
Abstrace: Toyota’s support of the Trump administration in its fight with California over auto emissions shocked consumers in a state known for its environmental activism.

Title: In Reversal, Rowland Vetoes Bill to Cut Emissions at 6 Power Plants
Abstrace: Gov John G Rowland vetoes bill that would have forced Connecticut's six oldest and least efficient power plants to cut emissions of smog-forming sulfur dioxide and end plants' ability buy federal emission credits from other, cleaner plants in Northeast; says bill, which he earlier said he would sign, would worsen state's air quality on smoggiest days and leave state open to California-style power shortages this summer; Democrats and environmentalists say veto show Rowland cares more about power-industry profits than clean air (M)

Title: In the Case of the Dead Otters, Evidence Points to Opossums
Abstrace: Large numbers of sea otters, both dead and alive, have been washing ashore along California coast; most die from either toxoplasma gondii or sarcocystis neurona, which are parasites that cause fatal diseases in otter brains and nervous systems; Dr Melissa Miller, University of California Davis) wildlife veterinarian and pathologist, holds otters likely are infected with parasites, which come from cat and opossum feces in shellfish contaminated from runoffs of heavy spring rains; 2,100 to 2,500 otters have died each year since 1995; map; photo (M)

Title: The Nation; A New Role for Greens: Public Enemy
Abstrace: Comment on Bush administration's identification of environmentalists as new 'public enemy' in perceived energy shortage; cites proposals to ease environmental controls, reversal of Pres Clinton's orders tightening arsenic-in-water standards, abandonment of campaign pledge on power plant emissions, and blaming 'green tape' for blocking energy projects; notes that some of measures under consideration have, at best, tangential relationship to California's power shortage; photo

Title: New York City and 8 States Plan to Sue Power Plants
Abstrace: Eight states and New York City will file federal lawsuit demanding 'substantial cuts' in carbon dioxide emissions by five major utility companies that operate 174 power plants (M)

Title: How to Get Better Air Quality
Abstrace: You can improve air quality indoors with the three “-ations”: filtration, ventilation and circulation.

Title: Officials Reach California Deal to Cut Emissions
Abstrace: The agreement imposes the most sweeping controls on carbon dioxide emissions in the nation.

Title: Oil Giants to Settle Water Suit
Abstrace: A dozen oil companies agreed to pay $423 million in cash plus clean-up costs to settle litigation over groundwater contamination from the gasoline additive, MTBE.

Title: National Briefing | West: California: Mystery In Sea Otter Census
Abstrace: Census by US Geological Survey finds sea otters are disappearing off California coast, and that researchers are at loss to explain why; spring tally found 2,139 otters, down from 2,161 in 2001; photo (S)

Title: In Visiting a Charred California, Trump Confronts a Scientific Reality He Denies
Abstrace: A president who has mocked climate change and pushed policies that accelerate it is set to be briefed on the scorched earth and ash-filled skies that experts say are the predictable result.

Title: Bottled Water Is Sucking Florida Dry
Abstrace: The state’s aquifers are shrinking, yet corporations want to appropriate even more of them.

Title: China Should Match California’s Effort to Slow Climate Change
Abstrace: By pledging to cut its emissions in half by midcentury, China would propel itself into a world-leading role in the fight against global warming.

Title: Fighting Trump on Climate, California Becomes a Global Force
Abstrace: The state has been at the leading edge of the resistance to President Trump. But of all the battles, none have the global implications of climate change.

Title: New Day on Climate Change
Abstrace: President Obama’s decision on emissions in California shows his commitment to the cause of reversing the rise in greenhouse gases.

Title: OBSERVATORY
Abstrace: Researchers at Oregon Health and Science University discover that immature male elephants secrete sweet-smelling chemicals from temple glands during annual musth, signal to adult males that they are not threat during mating season; University of Washington atmospheric scientist, in report published in Nature, discovers smog inversion-related phenomenon described as clean air sandwich--thin layer of stable, clean air trapped between two polluted ones, mostly found over southern Africa during mornings in August and September; researchers at Univesity of California at San Diego, in papers in journals Conservation Biology and Ecology Applications, blame Argentine ants, which are wiping out many larger ant species in some areas, for decline of already threatened coastal horned lizards in southern California; drawing (M)

Title: Officials Reach California Deal to Cut Emissions
Abstrace: California's political leaders announced an agreement on Wednesday that imposes the most sweeping controls on carbon dioxide emissions in the nation, putting the state at the forefront of a broad campaign to curb the man-made causes of climate change despite resistance in Washington.     The deal between the Democratic-controlled Legislature and the Republican governor, Arnold Schwarzenegger, calls for a 25 percent reduction in carbon dioxide emissions by 2020, and could establish controls on the largest industrial sectors, including utilities, oil refineries and cement plants. The state has already placed strict limits on automobile emissions, although that move is being challenged in federal court.

Title: California’s governor seeks to ban new fracking and halt oil production, but not immediately.
Abstrace: In the past, Gov. Gavin Newsom has said he lacked the executive authority to halt fracking, which has long been a source of both pollution and higher-paying jobs in California.

Title: California Air Quality: Should You Wear a Face Mask for Wildfire Smoke?
Abstrace: Residents in the Bay Area and Los Angeles complained of poor air quality. The best thing to do about it? “Stay indoors.”

Title: Here Come the Last-Minute Riders
Abstrace: Editorial urges Senate to reject series of spending bill riders offered by Sen Ted Stevens that would undercut efforts of Alaska's regional fishing managers to preserve essential fish habitat and dwindling fish species; opposes Sen Christopher Bond spending bill amendment that would strip California of its authority to set its own air quality standards, mainly to benefit two Briggs & Stratton lawn equipment plants in Missouri

Title: Charbroiling Burgers: An Air-Quality Scourge That May Be Worse Than Diesel Trucks
Abstrace: Authors of a study claimed that fewer particulate emissions were produced by running commercial diesel engines than by charbroiling hamburgers.

Title: National Briefing: West
Abstrace: CALIFORNIA: Police Check Bodies For Missing Woman ; CALIFORNIA: Boating Kills 4 Otters ;.

Title: California Redoes Its Greenhouse Gas Analysis
Abstrace: Responding to a judge’s order, state regulators in California undertook a new analysis of how different strategies would succeed in reducing emissions. The bottom line: they think cap-and-trade would work best.

Title: California Sets Up Statewide Network to Monitor Global-Warming Gases
Abstrace: The monitoring system is believed to be the first statewide network and is meant to help the state find specific sources of emissions.

Title: E.P.A. Staff Lobbied Boss on Decision on Emissions
Abstrace: Senator Barbara Boxer of California suggested a link to the denial of her state’s request to set rules for auto emissions.

Title: California Monks Wage Fight on Developers
Abstrace: Orange County, Calif, Board of Supervisors approves 283-home, 600-acre development on geologically unstable foothill in shadow of Saddleback Mountains, over unanimous objections of county-appointed advisory board and despite several lawsuits; supervisors then approve two more projects nearby; among chief critics are Hindu monks, whose monastary is tucked on 40 acres adjoining projected development; critics say largest development poses threat of landslide and added pollution runoff that will reach state's dirtiest beaches; photo (M)

Title: P What? PZEV’s Are Unsung Heroes in the Push to Clean Up the Air
Abstrace: Partial emissions vehicle standards refers to cars certified to standard set by California regulators; cars that meet criteria are specially equipped versions of familiar models that use improved pollution-control system to meet California's toughest tailpipe standard for cars with combustion engines; exhaust can be as clean as that of many hybrids, yet cars do not incur hybrid's price premium of several thousand dollars; few buyers know about these cars, as they have not been promoted heavily; chart; photos (M)

Title: California Leads on Warming
Abstrace: Tony Blair, the British prime minister, who worries about global warming more than any other world leader, has finally found an important American ally: Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger of California.

Title: New Emission Rule for Bay Area Refineries
Abstrace: California air regulators adopt rule intended to reduce sharply fiery flares and excess gas emissions vented from oil refineries in Bay Area; rule is first of its kind in nation; it is aimed at decreasing level of hazardous air pollutants released by flares, emergency mechanism used to vent excess pressure inside plants; similar rule is under consideration for Los Angeles area (M)

Title: California Leads on Warming
Abstrace: Editorial says California is filling federal leadership vacuum on global warming with proposal to require automakers to cut emissions of carbon dioxide and other suspect gases by as much as thirty percent over next decade

Title: Canada Says It May Emulate California on Auto Emissions
Abstrace: Canada's Environment Min David Anderson says his country will emulate California's new law aimed at curbing automotive global warming emissions if carmarkers do not agree to make significant reductions (M)

Title: Fuel of the Future? Some Say Coal
Abstrace: More than 100 coal-fired electric plants are vying for approval around US, driven by intensifying concerns about supplies of natural gas, and clashes over air quality are expected because coal, although significantly cleaner than it once was, is still dirtier than gas; many of new plants would be built in places with pristine air quality and relatively lax pollution restrictions; people of Gerlach, Nev, who number fewer than 200, are alarmed by Sempra Energy's plans for coal-fired plant there that would supply power to Los Angeles and San Diego; photos; graph shows amount of electricity generated by natural gas, coal and other (M)

Title: White House Joins Fight Against Electric Cars
Abstrace: Bush administration asks court to support automobile industry's effort to eliminate requirements in California that auto manufacturers sell electric cars; state's clean air rules require that 10 percent of vehicles sold in 2003 to 2008 model years be electric of 'zero-emission' vehicles, but state, recognizing that companies were not ready to meet that goal, offered to let them meet part of requirement with hybrid gasoline-and-electric vehicles depending on their fuel economy; administration says this provision effective regulates fuel economy sandards, over which federal government holds exclusive jurisdiction; Andrew H Card Jr, Pres Bush's chief of staff, was chief lobbyist for General Motors, one of plaintiffs in case (M)

Title: California Assembly Passes Bill to Limit a Greenhouse Gas
Abstrace: California Assembly passes bill that would set first standards in nation for regulating automotive emissions of carbon dioxide in effort to combat global warming; photo (M)

Title: Group That Beat Back Proposition 23 Is Reborn
Abstrace: “We’re getting the band back together” to push for green jobs in California, said the hedge fund billionaire Thomas F. Steyer, who has joined forces once again with the former secretary of state George P. Shultz.

Title: California Sues Trump Administration Over Car Emissions Rules
Abstrace: The state's move escalates a revolt against a proposed rollback of fuel economy standards that threatens to split the country’s auto market.

Title: Modifying California’s Petroleum Diet
Abstrace: A bipartisan group of Californians proposes that the state treat oil as gasoline consumption as it does greenhouse gas emissions, adopting policies that mandate and reward cuts.

Title: E.P.A. Readies Plan to Weaken Rules That Require Cars to Be Cleaner
Abstrace: The agency has drafted regulations on planet-warming emissions from vehicles that would dramatically weaken Obama-era standards.

Title: The Ashes of the Dixie Fire Cast a Pall 1,000 Miles From Its Flames
Abstrace: The megafires of the West are sending out giant clouds of smoke and leaving a footprint much larger than the evergreen forests they level and the towns they decimate.

Title: Your Gas Stove Is Bad for You and the Planet
Abstrace: To help solve the climate crisis, we need to electrify everything.

Title: ‘This Does Not Look Good for Children’: Fires Pose Risk to Young Lungs
Abstrace: The wildfires blazing in the West could hinder developing lungs, worsen asthma and even lead to the condition in those who don’t have it but are genetically disposed to it.

Title: Heat, Smoke and Covid Are Battering the Workers Who Feed America
Abstrace: Climate change is piling on to the hazards already faced by  California farm laborers, some of the country's poorest, most neglected workers.

Title: Cleaner Cars for New York
Abstrace: Editorial says New York State announced adoption of California's strict new limits on automobile emissions of carbon dioxide, major global warming gas; says governors who take global warming more seriously than Pres Bush and Congress do--including Republicans Arnold Schwarzenegger and George Pataki--have decided to take matters into their own hands

Title: California Fire and Floods Turn a River to ‘Sludge,’ Killing Thousands of Fish
Abstrace: Flash floods last week pushed burned soil, rocks and downed timber into the river, killing off, according to local tribal leaders, thousands of fish.

Title: E.P.A. Denies California Emission’s Waiver
Abstrace: The Bush administration said it will deny California’s bid to set stricter vehicle emissions standards than federal law required.

Title: California’s CO2 Now Has a Price, but a Low One
Abstrace: Officials express relief that all of the emissions allowances offered in the state’s first cap and trade auction were sold. Still, the $10.09 price left some participants feeling deflated.

Title: California Will Offer Plan to Cut Harmful Emissions
Abstrace: California will introduce a plan to cut greenhouse gas emissions to 1990 levels in 12 years, mostly by capping emissions from utilities and other businesses.

Title: The Week in Business: No More E-Cigarettes at Walmart, and an Attack on the World’s Oil Supply
Abstrace: Plus, a battle over California’s right to make its own car pollution rules.

Title: Bush to Insist on Ethanol Use in California
Abstrace: Bush administration will force California to use ethanol as antipollution fuel additive, move that critics say could increase gasoline prices by 5 cents per gallon during summer; will deny state's request to be exempted from Clean Air Act requirement to use additives to cleanse its gasoline on ground that cheaper technologies are available (M)

Title: Feeling the Heat
Abstrace: Editorial says Pres Bush seems increasingly isolated as he continues to run from issue of global warming; says warming issue is gaining traction at home and abroad, inspired partly by his incorrigible stubbornness

Title: Links, If You’re So Inclined
Abstrace: Your reading roundup for the week.

Title: Carmakers in Canada to Cut Emissions
Abstrace: Carmake

Title: Diesel, Cleaner, Is Set to Make a Comeback
Abstrace: With advances in diesel engineering and heightened interest in fuel economy, cars with diesel-powered engines are starting to sell again in the United States.

Title: California Leads the Way on Climate Change
Abstrace: With its new climate law, the state is again ahead of the rest of the country.

Title: California Recall Vote Could Weaken the State’s Aggressive Climate Policies
Abstrace: Many Republicans vying to replace Newsom as governor want to roll back the state’s ambitious plans to cut planet-warming emissions, a change with nationwide implications.

Title: Curb on Gas Emissions Is Stalled in California
Abstrace: Bill to reduce greenhouse gas emissions from automobiles stalls in California State Assembly; bill would be first to restrict automotive emissions of carbon dioxide and other gases thought by many scientists to be linked to global warming; bill directs California Air Resources Board to develop plan for reducing greenhouse gas emissions by January 2005, to be put into effect for 2009 model year; bill has met with staunch opposition from auto industry (M)

Title: Trump Stymies California Climate Efforts Even as State Burns
Abstrace: California is feeling the brunt of climate change with more intense fires. The Trump administration is blocking the state’s efforts to fight it.

Title: Making Yellow School Buses a Little More Green
Abstrace: Some school districts are replacing diesel buses with electric models to benefit students and the environment. But the change is expensive so utilities like Dominion Energy are helping offset the cost.

Title: California Weighs Tighter Fuel Economy
Abstrace: Initial draft of California global-warming regulation would require automakers to cut amounts of carbon dioxide and other gases linked to climate change that their new vehicles emit by as much as 30 percent over next decade; plan would make vehicles sold in California much more fuel efficient (M)

Title: The Auto Rule Rollback That Nobody Wants, Except Trump
Abstrace: The president is trying to sabotage an enormous climate achievement that much of the car industry supports.

Title: Pope Francis Aligns Himself With Mainstream Science on Climate
Abstrace: If anything, environmental scientists say, the pope may have bent over backward to offer a cautious interpretation of the scientific facts.

Title: The Dust Bowl Returns
Abstrace: What happens when America’s fruit basket becomes a desert?

Title: A Foil for the Koch Brothers?
Abstrace: The hedge fund manager Thomas F. Steyer speaks out against efforts to hobble the E.P.A.’s regulatory steps on greenhouse gases.

Title: More on Energy and Climate Paths for California and Beyond
Abstrace: Bright and downbeat views of next steps on energy and climate.

Title: Cap and Trade: Sweating the Small Stuff
Abstrace: A punctilious process limited the drama as California air regulators approved a program to reduce emissions linked to climate change.

Title: Piston Engine Holds Promise for Fuel Economy
Abstrace: A start-up venture is developing a four-stroke opposed piston engine that runs on a variety of fuels and wastes less energy as heat than internal combustion engines do.

Title: 9 States in Plan to Cut Emissions by Power Plants
Abstrace: Nine Northeastern states reportedly reach preliminary agreement to freeze power plant emissions at current levels and then reduce them by ten percent by 2020; photo; first such cooperative action follows Bush administration not to regulate greenhouse gases and would require legislation in each state; initiative would set up market-driven system to control carbon dioxide emissions from more than 600 electric generators, and could spur action nationally; California, Washington and Oregon explore similar agreement; Northeast states were brought together by New York Gov George Pataki, who broke sharply with administration on issue; spokesman declines comment on leaked draft; environmentalists say region's carbon dioxide emissions are about those of Germany, but that real significance of accord is example for other states (M)

Title: California Backs Plan for Big Cut in Car Emissions
Abstrace: California regulators approve plan aimed at drastically reducing over next 11 years vehicle emissions of gases that scientists link to global warming; California and seven Eastern states following its lead potentially represent 30 percent of automobile market; new standards challenge automakers to choose between building different vehicles for different markets or developing unified national strategy to meet standards; industry has fended off previous state efforts to regulate air quality, but states believe they will prevail this time; latest plan still faces expected legal challenge on multiple fronts from automakers and could be blocked by Bush administration; photo (M)

Title: U.S. Climate Change Policy: Made in California
Abstrace: A peculiar confluence of history, legal precedent and defiance has set the stage for a regulatory mutiny in California that would reverberate throughout the country.

Title: Where There’s Smoke, There’s a Conspiracy Theory at a Russian Consulate
Abstrace: Just what the Russians had set afire at their consulate in San Francisco, a day after the State Department ordered it shuttered, remains a burning question.

Title: Can California Avoid a ‘Shock to Trance’ Approach to Water Policy?
Abstrace: Can California battle inertia and pressure from its agriculture industry and become water resilient?

Title: California Plans Tighter Control of Fracking, but Not Enough for Some
Abstrace: Drillers ready to tap the giant Monterey Shale formation through the use of hydraulic fracturing face broad regulation for the first time.

Title: What to Know About California’s Fight With Trump Over Emissions
Abstrace: Thursday: Catch up on the escalating conflict. Also: Read about charges against Ed Buck, and see a Paso Robles light installation.

Title: Justice Dept. Investigates California Emissions Pact That Embarrassed Trump
Abstrace: The investigation escalates a standoff between President Trump, California and the auto industry over one of his most significant rollbacks of climate regulations.

Title: In California, a Final Exam for Heavy-Duty Hybrids
Abstrace: Hybrid bulldozer and terrain excavators will be monitored next year by academics and the California Air Resources Board to see if they offer significantly lowered carbon emissions.

Title: On Our Radar: ‘Small’ Nuclear War Would Cool Globe, Scientists Say
Abstrace: Explosions from bombs would throw approximately five million tons of black carbon into the upper atmosphere, blocking sunlight and causing a plunge in temperature, researchers say.

Title: Psst… Groundwater and Surface Water Do Mix
Abstrace: Although California policy treats them as separate entities, a growing number of studies on their interrelationships lends momentum to calls for regulatory changes.

Title: The State’s Green Ways Are Under Attack
Abstrace: California has been the leader in environmental legislation, but an effort is under way to roll back one of the most ambitious laws.

Title: A Climate Reckoning in Fire-Stricken California
Abstrace: If climate change was a somewhat abstract notion a decade ago, today it is all too real for Californians fleeing wildfires and smothered in a blanket of smoke, the worst year of fires on record.

Title: California Widens Clean-Fuel Zone for Ships
Abstrace: After commercial ships take long detours to avoid switching to cleaner fuel, creating logistical problems in a Navy testing zone, regulators expand the clean-fuel zone farther offshore.

Title: California Feuding
Abstrace: No state has done as much as California to sponsor, legitimize and reward environmental virtue.

Title: Standing, Stretching, Turning Around
Abstrace: We urge California voters to pass Proposition 2, which would ban the cruel confinement of animals.

Title: Effects of Wildfire Smoke Vary, Experts Say
Abstrace: Environmental health experts say inhalation of tiny smoke particles from California wildfires is unlikely to cause long-term damage to healthy people unless it occurs over prolonged period; warn young children, elderly and people with chronic pulmonary or cardiovascular conditions could be at risk and should stay indoors in air conditioning; San Diego County hospitals report significant rise in number of people with respiratory complaints; most have been treated and released; photo (M)

Title: Water Transfer to San Diego Is Upheld
Abstrace: An appeals court refuses to invalidate the agreement underpinning the transfer of water between the Imperial Valley and urban areas of Southern California.

Title: Detroit Fights California Bid to Open Car Pool Lanes to Fuel-Conscious Import

Title: Did California Overreach in Promising to Help the Salton Sea?

Title: California to Ban the Sale of New Gasoline Cars

Title: Energy Bill Would Welcome Back Diesels
Abstrace: Energy bill in Senate would extend extend tax credits to new automobiles with advanced diesel engines; credits would be equal to those provided for gas-electric and alternative fuel vehicles; critics oppose measure on grounds that new diesels are still too dirty, with Dan Becker of Sierra Club noting that many vehicles to receive diesel credits would not meet minimum air standards in California; current diesel engines emit more pollutants than gasoline-fueled counterparts, but offer 30 to 40 percent improvement in fuel efficiency and 15 percent reduction in oil consumption; chart; photos (M)

Title: The Warming Is Global but the Legislating, in the U.S., Is All Local
Abstrace: States across US have become driving force on fighting global warming, motivated by environmental and economic concerns as federal programs stall under Bush administration; most contentious of many new measures is California law setting strict new limits for auto emissions of carbon dioxide; actions elsewhere noted; photo of new solar panels atop San Francisco convention center; map (M)

Title: Trump Says His Regulatory Rollback Already Is the ‘Most Far-Reaching’
Abstrace: President Trump, showcasing his accomplishments near the end of his first year, said that for every new regulation, his administration has killed 22.

Title: California Softens Plan to Control Auto Emissions
Abstrace: California gives some ground to auto industry in its ambitious plan to regulate global warming emissions from tailpipes, but state is unlikely to avert legal challenge from carmarkers; under revised plan, which would start to take effect in 2009 model year, industry will have eight years instead of six to reduce global warming emissions by about 30 percent; changes to plan are disclosed in final draft of staff report released by California Air Resources Board; photo (M)o

Title: Canada Sets Goal to Cut Car Emissions

Title: To Pump or Not to Pump

Title: States Plan Suit to Prod U.S. on Global Warming

Title: California Regulators Modify Auto Emissions Mandate
Abstrace: California Air Resources Board, responding to legal pressure from auto makers and Bush administration, alters influential Zero Emission Vehicle mandate to require fewer vehicles to be sold in state with no tailpipe emissions and more with modest emissions, category that includes hybrids; new version to take effect for 2005 model year offers auto makers two compliance options; Jason Mark of Union of Concerned Scientists says question now is whether companies like General Motors and DaimlerChrysler will respond with lawyers or engineers (M)

Title: Timber Company Accused of Fraud in Deal to Save Redwoods

Title: Economic Scene; Gasoline prices are easing -- but not in California. Should the state step in?
Abstrace: Hal R Varian Economic Scene column on report from three analysts at University of California Energy Institute on steps California state government could take to reduce gasoline prices, which have not eased in recent weeks as they have elsewhere in country and are highest in country; they note that California's problem arises partly because it uses special low-pollution blend of gasoline called CaRFG; suggest that state could allow importation of non-CaRFG gasoline when CaRFG is in short supply, as long as importer pays tax equal to difference in cost between two kinds of gasoline; photo (M)

Title: More California Air Space Set for No-Smoke Zones

Title: Ford Heir Says Nation's Affair With the Car Has Lost Its Zip

Title: New Allies in the Energy Wars
