Abstrace: Environmental Protection Agency says about third of Americans live in counties that do not meet seven-year-old standards for microscopic particles of pollution that cause thousands of premature deaths every year; 20 states affected, including New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, have three years to develop plans to bring their problem counties into compliance by 2010, or face loss of federal highway money; map (M)

Title: SUPERFUND MONEY
Abstrace: Environmental Protection Agency earmarks $61.2 million to help New Jersey clean 10 of 115 Superfund sites (S)

Title: Christie, Defending Exxon Deal, Says Environmental Damage Will Be Repaired
Abstrace: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey praised a deal to conclude a multibillion-dollar pollution suit against the oil company. Critics say the deal is being made to fill holes in the state budget.

Title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Mercury Emission Controls
Abstrace: New Jersey proposes new controls intended to cut mercury emissions from power plants and other sources by 75 percent in three years (S)

Title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Auto Emission Tests Delayed
Abstrace: New Jersey Department of Environmental Protecton announces delay of new computerized auto emissions test until August because of system software problems (S)

Title: A Box Fell From the Sky. It Had a Note About Trump. The Police Were Not Amused.
Abstrace: The package landed on a New Jersey field with a note assuring that the device was not a bomb and wishing the president a “great round of golf.”

Title: Governor Outlines Restrictions To Protect Reservoirs' Purity
Abstrace: New Jersey Gov James E McGreevey outlines plan to protect water quality in nine major reservoirs that serve about 3.5 million people, or about half of state's population (S)

Title: Study Investigates Proliferation of Plastic in Waterways Around New York
Abstrace: At any given time, an estimated 165 million plastic particles are floating in the estuaries that stretch from the Tappan Zee Bridge to Sandy Hook Bay, in New Jersey, a study finds.

Title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Fouled Beaches Reopen
Abstrace: Four miles of New Jersey beaches in Lavalette and Dover Township are reopened after investigation finds waste on beach is not dangerous (S)

Title: SMOG INCREASES
Abstrace: New Jersey Public Interest Research Group reports that smog levels in state increased dramatically in 2001 and continue to worsen (S)

Title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Avon-By-The-Sea: Water Standards Criticized
Abstrace: Three-year study of wastewater off Jersey Shore by Clean Ocean Action finds few or no government standards for toxins and careless record-keeping by state (S)

Title: Gov. Christie’s Bad Deal With Exxon
Abstrace: Anyone who wants cleaner air and water in New Jersey should urge the governor to reject the $225 million settlement that was negotiated in secret.

Title: POLLUTERS PAY MORE
Abstrace: New Jersey Environmental Protection Comr Bradley Campbell says state is expanding scope of its efforts against polluters by seeking funds to compensate for loss of use of natural resources, including drinking water sources and wetlands (S)

Title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Beach Waste Was Accidental
Abstrace: Investigators report that syringes, crack vials and raw human sewage washing up on New Jersey's beaches this summer do not appear intentional, but rather overflow from sewers, storm drains, shorelines and sewage treatment plants (S)

Title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Legal Action Over Dioxin
Abstrace: Coalition of environmental groups will sue four chemical companies for dumping dioxins into Passaic River in New Jersey for 20 years; says dioxin eventually wound up in Newark Bay, where fishermen and crabbers, either unknowingly or defiantly, harvested tainted seafood (S)

Title: CRACKDOWN ON ILLEGAL DOCKS
Abstrace: New Jersey Environmental Protection Department cracks down on owners of 93 illegal docks that may pollute state-owned tidelands with oil and gas leaking from boats (S)

Title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Fuel-Cell Legislation
Abstrace: New Jersey Senator Peter A Inverso will introduce legislation that will offer business tax credit for purchase of fuel-cell powered cars, which only emit water vapor, and fuel research commission; photo (S)

Title: DIRTY WATER
Abstrace: Clamming is suspended indefinitely, shellfish beds are closed and health of Raritan Bay and nearby waters is threatened after ruptured sewage pipe serving most of central New Jersey diverts 2.5 million gallons of raw sewage an hour into upper New York Harbor; rupture does not affect quality of drinking water (S)

Title: NET LIMITS ON FISH
Abstrace: New Jersey Environmental Protection and Health and Senior Services Departments issue more restrictive advisories on amounts of 13 species of fish and crabs collected in state waters that are considered safe to eat based on their polychlorinated biphenyl levels (S)

Title: Health Hazards Close Beaches
Abstrace: Broken sewer pipe in Westchester County, NY, closes five beaches; four miles of Jersey Shore are closed after medical wastes wash up (S)

Title: NEW SUPERFUND SITES
Abstrace: Environmental Protection Agency adds former Atlantic Resources Corp industrial site in Sayreville, Quanta Resources Inc oil and coal tar storage site in Edgewater and Diamond Head oil refinery in Kearney to Superfund federal hazardous water clean-up program (S)

Title: EMISSIONS CONTRACT HEARINGS
Abstrace: Accountants and other analysts, testifying before New Jersey investigative commission, say state officials grossly underestimated costs and violated contract procurement rules in awarding 1998 auto-inspection contract to Parsons Infrastructure and Technology Group of California (S)

Title: SEWAGE CLOSES BAYS
Abstrace: Power blackout causes millions of gallons of sewage to bypass treatment plants in New York City and New Jersey and flow directly into Hudson River, closing Raritan and Sandy Hook bays to clamming (S)

Title: HOPE FOR CLAMS
Abstrace: Officials in Middlesex County, NJ, seeking to salvage clams contaminated in huge sewage leak, offer harvesters access to water from Barnegat Bay to clean their catches; say clam beds will remain closed until tested for heavy metals and other pollutants (S)

Title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Ex-Official Convicted In Fuel Deception
Abstrace: Thomas M Hayes of Saybolt Inc is convicted by federal jury in New Jersey of aiding the bogus testing of gasoline, which allowed millions of gallons of substandard gasoline to be sold in violation of Clean Air Act (S)

Title: INSPECTION SYSTEM
Abstrace: Parsons Infrastructure and Technology Group, which runs New Jersey's enhanced auto inspection system, reaches deal that provides additional $5.5 million for construction work and lowers daily fines for test delays (S)

Title: Trenton: Enforcement on Cleanup Sites
Abstrace: State environmental officials said yesterday that they would begin enforcement actions against 950 groups and individuals who have failed to comply with regulations for monitoring certain environmental cleanup sites, including groundwater contamination and protective caps. Environmental officials said state law requires that those responsible for monitoring the condition of such sites file reports with the state certifying that protective measures are still in effect. The officials said the state would begin issuing notices of violation next week to those who have not complied. The sites include residential developments, gas stations, industrial sites and public institutions, the officials said.

Title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Emissions Test Delayed
Abstrace: New Jersey will postpone until January 2004 requirement that owners of about 640,000 automobiles, model years 1996 and 1997, take new emissions test that reads emission data from computer in automobile rather than measuring tailpipe emissions; needs more time to education motorists about test (S)

Title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Bloomfield: Redevelopment Grants Set
Abstrace: Jane M Kenny of Environmental Protection Agency announces more than $3 million in federal grants to help decontaminate and redevelop old industrial sites in New York and New Jersey; agency is providing $75 million in federal funds to communities across country for revitalizing thousands of polluted industrial properties, called brownfields, that present comparitively low health risks (S)

Title: 2 States Break Rules on Smog, E.P.A. Finds
Abstrace: Environmental Protection Agency proposes designating all of New Jersey and Connecticut as being out of compliance with tougher anti-smog standards; also classifies Putnam, Orange and Dutchess counties in New York in same category with New York City, designation that could mean tougher standards there for industry, gas pumps and cars; state wanted counties placed in separate category; changes are intended to satisfy lawsuit brought by American Lung Association and environmental groups (M)

Title: McGreevey Assailed on Bill Easing Developers' Permits
Abstrace: Environmentalist score Gov James E McGreevey for supporting bill that would expedite environmental permit process in areas designated suitable for development; say that bill would despoil coast, increase urban pollution, hasten Wal-Mart proliferation, and cripple regulations protecting workers from hazards; bill is part of McGreevey's plan to revitalize cities and older suburbs; plan gives state officials 45 days to review applications and establishes 'smart growth ombudsman' (M)

Title: Global Warming Report in New Jersey
Abstrace: New Jersey Public Interest Research Group urges Gov Jon S Corzine to reduce global warming pollution 20 percent below current levels by 2020 and 70 percent by 2050; report by Princeton University scientists suggests that 1 to 3 percent of state would be submerged and 6 to 9 percent subject to chronic flooding by 2100 if warming continues at current pace (S)

Title: Plea Agreement Is Reached in Pipe Case
Abstrace: Federal prosecutors, who have announced second indictment of McWane Inc, say Donald Harbin, longtime manager in Birmingham, will cooperate with probe of environmental and safety violations by one of nation's largest manufacturers of cast iron pipes; ten McWane managers have been charged with crimes in Alabama and New Jersey (S)

Title: Miles From Home, but Now With Comfort and Cleaner Air
Abstrace: BORDENTOWN.

Title: Metro Briefing | New York: Garden City: Nassau Fines Gas Stations
Abstrace: Nassau County, NY, Office of Consumer Affairs investigators find four gas stations that illegally obtained cheaper gasoline from New Jersey to evade New York State excise taxes; gas contains additive MTBE, which is banned in New York; two stations have been shut down and two are given violation notices (S)

Title: New Jersey Dump Is Put Back on Superfund List
Abstrace: EPA will return Ringwood Mines area of northern New Jersey to Superfund list of heavily polluted sites; site was used by Ford Motor Co as dumping ground in 1970's and has been cleaned up before, but residents complain of lingering pollution and health problems (S)

Title: SILT GOING TO PENNSYLVANIA
Abstrace: Joint project by scrap metal dealer Hugo Neu Schnitzer East and New Jersey Office of Maritime Resources will dredge and clean contaminated silt from Claremont Channel off Jersey City, NJ, and use it to cap abandoned strip mine in Penfield, Pa, where it will keep mine acid from entering nearby waterways (S)

Title: New Jersey Proposes Measures to Reduce Mercury Emissions
Abstrace: New Jersey will propose new controls to limit emissions of mercury, a toxic substance that is particularly harmful to fetuses and young children.

Title: High Goals for Reducing Emissions in New Jersey
Abstrace: The New Jersey Legislature passed a bill Thursday that set ambitious goals for reducing emissions of greenhouse gases.

Title: New Criticism After New Jersey Posts Text of Exxon Settlement
Abstrace: Environmental groups and some state lawmakers call the proposed $225 million deal a “corporate giveaway” that “leaves us with more questions than answers.”

Title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Fresh Kills Environmental Study
Abstrace: New York State's Appeals Court rules New York City does not have to conduct further study on health effects of soot from diesel powered trucks transporting waste from Manhattan to New Jersey; Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer argued that city did not properly study environmental impact in preparation for closing of Fresh Kills landfill (S)

Title: Officials at Foundry Face Health and Safety Charges
Abstrace: Sweeping federal indictment unsealed in Newark charges that senior managers of New Jersey foundry owned by McWane Inc, nation's largest manufacturer of cast-iron pipe, conspired for years to violate workplace safety and environmental laws and then obstructed repeated government inquiries by lying, intimidating workers into silence and systematically altering accident scenes; indictment says motive was to enrich foundry, Atlantic States Cast Iron Pipe in Philippsburg, NJ, and its managers by maximizing production 'without concern to environmental pollution and worker safety risks'; indictment charges that foundry's managers routinely dumped thousands of gallons of contaminated wastewater into Delaware River, repeatedly exposed workers to unsafe conditions and regularly deceived environmental and workplace safety regulators; photos (L)

Title: Sharp Odor Along Jersey Shore Is a Mystery
Abstrace: Sharp chemical odor promopts calls to emergency officials along New Jersey shore (S)

Title: Toxic Passaic River to Get $1.38 Billion Cleanup Over 10 Years
Abstrace: The project announced by the Environmental Protection Agency will be among the most ambitious yet in the 35-year history of the Superfund program.

Title: Car Emissions Standards Are Stricter in New Jersey
Abstrace: New Jersey Legislature passes bill to bring state's emissions requirements in line with those of strictest states in nation; bill mandates that certain percentage of vehicle sales in state consist of low-emission models by 2009 and smaller number to be pollution free by 2012; also lowers emissions limits for each manufacturer's total fleet; final approval is also given to measure forbidding use of hand-held cellular phones while driving; photo (M)

Title: E.P.A. Sued Over Mercury in the Air
Abstrace: New Jersey and eight other states file lawsuit challenging Environmental Protection Agency rule that they claim does not do enough to control dangerous mercury emissions from coal-fired power plants (M)

Title: Robert Roe, New Jersey Congressman Called ‘Mr. Jobs,’ Dies at 90
Abstrace: Mr. Roe was an advocate for public works who helped finance the expansion of the nation’s highway system and efforts to combat water pollution.

Title: State Moves to Close Composting Plant
Abstrace: SPRINGFIELD TOWNSHIP, N.J.

Title: McGreevey's Optimism on Budget Plan Meets Criticism of Its Sources of Financing
Abstrace: Gov James E McGreevey's budget for New Jersey's fiscal 2005 is criticized for relying too heavily on $150 million in new fees and taxes and borrowing against money expected to come from cigarette tax and higher fines for driving infractions; McGreevey says that $150 million environmental impact fee on petrochemical companies is not stealth tax on gasoline, but on polluters; photo (M)

Title: Companies to Pay New Jersey $17 Million for Toxic Cleanup
Abstrace: Honeywell International, Tierra Solutions and PPG Industries will pay New Jersey $17 million for polluting northern New Jersey sites with chromium, ending 20 years of legal negotiations (M)

Title: The Comforts of Home, And Cleaner Air, Too
Abstrace: Article on innovation that is coming to Paulsboro Travel Center in New Jersey, where long-haul truck drivers idle their trucks all night while they sleep to save money and guard cargo; IdleAire, independent heating and cooling system, will be installed at 175 parking spaces; each parking space will feature giant yellow hose which, when hooked up to truck through window adapter, will supply heat, air conditioning, phone jack, cable and Internet access, all controlled by computerized console; photo (M)

Title: Critics Try to Turn Whitman Against Her Emissions Plan
Abstrace: New Jersey environmentalists, joined by group of anonymous employees of Environmental Protection Agency, call on agency's new administrator Christie Whitman to reject emissions-credit trading program that she herself had introduced as governor; warn that program is rife with pitfalls and could allow air polluters to claim credit for phantom reductions in toxic emissions without fear of detection by regulators; photo (M)

Title: Superfund Cleanup Stirs Troubled Waters
Abstrace: The Environmental Protection Agency is finally tackling some of the most heavily polluted waterways, many of which are in the New York-New Jersey area.

Title: Toms River Still Asking A Question: 'Why Us?'
Abstrace: Following six-year, $10 million study, epidemiological report released recently shows there may be connection between chemical pollution from Superfund site and instances of leukemia in infant girls, but offers no explanation for array of childhood cancers plaguing Toms River, NJ; Gov-elect James McGreevey strongly attacks State Dept of Health and Senior Services for taking so long to acknowledge problem existed and begin scientific study; parents feel at least partially vindicated but say common sense dictates that more of their children's cancers are produced by chemical pollution; photos (M)

Title: Judge Hears Arguments on an Exxon Settlement
Abstrace: On Thursday, lawyers for New Jersey and environmental groups argued their case about an environmental contamination settlement between the state and Exxon.

Title: Crews Restoring Newark Fields Tainted by Pool of Gasoline
Abstrace: Cleanup is under way in Branch Brook Park in Newark, NJ, where workers last October found large pool of gasoline three or four feet below surface; is expected to last until summer; people living near park may smell gasoline during cleanup; Environmental Protection Department Comr Bradley Campbell voices concern about contamination of brook that runs through park (M)

Title: Under Law, Christie Can Use Exxon Settlement to Help Balance Budget
Abstrace: The current New Jersey appropriations law says that any funds beyond the first $50 million collected in damages or other environmental recoveries shall go to the state’s general fund.

Title: New York City and 8 States Plan to Sue Power Plants
Abstrace: Eight states and New York City will file federal lawsuit demanding 'substantial cuts' in carbon dioxide emissions by five major utility companies that operate 174 power plants (M)

Title: Last Oil Being Cleared From New Jersey Beaches
Abstrace: Crews are cleaning up last remains of oil slick that polluted beaches on Jersey Shore (S)

Title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
Abstrace: PATERSON: Jury Continues Meeting On Dupont; ELIZABETH: 2 Charged In 3 Killings; TRENTON: Group Backs Insurance Changes; Landmarks Agency To Meet.

Title: MORE 65-M.P.H. ZONES
Abstrace: New Jersey Transportation Department recommends speed limit be raised to 65 miles per hour on 124 additional miles of highways (S)

Title: New York, New Jersey, Connecticut
Abstrace: NEW YORK.

Title: Stepping Up on Climate Change
Abstrace: New Jersey’s legislature, backed by Gov. Jon Corzine, set perhaps the most aggressive limits of any state on greenhouse-gas emissions.

Title: Finding the Bottom of a Polluted Field
Abstrace: Honeywell Corp seeks to cap hazardous waste site in Jersey City, one of nation's biggest; claims that it has found solution to heaving problem caused when ground water mixes with pollutants, mostly chromium, and hardens it; Honeywell proposes to remove hardened layer and fill it in with clean dirt; local groups and environmentalists say chromium will still leach into Hackensack River; Honeywell did not pollute land, but Allied Signal, its corporate predecessor, bought stock of Mutual Chemical Co, which did, leaving it responsible; photo (L)

Title: Simpler Auto Emissions Test to Be Phased In for Newer Cars, State Says
Abstrace: New Jersey officials announce that rigorous auto emissions test that created turmoil at state inspection stations when it was introduced two years ago is to be phased out and replaced by quicker, simpler computerized system starting next Jan; under new plan, newer cars will not have to undergo time-consuming tests; specifics of plan require approval of federal Environmental Protection Agency; McGreevey administration discloses that it has started close analysis of seven-year contract that Whitman administration awarded Parsons Infrastructure and Technology Group, California company, in 1998 to install and operate inspection system; during his campaign, McGreevey called contract 'cronyism at its worst,' noting that Parsons was sole bidder (M)

Title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: New Water Rules Proposed
Abstrace: New Jersey Dept of Environmental Protection proposes new regulations to increase state's water supply through new restrictions on residential and other development (S)

Title: State Postpones Inspections for Newer Cars
Abstrace: New Jersey is allowing owners of newer cars to wait four years before inspections, part of effort tocut $13 million a year from budget (S)

Title: Shortchanging New Jersey by Billions
Abstrace: Governor Christie settled a huge pollution case for pennies on the dollar.

Title: New Jersey’s $225 Million Settlement With Exxon Mobil Is Approved
Abstrace: The ruling by a state judge Tuesday comes in a longstanding legal battle in which the state had demanded $8.9 billion in compensation for natural resource damage.

Title: With Eye on 2016, Christie Resists Climate Change Plan
Abstrace: Gov. Chris Christie is adamant that New Jersey not participate in the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative, though most legislators say it would be good for the state.

Title: Rescuing Lady Bird’s Legacy
Abstrace: With all of the traffic congestion, pollution and detours they face, New Jersey’s drivers could do with the calming effect that greenery would provide.

Title: The Week in New Jersey
Abstrace: Dynamometers, the auto-emission testing systems that raised the ire of politicians and the blood pressure of drivers after they were introduced to state-run inspection stations seven years ago, are being dismantled and removed.

Title: DAMAGE CONTINUES
Abstrace: Natural Resources Defense Council releases report concluding that New Jersey environmental officials and Army Corps of Engineers have issued wetlands and coastal development permits too freely; report praises state officials for programs to save open space (S)

Title: A BUSY FAREWELL
Abstrace: New Jersey Legislature, before closing session, approves stricter auto emissions rules, passes bills that lower legal limit for driving while intoxicated to 0.08 percent and that require jail time for repeat drunken drivers, tightens code of ethics for legislators, and passes bill banning drivers from using handheld cellphones (M)

Title: Chunk of New Jersey’s Money From Exxon Settlement Is to Go to Legal Fees
Abstrace: If the broadly criticized deal is approved, New Jersey’s recovery will most likely total about $180 million or so, after legal fees and costs are deducted, records show.

Title: A Cleanup Plan for a Toxic River
Abstrace: It is past time to rehabilitate the Passaic River in New Jersey, one of America’s oldest industrial dumping grounds.

Title: Gov. Christie Goes Easy on a Big Polluter
Abstrace: A $250 million deal with Exxon to recover $8.9 billion in damages for environmental contamination is a colossal mistake.

Title: The Battle Over Teterboro: From Romance to Hostility
Abstrace: Article on staunch opposition by local residents and others to proposal by Federal Aviation Agency to allow jets weighing more than 100,000 pounds to land at Teterboro Airport in suburban New Jersey as well as about 3,000 other airports nationwide, including about 16 others in New Jersey; Congress has passed measure that may block proposal and Port Authority of New York and New Jersey chairman Anthony Coscia says his agency will not modify airport to allow heavier planes to land; photos; map (L)

Title: A Flash of Hope for a Tainted River
Abstrace: Cleanup of the Passaic River, long neglected and polluted, is scheduled to begin this summer.

Title: Is the Water Actually Fine?
Abstrace: Water quality on the nation's swimming beaches is facing contamination from storm water and even sewage.

Title: McGreevey Threatens to End Deal With Car Emissions Tester
Abstrace: New Jersey Gov James McGreevey threatens to break $400 million contract with Parsons Infrastructure and Technology Group, which runs state's troubled auto emissions inspection program, unless contractor agrees to substantial cut in fees; says new audit shows company failed to deliver on its contract by missing deadlines, performing tests inaccurately and keeping thousands of drivers waiting; photo (M)

Title: The Cost of Green Grass
Abstrace: An early growing season and a timing glitch affecting a certification process are creating temporary difficulties for landscapers.

Title: Trying to Make Some Sense of That Syrupy Scent. Why? It's Thursday.
Abstrace: New Jersey has been accused of many things, and almost none have had to do with smelling sweet.     But when a strange, syrupy scent descended on parts of New York City and New Jersey twice (and possibly three times) in the fall, theories spread faster than warm Aunt Jemima on pancakes. Speculation fell on the Garden State, a historic center in the production of fragrance, flavor and hoary olfaction jokes.

Title: Hitting Ground Zero Running
Abstrace: Profile of Jane M Kenny, new Environmental Protection Agency regional administrator, whose first task on job was to oversee clean-up effort at World Trade Center; she runs decontamination wash stations and monitors air and water samples taken in New York and North Jersey as debris is cleared away; she comments on her other duties; photo (M)

Title: Congestion Pricing Delays Threaten Subway Projects, M.T.A. Chair Says
Abstrace: A plan to toll drivers in Manhattan is expected to fund major improvements to New York City’s transit network. Officials fear delays threaten those plans.

Title: New Jersey Embraces an Idea It Once Rejected: Make Utilities Pay to Emit Carbon
Abstrace: Democratic governors nationwide are taking steps to tax or price emissions within their own borders, even as Trump dismantles federal climate policy.

Title: Landfill Cleanup Was Delayed, State Admits
Abstrace: New Jersey acknowledges that it failed to manage adequately cleanup of solid waste landfill in Edison, lapse environmentalists say may have allowed tons of heavy metals, benzenes and other carcinogens to seep into groundwater and possibly Raritan River; complaints have been raised by Edison Wetlands Association, a local environmental group, and Isaac Heller, owner of industrial park next to 145-acre ILR Landfill; Heller photo (M)

Title: 9 States in Plan to Cut Emissions by Power Plants
Abstrace: Nine Northeastern states reportedly reach preliminary agreement to freeze power plant emissions at current levels and then reduce them by ten percent by 2020; photo; first such cooperative action follows Bush administration not to regulate greenhouse gases and would require legislation in each state; initiative would set up market-driven system to control carbon dioxide emissions from more than 600 electric generators, and could spur action nationally; California, Washington and Oregon explore similar agreement; Northeast states were brought together by New York Gov George Pataki, who broke sharply with administration on issue; spokesman declines comment on leaked draft; environmentalists say region's carbon dioxide emissions are about those of Germany, but that real significance of accord is example for other states (M)

Title: So, How's the Weather? Futuristic; From Smog to Sun, Climate Scientists Zoom In on Changes
Abstrace: New York Climate and Health Project seeks to predict effects of global warming in region by 2050; divides 31 counties around city into hundreds of grid boxes and measures multitude of data from each; will identify 'heat islands' that can trap heat, making areas hotter; is experimenting with ways to make neighborhoods cooler through belts of trees and green roofs of grass on top of buildings; seeks to assess effect of hotter climate on rich and poor; will try to determine if local action can provide some relief from global warming or if large-scale government action is needed; photo (L)

Title: New York and New Jersey
Abstrace: NEW YORK.

Title: Christie Administration Officials Praise Deal With Exxon
Abstrace: The New Jersey governor’s office, heavily criticized for accepting a settlement for environmental damages that was called too low, released details of the deal for the first time Thursday.

Title: McGreevey Seeks Purity Standards for 2 Bergen Reservoirs
Abstrace: Gov James E McGreevey expands his campaign to clean up New Jersey's drinking water supplies by proposing that state's highest purity standards for untreated water be applied to two Bergen County reservoirs; McGreevey proposes Category 1 status for Lake Tappan, Woodcliff Lake and about 30 streams that flow into two reservoirs; photo (M)

Title: Report Cites Large Release of Sewage From Hurricane Sandy
Abstrace: Over 10 billion gallons were sent into waterways, with 94 percent flowing into rivers, canals and bays in New York and New Jersey, Climate Central said in a report.

Title: Rupture Sends Millions of Gallons of Sewage into Harbor
Abstrace: Ruptured sewage pipe serving most of central New Jersey is diverting 2.5 million gallons of raw sewage into upper New York Harbor each hour, closing shellfish beds and threatening health of Raritan Bay and nearby waters into summer; officials of Middlesex County Utilities Authority, which operates sewage system, say they do not know how long repairing break will take or how long sewage will flow into bay; photos; map (L)

Title: Policy at Its Worst
Abstrace: The veto of a railroad tunnel by Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey is a bigger loss than it might seem.

Title: Plane Crash in New Jersey Kills 2
Abstrace: A small airplane crashed in a wooded area near an airport in Ocean County, N.J., on Saturday, killing two passengers and critically injuring the plane’s other two occupants.

Title: Christie Administration Deal With Exxon Was Years in the Making
Abstrace: The seeds for New Jersey state officials’ controversial decision to settle a long-running environmental pollution case for $225 million were planted as early as summer 2012.

Title: Now You See Him, Now You Don't
Abstrace: New Jersey Governor James McGreevey makes brief public appearance in Atlantic City after signing bills to spur tourism and casino development (S)

Title: Enthusiasm for Ethanol Is Not Shared by All
Abstrace: New Jesey Assembly's Agriculture and Natural Resources Committee approves bill sponsored by Assemblymen John Burzichelli and Douglas Fisher that would create new facility in Gloucester County to produce ethanol (S)

Title: Crews Pick Up Oil and Injured Birds Along Miles of Beach
Abstrace: New Jersey beaches at Ocean Grove, Bradley Beach, Avon-by-the-Sea and Belmar are cleaned of oil globules that have washed up from unknown source; about 50 birds have died, and 35 more have been cleaned; environmental groups criticize authorities for getting slow start on spill, which may spread over larger area; photo; map (M)

Title: In About-Face, McGreevey Extends Car-Test Contract
Abstrace: Gov James McGreevey, who has long criticized New Jersey's privatized auto emissions inspection system, agrees to extend contract with same company, Parsons Infrastructure, in exchange for $85 million in cost reductions (S)

Title: DiFrancesco Seeks Options On Emissions Test Contract
Abstrace: New Jersey Acting Governor Donald T DiFrancesco seeks options on emissions-testing for automobiles that could include cancellation of 1998 contract with Parsons Infrastructure and Technology Group; comes after State Commission of Investigation proposes new laws to toughen state's contract-bidding and lobbying rules because of awarding contract to sole bidder (M)

Title: McGreevey Attacks Rival's Outsider Status
Abstrace: James E McGreevey accuses Bret D Schunder, Republican rival in New Jersey governor's race, of condoning insider dealing and shoddy management in state's auto emission testing program; notes that two leading Schundler supporters, C Richard Kamin and Frank Holman, are figures in controversy; charge is attempt to dent outsider status that Schundler has been cultivating (M)

Title: State Rushed Emissions Test System Into Use, Witnesses Say
Abstrace: Witnesses tell State Commission of Investigation hearing that New Jersey officials pushed through ill-conceived plan to let Parsons Infrastructure and Technical Group run its auto emissions testing program and then failed to provide enough time and supervision for inexperienced contractor to do job; note they acted hurriedly to head off federal threats to cut off highway funds because of NJ's poor air quality; session barely touches on possibility of political influence in awarding of contract (M)

Title: New York and New Jersey
Abstrace: NEW YORK.

Title: Public's Chance to Inspect Emissions-Test Contracting
Abstrace: Article contends that in year and a half since its disastrous debut left drivers fuming in long lines, New Jersey's problem-plagued emissions-testing system has spawned an equally long trail of investigations, reports and recriminations; State Commission of Investigation to begin holding public hearings this week that will focus on way politically conected firm Parsons Infrastructure and Technology Group, won half-billion-doillar contract (M)

Title: Market Place; Ohio Utility Cited in Blackout Has Had a Troubled Summer
Abstrace: Massive blackout is latest of FirstEnergy Corp's problems this summer, Market Place column; company acknowledges that alarm system had not been working at time of blackout, but it tries to deflect blame for widespread power failure, saying there were problems in other parts of nation's electrical system before its lines began to fail; North American Electric Reliability Council, group created by utilities to set standards for reducing risks of disruption, was first to call public attention to FirstEnergy's problems, but it agrees with company that problem is more complicated than just one utility; Richard H Marsh, FirstEnergy's chief financial officer, cites company's other problems this summer: blackouts in coastal New Jersey communities over July 4 weekend, federal judge's ruling that company violated Clean Air Act, delays in getting nuclear power plant in Ohio back in operation and decision by its auditors to require it to restate profits over last three years; photos; graph (M)

Title: City Trash Follows Long and Winding Road
Abstrace: Article traces path of New York City garbage now that Fresh Kills is closed and trash must be trucked to destinations as distant as Virginia and Pennsylvania through transfer stations in New Jersey; tolls, truck repair and fuel costs make it expensive proposition to dispose of 12,000 tons of city garbage each day; photo; diagram (M)

Title: In Fighting Coal Plant, a Dilemma
Abstrace: In Linden, N.J., environmentalists must decide whether to support unproven technology that combats climate change or fight every coal project that comes down the turnpike.

Title: Saving the Jersey Shore
Abstrace: Op-Ed article by US Repr Frank Pallone maintains rising sea levels caused by global warming are threatening New Jersey's coast; holds US should follow New Jersey's example and adopt sensible energy policy, focused on conservation and efficiency, which would also help stabilize gas prices, reduce dependence on foreign oil and improve air quality (M)

Title: New Jersey Vows to Overhaul Environmental Cleanup Work
Abstrace: After several environmental sites were mishandled, New Jersey promised to fix the program responsible for monitoring more than 16,000 contaminated sites.

Title: New Jersey Is Sued Over Cap-and-Trade Reversal
Abstrace: Two environmental groups argue that the state government acted illegally when it withdrew New Jersey from a regional cap and trade program.

Title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
Abstrace: BLOOMFIELD: Inquiry Into Detainee's Death; PATERSON: Dupont Jury To Deliberate Longer; TRENTON:.

Title: Mixed Reactions in New Jersey as Water Rules Await a Fix
Abstrace: Environmentalists are split over New Jersey Gov James McGreevey's commitment to controlling sprawl in wake of decision to delay and modify tough new regulations on storm water runoff from new developments; at issue is discovery by regulators that new rules to protect 2,000 miles of state streams and rivers from polluted runoff contained loophole that would have exempted subdivision proposals if they had already been approved at local level (M)

Title: Our Towns; A Fine Kettle Of Fish, Trout or Not
Abstrace: Officials of Cedar Grove and Verona, NJ, are fighting state's attempt to award Peckman River rare distinction of being an urban trout stream, fearing it would require an even cleaner river than it is now, which they estimate could cost them a combined $28 million in sewer plant improvements; sum is more than annual operating budgets of two towns (M)

Title: Judge Says 2 Agencies Erred And Set New PCB Standard
Abstrace: Manhattan federal court Judge Jed S Rakoff rules that Army Corps of Engineers and Environmental Protection Agency, in denying United States Gypsum's application for dumping silt in ocean off Sandy Hook, NJ, improperly set tough, new federal standard for PCB levels; does not grant permit for dumping but orders agencies to reconsider application under old standard; material did not exceed initial federal standard and judge says new standard amounts to new rule but without proper notification; in response to decision, New Jersey Sens Robert Torricelli and Jon Corzine and Rep Frank Pallone Jr introduce bills in Senate and House to set new stricter standard into law; agencies are considering appeal and watchdog group Clean Ocean Action says it will file suit to block any permit granted under old standard (M)

Title: Christie Whitman's Loyalties Are Being Tested These Days
Abstrace: Raymond Hernandez On Politics column on Environmental Protection Admr Christie Whitman's about-face as she defends Bush administration's pro-industry environmental agenda; New Jersey lawmakers warn that policies could have harsh effect on state (M)

Title: Even Paper Bags Will Be Banned From N.J. Supermarkets
Abstrace: The bill, which would make the state the first to ban single-use paper bags at supermarkets, would also ban single-use plastic bags in stores and restaurants.

Title: Chlorine Leak Closes Roads in New Jersey
Abstrace: A ton of unstable granular acid used to clean swimming pools released a noxious cloud of gas on Friday morning, causing the authorities to shut down the Pulaski Skyway and briefly evacuate several businesses in the area.     The leak occurred around 8:30 a.m. in a processing area of Alden Leeds, a factory that manufactures chemicals used in swimming pools, the authorities said.

Title: New Jersey Seeks Stricter Limit on Chemical in Drinking Water
Abstrace: A panel of scientists is recommending the nation’s most stringent limits on a class of chemicals found in drinking water that pose a threat to public health.

Title: Christie’s Office Drove Exxon Settlement, Ex-Official Says
Abstrace: A former New Jersey environmental commissioner wrote in an Op-Ed article that Gov. Chris Christie’s chief counsel inserted himself into an environmental settlement to “cut the deal favorable to Exxon.”

Title: In Plan to Dump Contaminated Soil, Classic New Jersey Politics Emerge
Abstrace: The Christie administration appears poised to let a company, Soil Safe, dump millions of tons of petroleum-contaminated soils on a site which lies directly west of Staten Island and the Arthur Kill.

Title: TV Stations Prefer Bayonne For New Tower
Abstrace: Coalition of 11 New York television stations submits proposal to build new tower in Bayonne, NJ, to New Jersey Environmental Comr Bradley M Campbell; proposal details preference for Bayonne site over one in Jersey City (M)

Title: Of Oft-Ribbed New Jersey, Poll Finds a Neutral Opinion
Abstrace: Fairleigh Dickinson University's Public-Mind survey results dispel notion of negative opinions about New Jersey; photo (M)

Title: The Week in New Jersey
Abstrace: Branch Brook Park in Newark has a great many cherry trees, and in the spring, the 360-acre grounds erupt in a flurry of pink and white.

Title: A Monument to New Jersey? Imaginations Are Born to Run
Abstrace: Peter Applebome column on exhibition set to open in Jersey City consisting of drawings, site plans and mock-ups of state monument for New Jersey; idea for exhibition, co-sponsored by Jersey City Museum and Victory Hall, is more to imaging monuments than to build them; most common theme is environment; photo (M)

Title: New Jersey Vows to Overhaul Environmental Cleanup Work
Abstrace: Lisa P Jackson, New Jersey commissioner of environmental protection, tells State Senate Environmental Committee of plans to overhaul department's $60 million cleanup program, which is responsible for monitoring more than 16,000 contaminated sites; Jackson tells senators that highly criticized use of unlicensed consultants to determine methods of clean-up for each site is to be addressed; appearance comes as committee considers measures to handle mercury contamination discovered in April at Kiddie Kollege, day-care center in Franklin Township; photo (M)

Title: Who Wouldn't Want a Life-Saving Service? Read On
Abstrace: SOMETHING ominous has wormed its way into the green acres of horse farms and sprawling old-money estates in central New Jersey. Ads placed in local newspapers said it would mean septic systems that are close to rivers and wetlands being polluted with blood, pathogens and medical waste; noise and air pollution; reduced property values; and, perhaps most ominously, an ''unwanted, unwarranted, unlawful invasion'' of a 50-employee business ''relocated from the heart of Newark's commercial district.''     Asbestos plant? Toxic waste dump? Nuclear fuel processing plant? Well, not exactly. It's the relocation of a New Jersey Medevac helicopter from the roof of University Hospital in Newark to rural Somerset Airport, the better to reach accident victims in central and western New Jersey. Medevac operations began at Somerset in February.

Title: Delaware River Oil Spill Leaves Wildlife Imperiled
Abstrace: Coast Guard and Fish and Wildlife Service officials say hundreds of birds, turtles and fish probably died from effects of 30,000 gallons of crude oil that leaked from Athos I, which was ripped open as it tried to dock at Citgo terminal in Paulsboro, NJ; spill left oil slick 24 miles long; ducks and geese coated in crude oil are taken to John Heinz National Wildlife Refuge in Tinicum, Pa, by volunteers trying to save them; photo (M)

Title: Trying to Tame the Noise In the City Is No Easy Sell
Abstrace: Voting in New Jersey presidential primary is light because earlier primaries in other states have all but confirmed candidates from two major parties; some voters complain that voters in Iowa have exponentially more power than anybody in state because of its late primary (S)

Title: Albany Encouraging Use of Diesel Generators to Avert Blackouts
Abstrace: ALBANY, March 20 — Concerned about the potential for power shortages, the Pataki administration and the managers of the state's power grid are taking steps to encourage businesses to run their backup diesel generators at times during the summer when electricity use is at its highest. The proposals have raised concerns among environmentalists because diesel generators pollute much more than even coal-burning power plants.

Title: Corzine Prepares to Assume New Title, and the Problems That Go With It
Abstrace: Jon Corzine begins transformation from US senator to New Jersey governor with equal measures of excitement and exhaustion; greets commuters in Woodbridge; photo; will begin plans to enact stricter governmental ethics and address fiscal and property tax issues; voters approve ballot proposals to establish office of lieutenant governor and amend environmental spending; tallies; maps (M)

Title: Trenton Report Calls Auto Tests A 'Boondoggle'
Abstrace: New Jersey State Commission of Investigation issues report on auto-emissions testing system, describing it as 'mammoth boondoggle' and portraying contract as study in patronage and incompetence; holds project will cost taxpayers $590 million, $200 million more than it was supposed to; finds system achieved no improvement in air quality; says Parsons Infrastructure and Technology Group, sole bidder for contract, was granted favored treatment and was big campaign contributor to Republicans; Parsons spokeman rejects report and says costs were higher than expected because number of cars was greater than anticipated; report contends state would have saved $225 million by operating system itself (M)

Title: Witnesses Say Auto Test Company Got Inside Data
Abstrace: Witnesses testifying at New Jersey State Commission of Investigation hearing say that, in violation of rule prohibiting state officials from meeting with potential bidders, one company that bid on New Jersey's $500 million auto emissions testing system in 1998 was given advance information on program; say that senior state officials met with lobbyists and engineers from Parsons Infrastructure and Technology Group while contract specification were being drawn up and before contract was put out to bid (M)

Title: A River That Follows Two Paths
Abstrace: Delaware River is complicated resource that benefits New York, New Jersey, Delaware and Pennsylvania, and has become political football; northern stretch is pristine and scenic, while southern stretch is polluted from numerous factories and oil refineries that line its banks; map; photos (M)

Title: Of Auto Emissions And a Road Not Taken
Abstrace: Article on plan to lower auto emissions in New Jersey, which remains in committee; bill is facing strong opposition from Sen Joseph Suliga, Democratic co-chairman of Environment Committee whose district includes large General Motors plant but who insists he is not trying to stop bill; photo (M)

Title: New York and New Jersey
Abstrace: NEW YORK.

Title: Born-Again Beaches For the Urban Folk
Abstrace: Article on some beaches along rivers and bays of New Jersey cities like Perth Amboy, South Amboy, Hoboken and Harrison that are being resurrected; water quality has improved after years of industrial pollution but not enough for swimming; photos (M)

Title: Cleaning a River That Was Given Up for Dead
Abstrace: Acknowledging the extent of the contamination is just the first challenge in tackling a project as big as detoxifying a river, especially one that was as abused as the Passaic.

Title: Where Eagles Are Flying Into an Eco-Political Fray
Abstrace: Petty's Island, NJ, is caught between those who want to see it developed as resort and those who would like to turn it into nature preserve; island, owned by Citgo, is home to pair of bald eagles and preservationists warn that development could scare them off, but officials in nearby Pennsauken need added revenue that would come from development; history of island noted; photos (M)

Title: Texas to New Jersey: Tracking the Toxic Chemicals in the Ohio Train Inferno
Abstrace: Tankers of vinyl chloride were going halfway across the country, government records show, a trip highlighting the risks of transporting chemicals as plastics production grows.

Title: National Study Gives Gateway Park Low Marks
Abstrace: The waterfront park that stretches from Jamaica Bay to Sandy Hook in New Jersey is in worse condition than any other national park, according to a new survey.

Title: The Hired Gun Brought In To Clean Up
Abstrace: Article on New Jersey Environmental Commissioner Bradley Campbell; Campbell, lifelong Democrat and former Washington lawyer, has won plaudits in post for managing state's worst drought in decade and for his willingness to confront longstanding problems of sprawl, pollution and environmental enforcement; photos (L)

Title: Can a $10 Billion Highway Fix One of New Jersey’s Worst Traffic Jams?
Abstrace: And, in the face of climate change, should it? A plan to widen the highway that leads into the Holland Tunnel is fueling heated debate.

Title: Hamptons' Visitors Went Shopping, but Jersey Shore's Went Home
Abstrace: Businesses in Hamptons do well this summer despite rain, recession and blackouts, and real estate prices are rising; Jersey Shore, by contrast, suffers through these summer tribulations and is additionally burdened by new hotel taxes and medical waste on its beaches (M)

Title: With 130-Mile Coast, New Jersey Marks a First in Climate Change Fight
Abstrace: Builders will be forced to take climate change, including rising sea levels, into account to win government approval for projects.

Title: Nets Along the Passaic Are Helping to Clear It
Abstrace: PATERSON.

Title: Refloating a Notion About Subways
Abstrace: Fishermen and some New Jersey lawmakers want to refloat proposal that would sink 200 to 300 old Redbird subway cars off New Jersey coast in order to create more artificial reefs and boost state's recreational fishery; Acting Gov Donald DiFrancesco scuttled idea in 2001 following opposition by environmentalists; state sank 432 subway cars last August off Cape Henlopen; photos (M)

Title: New Jersey Fishermen Warned of Mercury Levels in Some Fish
Abstrace: New Jersey Environmental Protection Department warns of high mercury levels in 21 species of freshwater fish in state's waterways (S)

Title: ‘Hallelujah Moment’: How This City Overcame Its Lead Crisis
Abstrace: Lead pipes had tainted Newark’s drinking water. Now it is close to replacing nearly all those lines.

Title: Backers and Critics Spar Over a Rail Plan
Abstrace: WHILE some towns in central New Jersey are eagerly anticipating a New Jersey Transit plan to build a rail line intended to ease traffic congestion, others are refusing to climb on board.

Title: ‘Outrageous’ $17 Toll to Cross the Verrazano Vexes Drivers
Abstrace: Though congestion pricing failed, it has focused attention on the hefty bridge tolls outside Manhattan, where public transit options are limited.

Title: In the Region/New Jersey; When Buying a House, Beware the Buried Oil Tank
Abstrace: New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection oversees about 1,800 residential oil tank cleanups annually; larger commercial tanks must be registered and inspected annually, but residential tanks of less than 1,100 gallons are exempt from this requirement; buyers of homes should take measures to avoid liability for any leaks and cleanup costs; photo (In the Region/New Jersey) (M)

Title: New Jersey Tribe Member Dies After Police Shooting at a Back-Roads Party
Abstrace: Emil Mann, member of Ramapough Mountain Indians, dies nine days after being shot during confrontation with New Jersey State Park Police who were enforcing rules against all-terrain vehicles on parkland; confrontation occurred at popular picnic site in Mahwah; tribe members say Mann was trying to break up fight (M)

Title: Those Leafy Suburbs
Abstrace: AUTUMN would be just about perfect in New Jersey's leafy suburbs, if only the leaves would stay on the trees. But leaves, no matter how brilliant, wither and fall. Then homeowners have to figure out a way to get rid of millions of nature's expired treasures.     ''It's part of the charm of living here, the fall foliage, but it's a cross we have to bear,'' said Tim Monahan, the supervisor of public works in Millburn Township.

Title: New Jersey Halts Oyster Restoration Project
Abstrace: NY/NJ Baykeeper reluctantly complied with a state order and pulled up oysters it had seeded in the polluted Raritan Bay.

Title: A Bridge Over Troubled Water
Abstrace: Profile of and interview with Julia Somers, 46, who, as as executive director of Great Swamp Watershed Assn for last 12 years, has been working to redraw boundary of Great Swamp National Wildlife Refuge in New Jersey; nonprofit group and its staff monitor pollution in local streams, arrange conservation easements to maintain open land and conduct seminars on region's culture, history and environment; photo (M)

Title: N.Y. Congestion Pricing Plan Moves a Step Closer to Reality
Abstrace: The Federal Highway Administration said on Friday that the toll program, which would charge drivers entering Manhattan, could advance to its next steps before final approval.

Title: Challenger Says Senator Took Donations From Supporters of a Terrorist Group
Abstrace: New Jersey Senate candidate Douglas Forrester charges Democratic incumbent Robert Torricelli with taking more than $10,000 from supporters of listed Iranian terrorist group and lobbying to have it removed from government watch list; senator says People's Mujahedeen of Iran, which is allied with Saddam Hussein, is legitimate opposition group but that he has not taken money from group member (M)

Title: New Jersey Transit Board Approves Fare Increase and Service Changes
Abstrace: Fares on the network’s trains, buses and trolleys will rise about 9 percent, on average, in October.

Title: Lead Crisis in Newark Grows, as Bottled Water Distribution Is Bungled
Abstrace: Worries about the safety of the drinking water in New Jersey’s largest city have raised comparisons to Flint, Mich.

Title: A Wildlife Lover Gets His Dream Job at Last
Abstrace: TRENTON.

Title: Public Meetings Are a Brawl, So the Mayor Suggests a Bouncer
Abstrace: Like many towns, Edgewater, N.J., is struggling to find a way to impose order on public meetings.

Title: New Jersey Senate Panel Supports Penalty for Smoking in Cars With Children Aboard
Abstrace: TRENTON, June 7  Smoking in New Jersey has been banned from the workplace, public buildings, bars, restaurants and even large swaths of the casino floors in Atlantic City. The next frontier is the family car with children aboard.

Title: Saving the Republican Party
Abstrace: The big challenge now for New Jersey Republicans is to face the fact that the brand is going to have to be moderate if they want to win statewide elections.

Title: Ode to Commuting
Abstrace: Andrea Honore Soapbox essay on pros and cons of commuting alone by car between Princeton and New Brunswick, NJ; drawing (M)

Title: New York and New Jersey
Abstrace: NEW YORK.

Title: Stinking Garbage, How I Miss It
Abstrace: Marialisa Calta Rituals column recalls fond childhood memories of visiting dump with neighbor at Jersey Shore; drawing (M)

Title: Grateful for Power, and for the Power to Corrupt
Abstrace: Neil Genzlinger Jersey column offers results of informal survey of what New Jerseyans say they are grateful for; drawing (M)

Title: Get Ready for a Brawl on Sprawl
Abstrace: New Jersey Gov James McGreevey essay explains his goals for regulating and curtailing uncontrolled development in state; photo (M)

Title: Senate Candidates Argue Over Ability to Get U.S. Money for New Jersey
Abstrace: New Jersey Senate candidates Douglas Forrester and Frank Lautenberg argue over who could bring most federal money back to state; photos of Forrester in Ridgewood with Repr J C Watts Jr of Oklahoma andLautenberg in Secaucus (M)

Title: At Some Superfund Sites, Toxic Legacies Linger
Abstrace: The cleanup of toxic sites in the region is not easy and frustrations often are expressed.

Title: Homes: 1,681; Horses: More Than 500
Abstrace: Despite the development pressure, the 28-square-mile township remains about two-thirds farmland.

Title: Sierra Club Endorses McGreevey For Governor
Abstrace: Jeffrey Tittel, head of New Jersey chapter of Sierra Club, calls Bret D Schundler a 'threat to the environment in New Jersey'; delivers ringing endorsement of his Democratic opponent in governor's race, James E McGreevey (M)

Title: California Shows How States Can Lead on Climate Change
Abstrace: The state is making a bold global statement with its cap-and-trade program.

Title: For Developers, Brownfields Look Less Risky
Abstrace: Article on private sector's increasing interest in making money cleaning up and redeveloping lightly contaminated properties called brownfields, many of which are convenient to transportation and urban centers; dreay 1.87-square-mile stretch of old municipal dumps that litter New Jersey Meadowlands is to be transformed from longtime eyesore into parklike setting of golf courses, hotels, housing and offices; photos; map (M)

Title: Plan for Electric Cable to Grid Nears Deadline
Abstrace: At issue is a cable under the Hudson River that would hook New York City to the electricity grid in New Jersey.

Title: Qualms Over Clean Energy That Would Come From 12 Stories Up
Abstrace: A man’s plan to install a wind turbine at his car wash in Wayne, N.J., has brought opposition from many residents.

Title: As Flooding Persists, Calls for Dredging of Rivers
Abstrace: SADDLE BROOK.

Title: Why Dumps Are Gaining in Allure
Abstrace: Transforming waste facilities into more lucrative properties is becoming increasingly common.

Title: No Longer Tourists, Stripers Return to Stay
Abstrace: Biologists in New Jersey are keeping a watchful eye as the population of the striped bass rebuilds.

Title: Saving the Republican Party
Abstrace: Editorial, in light of election results, sees ominous possibility that New Jersey could become one-party Democratic state; holds Republican survivors should look to Thomas Kean Jr's losing campaign for clues about what they need to change; says Republican brand needs to be moderate if future candidates want to win statewide elections

Title: New York, New Jersey and Connecticut
Abstrace: NEW YORK.

Title: Corzine Offers Health Plan; Rivals Unite in Attacking It
Abstrace: With Republicans mired in an increasingly caustic primary, Senator Jon S. Corzine, the de facto Democratic nominee, sought to take center stage on Monday in New Jersey's gubernatorial race by unveiling a health care plan intended to slow increases in insurance premiums and help hundreds of thousands of uninsured New Jersey residents afford coverage.    Mr. Corzine's proposal called for universal coverage for pregnant women and children and for a pool of finances to help small businesses pay for catastrophic care. The proposal would also require insurance companies to allow parents to cover their adult children, ages 19 to 30. He said that his goal was to have 95 percent of the state's residents covered by health insurance by 2009, up from 81 percent today.

Title: New Jersey and New York
Abstrace: NEW JERSEY.

Title: Second Part Of Land Deal Speeds Up Development
Abstrace: New Jersey lawmakers unveil proposal that would significantly speed development on more than one-third of state's vacant land, just days after approving plan to preserve 400,000 acres near sources of drinking water in Highlands region; law would streamline building-permit process by granting developers automatic approval of zoning or environmental applications that are still undecided after 45 days; plan calls for ombudsman to help builders who believe they are bogged down by Environmental Protection Dept or other agencies; Gov James McGreevey spokesman says proposal does not weaken regulations, but environmentalists are angry about concessions to building lobby (M)

Title: Residential Real Estate; A Turnabout for North Jersey Rentals
Abstrace: 41-story, 538-unit rental complex atop Palisade cliffs in Fort Lee, NJ, is latest addition to Hudson River waterfront in Bergen County; complex, called Palisades, opens for leasing in March (M)

Title: A $52 Billion Proposal Aims to Protect New York Harbor From Storm Surges
Abstrace: The proposal for 12 movable sea barriers across waterways like Jamaica Bay replaces a disputed plan for a single, larger outer-harbor wall.

Title: Gas Tax Spikes in N.J. Because of Pandemic’s Impact
Abstrace: Taxes on gasoline and diesel increased by 9.3 cents a gallon on Thursday in a state once known for bargain fuel. The increase came a month after tolls on major roadways also went up.

Title: Some Rose to Greatness in the Disaster. Could That Happen in the ’13 Campaign?
Abstrace: Perhaps people who acted heroically during Hurricane Sandy can be emulated by mayoral candidates, who should face the challenges of global warming that Governor Cuomo discusses.

Title: Christie’s Silence Spurs Worry for Train Tunnel
Abstrace: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey could scuttle the biggest mass transit project under way in the country.

Title: A Back Seat for Parking Space
Abstrace: A classic feature of the gritty old days of New Jersey’s older, larger cities is starting to shrivel and disappear from view: parking garages.

Title: In Local Waters, an Oyster Resurgence
Abstrace: Two years after a failed effort to declare it an endangered species, the Eastern oyster is making a big comeback.

Title: The Week in New Jersey
Abstrace: Increased development along Barnegat Bay has contributed to an overabundance of nitrogen and other nutrients that threaten the bay’s long-term health, according to a report released Tuesday by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

Title: The Week in New Jersey
Abstrace: The family of a man dragged to death by a New Jersey Transit train has sued the railroad, charging that negligent employees and a faulty door were to blame for the November accident. Meanwhile, the crew on board when the man, John D’Agostino, was killed have almost exhausted their appeals fighting dismissal from their jobs.

Title: The Week in New Jersey
Abstrace: For now, it appears, all bets are off for an out-of-court settlement between former Gov. James E. McGreevey and his estranged wife, based on an amended complaint he filed seeking the court’s input on child custody, support and visitation.

Title: Transit Villages Come to Life
Abstrace: In a number of New Jersey communities a state program has enlivened once empty streets.

Title: No Longer Tourists, Stripers Return to Stay
Abstrace: Kevin Coyne Jersey column on work of New Jersey Division of Fish and Wildlife biologists that catch, count and measure striped bass that were spawned in Delaware River; photo (M)

Title: Shedding Some Light On Our Addiction to Oil
Abstrace: Paula Span Jersey column on promotion of solar energy to businesses and residents of New Jersey; state has promoted solar electricity so effectively that a thousand voltaic array systems are operating around state, mostly atop homes; installing seven kilowatt system that can provide 75 percent or more of household's electricity (excluding heat and hot water) costs nearly $60,000; state rebate program currently covers about half; drawing (M)

Title: Everybody Loves a Whale; Sea Turtles Need a Press Agent
Abstrace: The last time all three phone lines at the Marine Mammal Stranding Center lighted up all at once was in 1994, when a right whale drew crowds as it swam free in Delaware Bay below Philadelphia. This time it was the beluga whale that followed the spring shad run up the Delaware as far as Trenton.    But the dozens of seals, turtles and other sea animals that the center rescues each year hardly draw a ripple of notice.

Title: New Jersey Democrats Campaign Without Mentioning McGreevey
Abstrace: New Jersey Democrats campaign for State Legislature without mentioning Gov James E McGreevey, whose popularity ratings are dismal; Republican candidates score property tax increases in governor's budget, but analysts say McGreevey's low approval rating may be due not to one issue but rather to variety of missteps; photo (M)

Title: Meaningful Legislation? Don't Hold Your Breath
Abstrace: Laura Mansnerus On Politics column on lackluster performance of New Jersey legislature in 23 months since Gov James McGreevey took office; holds failure to act on some of state's most pressing problems cannot be blamed on Senate's 20-20 political split (M)

Title: Why a Station in Secaucus With So Many Costly Woes
Abstrace: David Kocieniewski On Politics column expresses doubts that opening of New Jersey Transit's $450 million Secaucus transfer station will mark beginning of new Golden Era for rail travel in New Jersey; notes agency's $1.3 billion budget is stretched thin, South Jersey Light Rail project may become major fiasco and commuters keep on waiting for better service (M)

Title: Torricelli-Forrester Fight Grows Fiercer by the Day
Abstrace: Debate between Dl

Title: Great Idea For Trash, If It Works, Most Say
Abstrace: Bloomberg administration's solution to New York City's $1 billion-a-year trash problem is to deliver garbage in sealed containers to local railyards or shipyards that can move it to landfill anywhere east of Mississippi instead of sending trash to Fresh Kills landfill each day, as barges once did; no one, including Bloomberg's own staff, is quite sure plan would work; since Fresh Kills closed last year, thousands of trucks each day have been carrying garbage across bridges and tunnels to New Jersey, where it was either burned at incinerators or put onto tractor-trailers and then hauled to landfills mostly in Pennsylvania, Ohio and Virginia (M)

Title: A 'Fairly Typical' Year for Beach Closings
Abstrace: Article on challenges facing New Jersey shore communities this summer as they deal with new water-testing standards and overtaxed storm water and sewage system made worse by recent torrential rains; ocean beach closings in New Jersey stand at 20 so far this summer, same as last year at this time; photos (L)

Title: If a Rainstorm Causes Flooding in New York, What Would a Hurricane Bring?
Abstrace: The storms and power failures this week show the region is not prepared for the extremes that climate change will bring, officials warned.

Title: High Above the Water, but Awash in Red Tape
Abstrace: The approval process for elevating the deck of the Bayonne Bridge is a case study, critics say, in environmental bureaucracy.

Title: Christie Halts Train Tunnel, Citing Its Cost
Abstrace: Gov. Chris Christie cited estimates that the project could be more than $2.5 billion over its budget of $8.7 billion.

Title: Without Superfund Tax, Stimulus Aids Cleanups
Abstrace: The Superfund program, established nearly 30 years ago to clean up the nation’s most contaminated industrial sites, has been underfinanced since a tax expired in 1995.

Title: Commuting by Road, but Not by Car
Abstrace: Bus systems are attracting new riders as $3-a-gallon gas prices remain common around the region and mass-transit advocates urge commuters to leave their cars at home.

Title: A Well-Traveled Ecologist
Abstrace: Profile of Steven Handel, Rutgers University urban ecologist and director of Center for Urban Restoration Ecology, joint venture between Rutgers and Brooklyn Botanic Garden; photos (Special Issue: New Jersey at Its Best) (M)

Title: Where Mosquitoes And Tires Breed
Abstrace: New Jersey officials, seeking to combat West Nile virus, have earmarked funds to clean up so-called orphan dumps, where huge piles of tires fill with water and leaves, making them perfect spawning grounds for mosquitoes; photos; map (M)

Title: Hudson Tunnel Review Raises Fear for Project
Abstrace: Advocates fear the planned tunnel may be delayed or scrapped after Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey ordered a reassessment of the cost, now estimated at $8.7 billion.

Title: New Jersey Joins 10 States in Banning Indoor Smoking
Abstrace: New Jersey is set to become eleventh state to impose smoking ban in indoor public places, which include restaurants and bars; smokers out for one last night before law takes effect discuss ban; Atlantic City casinos are exempt from current legislation, but anti-smoking efforts are underway to make casinos smoke-free as well; photo (M)

Title: Tourists Seeking Wild Beauty, in New Jersey? Seriously, They Find It
Abstrace: This area is better known to most as Exit 15W on the New Jersey Turnpike, or the flight path out of Newark Liberty International Airport, or the railroad crossing on New Jersey Transit's main line. But beneath these human landmarks, unnoticed and as foundational as a heartbeat, lie dirt, water, grass and life.      A double-crested cormorant struggles to swallow a wriggling American eel. Tree swallows in the Mill Creek Marsh each eat 2,000 mosquitoes a day. Pontoon boats full of ecotourists roam the Hackensack River.

Title: New Jersey Blocks Off Highlands But Eases Other Rules for Builders
Abstrace: New Jersey lawmakers approve two bills that could alter state's landscape for generations; one will protect much of state's drinking water by limiting development in area known as Highlands, but critics have lambasted Gov James McGreevey for trading out benefits of that bill for one that streamlines building permit process in much of state, which is likely to accelerate construction in some areas; second bill passed quickly and with no floor debate, illustrating construction lobby's political muscle; legal experts say rules are so lax now that they are not likely to withstand court challenges; map shows desinated growth areas (M)

Title: Biden to Visit Northeast Flood Zones as Demand Grows for Climate Action
Abstrace: The president will visit hard-hit areas in New York and New Jersey, as residents call for more serious action on climate change.

Title: Local Elections to Test the Nation's Mood
Abstrace: Voters, in first broad test of nation's political mood since September 11 terrorist attacks, will go to polls on November 6 to elect governors and legislatures in New Jersey and Virginia and mayors in dozen or so major cities; subtext of many campaigns, and main text of few, has been deteriorating economy and need for strong security and strong leaders in attacks' aftermath; gubernatorial campaigns in Virginia between Democrat Mark Warner and Republican Mark L Earley and in New Jersey between Democrat James E McGreevey and Bret D Schundler discussed; other contests noted; photos (M)

Title: The wheels come off the school bus industry
Abstrace: And students in Britain and New Jersey are facing a particularly uncertain start to the year.

Title: Got Water?
Abstrace: Article on difficulty of managing public water supplies in New Jersey; recalls 1999 crisis when water in Passaic River became too dirty to drink and hurricane came to rescue; lack of rainfall and rapid growth again is threatening drinking water supply and some towns have imposed water restrictions; photos; map; chart (L)

Title: Competing Plans to Transform a Town
Abstrace: A DEVELOPER proposing to create what amounts to a new waterfront town within Sayreville on 400 acres of polluted land claimed last week that the project could eliminate the need for current residents to pay taxes.      At a public hearing on four proposals by ''finalists'' in the quest to redevelop the former site of the National Lead Company, an area surrounded on three sides by water, Beacon Pointe, a development group, told assembled residents that if it ushers in this project, they can usher out their annual town tax bills.

Title: Hot and Cold on the State Purse
Abstrace: Article on debate over environmental aspects of New Jersey Gov James McGreevey's latest budget proposal; plan, praised by environmentalists and condemned by businesses, calls for number of fees and taxes aimed at strengthening variety of environmental programs, part of long-term move to shift cost of environmental enforcement from taxpayers to polluters; photo (M)

Title: New Jersey Well-Water Testing
Abstrace: Article on new New Jersey law that requires homeowners to have their water wells tested for contamination before selling their property; says tests--which are estimated to cost $450 to $600--must be conducted before closing, and both buyer and seller must certify in writing that tests were performed and that they have been notified of results; drawing (M)

Title: New Jersey Well-Water Testing
Abstrace: Article on new New Jersey law that requires homeowners to have their water wells tested for contamination before selling their property; says tests--which are estimated to cost $450 to $600--must be conducted before closing, and both buyer and seller must certify in writing that tests were performed and that they have been notified of results; drawing (M)

Title: In New Jersey, Party Bosses Meld Politics and Business
Abstrace: Construction is expected to begin this year on a condominium project that will add cars to clogged roads, tax the sewer system and strain the nearly depleted water supply of this growing suburb along the Jersey shore.      Getting the go-ahead to build near a congested stretch of Route 9 in Dover Township required an assortment of special arrangements including zoning changes that hinged on the support of local officials.

Title: The Decibel Level Rises Over Off-Road Vehicles
Abstrace: New Jersey environmental officials, alarmed by surge in off-road riders on illegal, makeshift dirt tracks and trails and damage to natural areas, are expected to announce policy that would ease ban against such vehicles on public lands; photos (M)

Title: Endorsements in New York and New Jersey
Abstrace: There are a number of congressional and state races where voters can make a difference.

Title: Betting on a new way to make concrete that doesn’t pollute
Abstrace: A New Jersey firm is experimenting in a small town in England with a new formula that reduces the carbon dioxide emitted in the making of the building material.

Title: Drowsy Truckers Find No Room for Their Rigs
Abstrace: Overcrowding at interstate rest areas only adds to nationwide safety problem caused by sleepy truck drivers; study conducted by University of Tennessee finds that along Tennessee highways on any given night, more than 500 trucks are parked illegally; related problem is that 18 states limit amount of time trucker can remain in rest area, with two hours being limit in Pennsylvania, New York, Virginia and parts of New Jersey; Federal Highway Administration is conducting study of extent of aggregate space shortage at rest areas and truck stops; photo (M)

Title: E.P.A.'s Authority on Air Rules Wins Supreme Court's Backing
Abstrace: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 — The Supreme Court today unanimously and decisively rejected an industry attack on the Clean Air Act in one of the court's most important environmental rulings in years.

Title: Bottle Bing
Abstrace: To increase its wine business, New Jersey needs to channel its inner Tony Soprano.

Title: The Enforcer; As Mrs. Whitman Begins Her New Job, There Is Debate Over Her Commitment to the Environment in the Past
Abstrace: Article on debate over New Jersey Gov Christie Whitman's depth of concern for the environment as she begins new job as head of Environmental Protection Agency; Whitman's administration was marked by controversial change in philosophy toward less regulation and more cooperative relationship with industry and developers, rankling environmental groups; photos (M)

Title: The Smoke Just Won't Settle
Abstrace: Bartenders and patrons in Hoboken comment on two new reports on secondhand smoke in bars and restaurants that are renewing interest in passage of smoking ban in New Jersey similar to ones enacted in at least 10 states; Park Cancer Institute study of air quality in 62 bars and restaurants in eight cities concluded that carcinogens and other pollutants in New Jersey bars and restaurants are nine times worse than those in New York City, where smoking has been banned since March 2003; study sponsored by New Jersey Breathes found that 74 percent of state's registered voters favored passage of smoking ban in workplaces; photos (M)

Title: Who Let the Dogs Out?
Abstrace: Article on New Jersey residents who participate in sport of dog sledding as new season opens in Pine Barrens; photos (M)

Title: Several States Likely to Follow California on Car Emissions
Abstrace: California's plan for sharp cuts in automotive emissions of global warming gases could eventually lead much of coastal US to turn to vehicles that are substantially cleaner, and by extension more fuel efficient, than those in rest of nation; New Jersey, Rhode Island and Connecticut have said they intend to start following California's car rules instead of those of federal government; New York, Massachusetts, Vermont and Maine already do so; photo (M)

Title: Jim Florio, New Jersey Governor Undone by Tax Hike, Dies at 85
Abstrace: A Democrat, he had successes on gun control, the environment and property-tax relief, but after raising income and sales taxes, he lost a bid for re-election.

Title: New Jersey Governor Seeks to Slow New York’s Congestion Pricing Effort
Abstrace: The plan would charge drivers who enter Manhattan below 60th Street.

Title: Shocking, but Not Surprising
Abstrace: New Jersey Gov James McGreevey's wrenching career implosion is somehow unsurprising in state known for periodic revelations of inappropriate behavior in high places; photos (M)

Title: In War on Congestion Pricing, Governor Turns to Courts and Trash Talk
Abstrace: A lawsuit that Gov. Philip Murphy of New Jersey has filed against New York’s congestion pricing plan has reignited a border war and led to charges of hypocrisy.

Title: Boy, Is This Seder Different From All Others
Abstrace: Article on Murray Spiegel, Rickey Stein, Rabbi Ron Kaplan and Ann Thayer-Cohen, just a few of increasing number of Jews in New Jersey who stage elaborate and untraditional Passover seders each year; photo (M)

Title: Sewage Flows After Storm Expose Flaws in System
Abstrace: Hurricane Sandy crippled treatment plants in New York and New Jersey, revealing problems in the region’s wastewater infrastructure that could take several years and billions of dollars to fix.

Title: What Could Disappear
Abstrace: Coastal and low-lying areas that would be permanently flooded in three levels of higher seas.

Title: For Him the Toll Smells
Abstrace: Article on Raymond Neveil, 77-year-old retiree who formed Citizens Against Tolls more than a year ago, which has helped force issue of tolls on Garden State Parkway into New Jersey gubernatorial race; photos (M)

Title: New Jersey’s Governor Often Wasn’t in New Jersey
Abstrace: Since taking office last year, Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey has traveled outside the state far more than his recent predecessors — nearly one in every four days.

Title: These Days, a Commissioner Is Under Siege
Abstrace: BRADLEY M. CAMPBELL is either Solomonic or politically hopeless. In a brewing political fight over sprawl, Mr. Campbell, the state's commissioner of environmental protection, is vilified by builders and environmental advocates alike. And the man he works for, Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey, is not exactly rushing to his side.      Mr. Campbell puzzled just about everybody recently when he said he was suspending work on a new law, known by its Trenton shorthand as ''fast track,'' that expedites approvals for development projects.

Title: New Jersey Prosecutor Finds He's the One Investigated
