Title: Montanans Weigh Options on a Toxic Legacy
Abstrace: Clark Fork, 120-mile long river in Montana, is contaminated with more than century's worth of cadmium, arsenic, copper and other toxic mine waste that has washed down from hard rock mining that began in 1864 in Butte; last stop for mine waste has been behind Milltown Dam in Bonner, creating huge pile of toxic sludge; Environmental Protection Agency will decide fate of river in next few months; cost for cleanup to date is $700 million and is expected to reach $1 billion in next decade; many local residents portray dam as toxic time bomb; ARCO, company that bought mining company only to find it has inherited expensive mess, does not favor removal, saying it would do more harm than good; photo; map (M)

Title: Hordes of Geese Die on a Toxic Lake in Montana
Abstrace: The exact cause of the birds’ deaths is unknown, and experts worry that thousands more could be in danger during this year’s migratory season.

Title: Traces of Montana Oil Spill Are Found in Drinking Water
Abstrace: Crews were working to clean up 50,000 gallons of oil that flowed into the Yellowstone River from a ruptured pipeline.

Title: Rich in Coal, a Tribe Struggles to Overcome Poverty
Abstrace: Leaders of the Crow Nation are trying to develop the tribe's energy resources to create more jobs. But starting a new coal project has proved difficult, and some members are pursuing wind power.

Title: Too Many Links
Abstrace: Don’t ever take a week off from link aggregating. You’ll never catch up.

Title: Mine in Wilderness Approved After 14 Years
Abstrace: United States Forest Service and Mont

Title: Let the Stream Run Through It
Abstrace: It’s taken two decades to clean up most of Silver Bow Creek, polluted from a century of mining. Now some Butte, Mont., residents want the last two miles restored, to babble on through the city.

Title: Can Montana’s Smith River Survive a Nearby Mine?
Abstrace: A float trip down a beloved river explores what might be at stake if a proposal for a copper mine by its watershed becomes reality.

Title: Judge Vacates Oil and Gas Leases on 145,000 Acres in Montana
Abstrace: A federal judge, rapping the Trump administration for its weak environmental assessments, has vacated hundreds of oil and gas leases across a large swath of Montana.

Title: Seeking Clean Fuel for a Nation, and a Rebirth for Small-Town Montana
Abstrace: Gov Brian Schweitzer of Montana, which has 120 billion tons of coal reserve, is promoting conversion of coal to fuel that could run cars, jets and trucks or heat homes without contributing to global warming or setting off major fight with environmental groups; believes array of coal-to-fuel factories would help revive Montana dying small towns; his ideas are just speculative for now, but several energy companies have expressed interest in building plants; environmentalists have concerns about strip mining ranch country and would want assurances that synethetic fuels will be made with new technology that removes and stores pollutants during and after processing; photo (M)

Title: Congress, in a First, Removes an Animal From the Endangered Species List
Abstrace: Environmental groups said a budget measure dictating that wolves in Montana and Idaho be taken off the list sets an unnerving precedent.

Title: In Montana, It’s Youth vs. the State in a Landmark Climate Case
Abstrace: Sixteen young Montanans have sued their state, arguing that its support of fossil fuels violates the state Constitution.

Title: Blotting Out the Big Sky
Abstrace: The weather that now bears very directly on the Montana economy is in crisis.

Title: Dam and Waste Will Go, Freeing Two Rivers
Abstrace: Since 1907, the Milltown Dam just east of Missoula, Mont., has held back two of the state's major rivers and trapped tons of toxic mining waste that once washed down one of them from more than 100 miles upstream.     An agreement announced this week, however, will allow work to begin on the removal of the decaying timber-and-stone structure and the waste behind it. The job is a technically challenging one that aims to restore the two rivers, the Blackfoot and the Clark Fork, to free-flowing conditions by 2009 at a cost of about $100 million.

Title: Shouting ‘Fire!’ in the Burning West
Abstrace: It’s almost like we have just two seasons now, winter and wildfire.

Title: Capturing the Joyful Spirit of a Montana General Store
Abstrace: The state’s oldest continually open general store serves customers in Fishtail from all walks of life, from ranchers and miners to doctors and C.E.O.s.

Title: Judge Rules in Favor of Montana Youths in a Landmark Climate Case
Abstrace: The court found that young people have a constitutional right to a healthful environment and that the state must consider potential climate damage when approving projects.

Title: Montana’s Famed Trout Under Threat as Drought Intensifies
Abstrace: The state is imposing more restrictions on fishing this year as the combination of extreme conditions, including low river levels, fish die-offs and the crush of anglers, poses long-term problems.

Title: The Freshwater Giants Are Dying
Abstrace: Overharvesting and habitat loss endanger most of the world’s freshwater “megafauna.” But many species may yet be saved.

Title: Writer on the Road: Heading West
Abstrace: Steve Chapple travel article on his 2-day trip from Montana to Southern California with his final destination Paris Hotel in Las Vegas; map; photos (special section, The Sophisticated Traveler) (part 2 of 2-part section) (L)

Title: PBS Series Explores ‘A New Wild’ Sustained, Instead of Wrecked, by People
Abstrace: In a new PBS series, a conservation biologist explores how people can be a nurturing presence in what used to be called “the wild.”

Title: Fight Against Coal Plants Draws Diverse Partners
Abstrace: An increasingly vocal and potent anti-coal movement in the West includes ranchers, farmers and religious groups.

Title: Wilderness Above, a Mine Below and a Furor
Abstrace: Environmentalists plan to mount strenuous legal challenge to project to mine silver and copper beneath Cabinet Mountains Wilderness Area, first such large-scale mining to be permitted beneath wilderness area; Montana Dept of Environmental Quality and United State Forest Service have granted permission to Sterling Mining Co, but with strict environmental regulations; project also angers officials in northern Idaho, which depends on tourists drawn to its clear rivers; treated waste water from mine would drain into trout-filled lakes in Montana and Idaho; at core of fight is question never tested on so large a scale since Congress authorized creation of national wilderness areas 38 years ago: should mines be allowed to extend underneath federally designated wilderness zones, which by statute are to be 'untrammeled by man'; Sterling Mining Co contends that wilderness area would be untrammeled on the surface; opponents say project would be far more intrusive than Sterling says; photos; map (L)

Title: Behind Gold's Glitter: Torn Lands and Pointed Questions
Abstrace: First article in series examining gold mining around the world; with of gold at about $500 per ounce, small amount that is left to be mined is being taken at high cost to environment and often in poorest regions; latest gold mania is almost all about soaring demand for jewelry, which consumes 80 percent or more of gold mined today; to get one ounce of gold, miners dig up and haul away 30 tons of rock, sprinkle it with cyanide, which separates gold from rock, and leave behind environmental degradation; EPA says hard-rock mining generates more toxic waste than any other industry in America, and estimates that cost of cleaning up metal mines could reach $54 billion, which will likely be passed to taxpayers; people of Montana are still bitter over first large-scale open-pit cynanide operation in northeastern part of state, and blame Pegasus Gold's overly ambitious production schedule, internal mismanagement and poor oversight for multilayered disaster; with rich countries' supplies mostly depleted, 70 percent of gold is mined in developing countries like Ghana and Guatemala; gold companies tout their contribution to new frontiers, but environmentalists say they are mining in ways that would never be tolerated in wealthier nations; World Bank has encouraged poor nations to take steps to lure mining companies, but promised jobs have not materialized, indigenous people have been displaced and working conditions are intolerable; photos; map; chart shows mining processes (L)

Title: How Montana Took a Hard Right Turn Toward Christian Nationalism
Abstrace: What happened to a state known for its political independence?

Title: Polluting Industries Say the Cost of Cleaner Air Is Too High
Abstrace: As the Biden administration prepares to toughen air quality standards, health benefits are weighed against the cost of compliance.

Title: National Briefing | Midwest: Ohio: Egg Company To Curtail Pollution
Abstrace: Owners of network of egg farms in northwest Ohio that discharged thousands of tons of ammonia, dung dust and other air pollution each year will install $1.6 million in filters and other pollution controls and pay $880,598 in penalties under settlement filed in federal court (S)

Title: A Warning for the Newest Victims of Federal Neglect and Corporate Greed in Ohio
Abstrace: I grew up near a toxic disaster. The years ahead in East Palestine could be tough.

Title: TRIAL OPENS
Abstrace: New Jersey and federal government begin trial in Columbus, Ohio, alleging that air pollution in New Jersey is made worse by Ohio Edison power plant (S)

Title: National Briefing: Midwest
Abstrace: OHIO: Egg Company To Curtail Pollution; MICHIGAN: University Fights Abortion Subpoena;.

Title: Behind Toledo’s Water Crisis, a Long-Troubled Lake Erie
Abstrace: Pollution concerns persist about tides of phosphorus in the Great Lakes and in waterways across the United States.

Title: ‘We’re Scared, Too’: Ohio Residents Press for Answers on Train Derailment at Meeting
Abstrace: Officials for the railroad company pulled out hours earlier, infuriating some residents who said they wanted answers from the company.

Title: Many in East Palestine, Skeptical of Official Tests, Seek Out Their Own
Abstrace: The moves reflect residents’ deep-seated mistrust of government screenings of toxic chemicals and fears of long-term effects from the train derailment.

Title: Power Plant That Pollutes Northeast Agrees to Cut Emissions
Abstrace: Ohio Edison Co agrees to cut harmful emissions at W H Sammis plant in Stratton (Ohio); move could drastically reduce air pollution in areas in Northeastern states that are downwind of plant, including New York State; photo (M)

Title: Under Trump, E.P.A. Has Slowed Actions Against Polluters, and Put Limits on Enforcement Officers
Abstrace: An analysis of enforcement data at the E.P.A. shows a substantial drop in activity against polluters when compared with the Obama and Bush administrations.

Title: E.P.A. Enforcement Nominee Withdraws
Abstrace: Donald Schregardus, who was nominated by Pres Bush to be top law enforcement official of Environmental Protection Agency, withdraws his name from consideration, saying his nomination will not be considered 'in a timely manner'; several Democratic senators and environmental groups had criticized him, saying he was lax in enforcing pollution laws in Ohio, where he was environmental regulator; his nomination ran into new trouble when EPA itself released report criticizing his efforts to enforce clean-air laws in Ohio; photo (M)

Title: A Homecoming for Hellbenders, the Biggest Salamanders in North America
Abstrace: To try to restore their population, conservationists will release hundreds of the salamanders, which have been raised to maturity, into streams in Ohio.

Title: In Ohio Town Where Train Derailed, Anxiety and Distrust Are Running Deep
Abstrace: Nearly two weeks after a train carrying toxic chemicals derailed in East Palestine, Ohio, confusing messages from government officials have frayed locals’ trust.

Title: A Novel Way to Clean Wastewater
Abstrace: A silica substance that behaves like a sponge, pulling out contaminants but not the water itself, could prove useful in treating wastewater from fracking, its inventor says.

Title: In Ohio, One Farmer's Prosperity Is Another's Poison
Abstrace: New generation of large dairy farms in Ohio, Indiana and Michigan, many owned by Dutch immigrants, are pumping money into rural economies but also drawing protests from environmental groups and homeowners concerned about water pollution, odors and land values; Martin De Haan plans to build 2,100-cow dairy farm in South Solon, Ohio, but his neighbor Mary Pierce opposes it; their photos (M)

Title: Ohio Groups Question Justice's Trip On Utility Jet
Abstrace: American Electric Power, company based in Ohio with dozen cases in federal courts, is flying Supreme Court Chief Justice William H Rehnquist to Columbus so he can deliver speech at dedication of new home of Ohio Supreme Court; environmental groups express concern over propriety of Supreme Court justice's being accorded favors by company that has so many active cases, including one that goes to trial in 2005 involving accusations that its plant operations in Ohio violate Clean Air Act; Rehnquist photo (M)

Title: With E.P.A. Cuts, States Would Lose Help in Emergencies
Abstrace: Much of the agency’s state-level work would be eliminated or sharply reduced by President Trump’s proposed budget, which cuts the E.P.A. more than any other agency.

Title: Lead in Ohio Villages’ Water Went Uncurbed for Months, State Says
Abstrace: Officials took action against the operator of the water treatment plant in Sebring, who they said delayed raising an alarm and might have falsified documents.

Title: The Proliferation of Plastics and Toxic Chemicals Must End
Abstrace: As we confront climate change, focusing on a single metric, like greenhouse gas emissions, could leave other harmful practices unaddressed.

Title: An Environmental Nominee Is Opposed
Abstrace: Democratic critics and environmental groups step up pressure to halt Pres Bush's nomination of Donald Schregardus, Ohio's top environmental regulator to be lead enforcer for Environmental Protection Agency; says Schregardus was lax during tenure in Ohio and that several programs for which he was responsible are under investigation by federal agency; Schregardus opposition to environment lawsuits filed by federal government during Clinton administration, many against power plants in Midwest, discussed; photo (M)

Title: Market Place; Ohio Utility Cited in Blackout Has Had a Troubled Summer
Abstrace: Massive blackout is latest of FirstEnergy Corp's problems this summer, Market Place column; company acknowledges that alarm system had not been working at time of blackout, but it tries to deflect blame for widespread power failure, saying there were problems in other parts of nation's electrical system before its lines began to fail; North American Electric Reliability Council, group created by utilities to set standards for reducing risks of disruption, was first to call public attention to FirstEnergy's problems, but it agrees with company that problem is more complicated than just one utility; Richard H Marsh, FirstEnergy's chief financial officer, cites company's other problems this summer: blackouts in coastal New Jersey communities over July 4 weekend, federal judge's ruling that company violated Clean Air Act, delays in getting nuclear power plant in Ohio back in operation and decision by its auditors to require it to restate profits over last three years; photos; graph (M)

Title: Gas Flaring and Preterm Births
Abstrace: Also this week, a corruption case in Ohio that’s all about energy

Title: A Pushback on Green Power
Abstrace: Opponents of government policies that have spurred the growth of renewable energy are pushing back on mandates nationwide.

Title: Miles of Algae Covering Lake Erie
Abstrace: A large algae bloom overtook the western basin of Lake Erie last week, alarming residents and local officials.

Title: A Late Bet on Coal May Not Pay Off
Abstrace: A consortium of utilities decided to build a coal-fired power plant, probably one of the last that will be allowed under E.P.A. regulations, figuring it would be cheaper than buying electricity on the open market. The low cost of natural gas has foiled that calculation.

Title: Seeking Disclosure on Fracking
Abstrace: The push toward making companies disclose the chemicals used in the oil and gas drilling practice is based on fears that the process could contaminate groundwater.

Title: Great Idea For Trash, If It Works, Most Say
Abstrace: Bloomberg administration's solution to New York City's $1 billion-a-year trash problem is to deliver garbage in sealed containers to local railyards or shipyards that can move it to landfill anywhere east of Mississippi instead of sending trash to Fresh Kills landfill each day, as barges once did; no one, including Bloomberg's own staff, is quite sure plan would work; since Fresh Kills closed last year, thousands of trucks each day have been carrying garbage across bridges and tunnels to New Jersey, where it was either burned at incinerators or put onto tractor-trailers and then hauled to landfills mostly in Pennsylvania, Ohio and Virginia (M)

Title: This Deadly Chemical Should Be Banned
Abstrace: The cancer-causing chemical vinyl chloride was vented and burned after the Ohio train crash to avoid an explosion. The United States should phase it out.

Title: Fight Against Asian Carp Threatens Fragile Great Lakes Unity
Abstrace: A nonnative fish that consumes the food of other, native fish is unwanted in Michigan, and the state is suing to have waterways shut down.

Title: Farmers Lean to Truce on Animals’ Close Quarters
Abstrace: Ohio farmers agreed to phase out confinement of livestock, underscoring the clout of the animal welfare movement.

Title: Reborn, Lake Erie Beckons Kayakers
Abstrace: Article on kayaking trip among Ohioan islands of Lake Erie; photos; maps (M)

Title: For Manufacturers, a Complex Mix Can Determine Location
Abstrace: While rural areas offer manufacturers some advantages, they can no longer count on lower salaries for workers or finding employees with the skills they need.

Title: Ohio’s Resurgent Natural Gas Industry Spends Millions to Set Up Shop
Abstrace: As gas starts to flow from wells drilled into the Utica Shale deep beneath the state, a network of infrastructure is being built to process, market and transport it.

Title: Some States Sitting on Piles of Cash, and Cities Want a Cut
Abstrace: States like Ohio are placing their surpluses in rainy-day funds, but cities that have suffered because of cuts since the recession say it is time to loosen up.

Title: Finding Purpose After Living With Delusion
Abstrace: Milt Greek, an Ohio computer programmer, helps other people who have been diagnosed with schizophrenia to share their stories and gain insight into their condition.

Title: Stemming the Loss of Local Journalism
Abstrace: Readers discuss the role that philanthropists and lawmakers can play to help save local papers.

Title: National Briefing | Washington: E.P.A. And North Dakota Ease Air Rules
Abstrace: North Dakota and Environmental Protection Agency agree to adopt new ways to measure air pollution that will ease way to build coal-burning power plants near Theodore Roosevelt National Park and other areas (S)

Title: Fighting the Tank Car Invasion
Abstrace: Tankers of combustible crude oil have overtaken railways in recent years, but one community is pushing back.

Title: U.S. and Canada Reach Deal on Draining Lake
Abstrace: American and Canadian negotiators have reached an agreement that will allow North Dakota to drain excess water from its largest natural lake into Canadian lakes and rivers, overcoming pollution concerns that had become an escalating diplomatic irritant for more than a year.     Devils Lake, in northeast North Dakota, has not drained into the Red River basin for more than 1,000 years, leading to fears by Canadian officials that mixing waters could introduce striped bass and microscopic species into Canadian waters, particularly Lake Winnipeg. Lake Winnipeg has no natural predators for unforeseen species, Canada has argued, and the diversion could spoil a fishing industry that generates $20 million a year in income.

Title: Under Trump, E.P.A. Has Slowed Actions Against Polluters, and Put Limits on Enforcement Officers
Abstrace: An analysis of enforcement data at the E.P.A. shows a substantial drop in activity against polluters when compared with the Obama and Bush administrations.

Title: Signs of Baby Steps on Stanching Wasteful Flaring of Natural Gas
Abstrace: Signs of progress on wasteful, warming flaring of natural gas in America’s Bakken oil patch.

Title: Power Imbalance at the Pipeline Protest
Abstrace: President Obama could step in to protect everyone’s safety and pressure the sheriff’s officers to stand down in North Dakota.

Title: Roadside Invader: Engineered Canola
Abstrace: Critics of biotech crops might conceivably point to the canola phenomenon as an example of how hard it is to stop the spread of “gene pollution.’’

Title: Links, If You’re So Inclined
Abstrace: Your reading roundup for the week.

Title: Hell From High Water
Abstrace: Op-Ed article by Frank McKenna, Canadian ambassador to United States, objects to North Dakota's plans to open outlet that will let Devils Lake water travel into Sheyenne River and on into Red River, which flows north into Canada; says from there water will eventually stream into Lake Winnipeg and Hudson Bay watershed; says because Devils Lake is closed ecological system, its salty waters have high concentrations of minerals that could cause severe digestive distress if consumed and could be lethal to aquatic life; says North Dakota's plan would pollute Canada; map; drawing (M)

Title: Fracking Firms Fail, Rewarding Executives and Raising Climate Fears
Abstrace: Oil and gas companies are hurtling toward bankruptcy, raising fears that wells will be left leaking planet-warming pollutants, with cleanup costs left to taxpayers.

Title: As Listener and Saleswoman, E.P.A. Chief Takes to the Road for Climate Rules
Abstrace: On trips that are both listening tour and sales pitch, Gina McCarthy, the E.P.A. administrator, is trying to counter a fight against planned rules limiting emissions by power plants.

Title: The Real-World Costs of the Digital Race for Bitcoin
Abstrace: Bitcoin mines cash in on electricity — by devouring it, selling it, even turning it off — and they cause immense pollution. In many cases, the public pays a price.

Title: What Are Donald Trump’s Views on Climate Change? Some Clues Emerge
Abstrace: Mr. Trump has mostly expressed his opinions on climate change and energy policy through Twitter messages. But more of his views are starting to emerge.

Title: Water Everywhere, but Is It Good for Fish?
Abstrace: Manitoba, Canada, fears invasion of alien species and micro-organisms will ruin fishing on Lake Winnipeg if North Dakota drains Devils Lake water through Red River of the North system; two water systems have not been connected for 1,000 years; Devils Lake has risen 27 feet since 1993 because of rain, causing floods and $400 million in damage; North Dakota has been frustrated by lack of progress between US and Canada and has forced issued by beginning work on unfiltered drainage system, to be ready by May 2005; case may set precedent for handling growing number of cases affecting boundary waters; photos; map (M)

Title: Citing Climate Change, Obama Rejects Construction of Keystone XL Oil Pipeline
Abstrace: The president’s decision was a major victory for environmentalists and a bitter loss for the oil industry.

Title: June 9-15
Abstrace: BISHOPS' NEW POLICY At a meeting in Dallas prompted by the pedophilia scandal, America's Roman Catholic bishops adopted a policy on abusive priests: any priest known to have abused a child, no matter when, will not be allowed to dress in clerical garb or say Mass in any public setting, be it in church, school, a nursing home or a hospital. And the bishops, some of whom have been harshly criticized for covering up for predator priests, adopted a broad definition of sexual abuse that includes situations that do not involve force or even physical contact. Catholic reaction included satisfaction, disappointment, and concerns that the measures would pit bishops against priests and that the policy is too harsh for a church built on the concepts of forgiveness and redemption. It is unclear how the bishops' decisions will be received in the Vatican. America and the Vatican, Page 1. WHERE THERE'S A WILL The legislative fight over the repeal of the inheritance tax that began with last year's adoption of $1.35 trillion in tax cuts was put to rest in the Senate. Republicans were able to muster only 54 of the 60 votes they needed to permanently rescind what they call the death tax, but they promised the issue would live on in Congressional races this fall.   Carl Hulse DOCTORS' ORDERS The grueling schedule that many doctors go through to train as specialists is about to ease. The Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education said that in July 2003, it will impose — and enforce — strict new rules that limit to 80 hours the work week of such doctors, known as residents. The rules, intended in part to reduce the risk of dangerous errors by sleep-deprived residents, will require at least 10 hours of rest between shifts and restrict duty to no more than 24 hours at a time.   Lawrence K. Altman BUSINESS ANDERSEN VERDICT After a complex criminal trial that lasted almost six weeks, a Federal District Court jury in Houston yesterday fo

Title: With Unresolved Health Risks and Few Signs of an Economic Boon, Cuomo to Ban Gas Fracking
Abstrace: A look at the mix of economic, political and environmental factors that prompted Gov. Cuomo to bar fracking.

Title: In North Dakota, Flames of Wasted Natural Gas Light the Prairie
Abstrace: About 30 percent of the natural gas produced in North Dakota is burned as waste, an amount that no other domestic oil field comes close to.

Title: Larry Woiwode, Who Wrote of Family, Faith and Rural Life, Dies at 80
Abstrace: Raised in North Dakota and rural Illinois, he was a literary star in New York City in the 1970s. But he left the limelight to raise a family on a North Dakota farm.

Title: Old Treaties and New Alliances Empower Native Americans
Abstrace: Tribes have aligned to assert their government pacts and to demand management rights over government land in the United States and Canada.

Title: Prairie Farmers Reap Conservation's Rewards
Abstrace: Federal subsidies for leaving land for habitat for ducks are helping farmers to survive on Dakota plains; annual payments are keeping small farms afloat, allowing young farmers to establish themselves and has ensured revival of North American duck population that decade ago was in serious decline; region, which stretches through Dakotas into eastern Montana, is primary exhibit for lawmakers promoting more subsidies for conservation and less for traditional row crops; North Dakota has become prime venue for viewing unrecognized debate over $171 billion farm bill, namely, spending to conserve open spaces, fields, ranges and pastures, rather than subsidies for traditional crops; many of large farmers, backed by powerful agribusiness lobbies, oppose increases for conservation programs, presaging big fight in coming weeks as House and Senate debate different approaches; in last five years, conservation programs have fallen to 9 percent of all farm subsidies from 30 percent of payments; map; photos (M)

Title: The Downside of the Boom
Abstrace: North Dakota took on the oversight of a multibillion-dollar oil industry with a regulatory system built on trust, warnings and second chances.

Title: Gas Prices Surge as Supply Drops
Abstrace: Gasoline lines reappear in some corners of United States for first time since 1970's, three days after Hurricane Katrina deals devastating blow to nation's largest energy hub; gasoline prices surge well above $3 a gallon after sudden drop in oil supplies; shortages and gasoline lines are reported in parts of South Carolina, Dakotas, Arkansas and Kentucky; White House says it would release oil from nation's emergency stockpiles to meet shortages and would relax environmental standards nationwide so refiners could produce more--but dirtier--gasoline; analysts do not expect such moves to produce much gasoline in short term or bring prices down anytime soon; they see problem not in any immediate shortage of crude oil but rather in fact that crucial oil product pipelines and refineries in gulf region are unable to operate; photo (M)

Title: In North Dakota, a Tale of Oil, Corruption and Death
Abstrace: Tex G. Hall, a tribal chief connected to the oil industry, has pushed profits on the Fort Berthold Reservation. But accusations of corruption and murder for hire have upended business as usual.

Title: Where Oil and Politics Mix
Abstrace: After an unusual land deal, a giant spill and a tanker-train explosion, anxiety began to ripple across the North Dakota prairie.

Title: Oil Drills and Spills
Abstrace: Readers discuss the environmental damage in North Dakota from oil extraction.

Title: 9 Northeast States File Suit Over New Rules on Pollution
Abstrace: Nine Northastern states file legal challenge to new air-pollution rules for power plants and other industries just hours after Bush administration publishes rules; say rules constitute most serious effort at rolling back landmark Clean Air Act since it was enacted more than 30 years ago; changes would allow thousands of aging coal-fired power plants and other industrial sites to upgrade without having to install costly anti-pollution devices (M)

Title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Ford Focus PZEV; A Stealthy Operative In the War on Pollution
Abstrace: Behind the Wheel column assesses Ford Focus PZEV, which meets emissions standards in California, Maine, Massachusetts, New York and Vermont; chart compares so-called clean cars; photo (M)

Title: Eastern States Introduce a Plan to Cap Tailpipe Pollution
Abstrace: Twelve states and the District of Columbia released a draft plan for an ambitious cap-and-trade program to curb planet-warming emissions on the region’s roads.

Title: New England’s River of Change
Abstrace: In the last 30 years, the Blackstone River has shrugged off centuries of pollution.

Title: States Sue E.P.A. Over Delayed Soot Rules
Abstrace: Eleven states argue that drafting new rules is vital to public health. But the Obama administration faces pressure from Republican critics who say that tighter air pollution rules could hurt the economy.

Title: Court Backs Most E.P.A. Action On Polluters in Central States
Abstrace: Federal appeals court, 3-0, mostly upholds Environmental Protection Agency crackdown on nitrogen oxide emissions from 392 Midwestern and Southern factories and power plants; sends two sections of rule back to EPA for more work; Connecticut, Massachusetts, New York and Pennsylvania sought crackdown on upwind polluters (M)

Title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Shellfish Ban Extended
Abstrace: Massachsuetts shellfish biologist J Michael Hickey says shellfish beds will remain closed for at least another month because of red tide, toxic algae (S)

Title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Shellfishing Disaster Claim Denied
Abstrace: Federal Emergency Management Agency decides that outbreak of red tide in shellfish beds of Massachusetts does not qualify as disaster, which would have allowed shellfishermen to qualify for federal unemployment benefits (S)

Title: National Briefing | Washington: 3 States Plan To Sue E.P.A.
Abstrace: Attorneys general of Connecticut, Massachusetts and Maine will sue EPA to force agency to restrict carbon dioxide as 'criteria pollutant' under terms of Clean Air Act (S)

Title: Pressure Grows for Answers on Fracking
Abstrace: Congressional Democrats demand answers about the safety of hydraulic fracturing after revelations that wastewater from such drilling is regularly dumped into rivers and streams without proper treatment.

Title: A Better CO2 Rule
Abstrace: Susan Tierney Op-Ed article focuses on outpouring of criticism of Pres Bush since repudiating campaign promise to battle global warming by regulating carbon dioxide; says Bush should look to Massachusetts for way to address environmental issue without compromising concerns about energy supply and costs; notes state is requiring six of its major fossil fuel power plants to meet stringent new air pollution standards by 2008 that cover major pollutants that cause acid rain, smog and soot--as well as carbon dioxide (S)

Title: Volkswagen Scandal Reaches All the Way to the Top, Lawsuits Say
Abstrace: The suits claim the decision to thwart pollution tests involved dozens of engineers and managers, and reached into the company’s boardroom.

Title: Electric Cars May Lose Push In Northeast
Abstrace: New York, Massachusetts and Vermont may postpone until 2007 requirement that electric cars be sold, and may promote use of other emission-reduction technologies instead; state officials claim change could actually produce deeper cut in tailpipe pollution in first few years, while giving car companies needed flexibility; environmental groups question that claim and say retreat by Northeast states would damage efforts to make electric cars commonplace and economicaly viable; move leaves California as only state requiring sales of electric cars over next several years, cutting market for them in half; New York's environmental conservation commissioner, Erin Crotty, says postponing electric car mandate is state's recognition that automakers are not yet ready to produce them; automakers have said they would be unable to make commercially viable electric cars in time to meet California mandate that begins with 2003 model year (M)

Title: E.P.A. Sued Over Mercury in the Air
Abstrace: New Jersey and eight other states file lawsuit challenging Environmental Protection Agency rule that they claim does not do enough to control dangerous mercury emissions from coal-fired power plants (M)

Title: A Plan by Eastern States to Cap Tailpipe Emissions Gets Off to a Slow Start
Abstrace: Connecticut, Massachusetts, Rhode Island and Washington, D.C., all announced they would join a cap-and-trade program for cars and trucks. But many bigger states have yet to join.

Title: Massachusetts: Buyer Found for Wind Farm’s Energy
Abstrace: National Grid, will buy half the output of Cape Wind, which if built would be the nation’s first offshore wind farm.

Title: 3 States Sue E.P.A. to Regulate Emissions of Carbon Dioxide
Abstrace: Connecticut, Maine and Massachusetts sue Environmental Protection Agency, contending that carbon dioxide emissions from cars and power plants should be regulated as air pollutant because they contribute to global warming; officials say it is first time that any state has sued government to compel action on climate change (M)

Title: Mayors Seek Regional Plan on Power Plant Gas Emissions
Abstrace: The mayors of more than 40 cities in the Northeast have urged the governors of New York and eight other states to quickly adopt a regional plan to regulate greenhouse gases that contribute to global warming, saying in a letter yesterday that climate change ''poses significant threat to the people and communities of the Northeast.''      Officials in the nine states released a general outline of the plan, called the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative. While state officials have given it preliminary approval, some specifics are still unresolved, especially those involving the eventual cost to consumers. They need to be ironed out before the plan can go back to the individual states for legislative or regulatory approval, a process that could begin early next year.

Title: Trying to Salvage His Climate Agenda, Biden Weighs Remaining Options
Abstrace: With his legislative plan for global warming in shreds, the president has come under pressure to use all other tools at his disposal.

Title: National Briefing: New England
Abstrace: MAINE: Tough Penalties For 2 Fish Farms; MASSACHUSETTS: Clinton Backs Third Term;.

Title: Massachusetts Sets Ambitious Energy Standards
Abstrace: Massachusetts state officials on Friday announced new energy efficiency standards for utilities that aim to be the most ambitious of any in the nation.

Title: 9 States in Plan to Cut Emissions by Power Plants
Abstrace: Nine Northeastern states reportedly reach preliminary agreement to freeze power plant emissions at current levels and then reduce them by ten percent by 2020; photo; first such cooperative action follows Bush administration not to regulate greenhouse gases and would require legislation in each state; initiative would set up market-driven system to control carbon dioxide emissions from more than 600 electric generators, and could spur action nationally; California, Washington and Oregon explore similar agreement; Northeast states were brought together by New York Gov George Pataki, who broke sharply with administration on issue; spokesman declines comment on leaked draft; environmentalists say region's carbon dioxide emissions are about those of Germany, but that real significance of accord is example for other states (M)

Title: Much Heat and Deep Split Over a Cape Cod Wind Farm
Abstrace: Four formal hearings are held on proposal to install giant wind farm in offshore waters south of Cape Cod; plans call for 130 turbines in 24-square-mile grid off Cape; consensus appears to be as far away as ever, with advocates and opponents deeply divided on project and vast majority still ambivalent; map (M)

Title: OBSERVATORY
Abstrace: Dr Lawrence M Hanks, entomologist at University of Illinois, discovers first example of insect hibernation causing plant chemistry to be altered so male wasps can find females using sense of smell; recent study by Woods Hole Oceanographic Institute reports petroleum hydrocarbons found in Buzzards Bay, Massachusetts, 31 years after oil spill, remain in same concentration as immediately after accident, demonstrating truly catastrophic nature of oil spills; Antarctica's Cape Crozier penguin colony is disrupted by two icebergs crashing into shore; ice blocks parents from getting adequate food for their young and large colony has split into smaller groups; cartoon (M)

Title: Justices to Decide Merits of Global Warming Petition
Abstrace: Supreme Court will hear oral arguments on questions of whether federal government, particularly Environmental Protection Agency, is authorized and obligated to take action to ease global warming; Massachusetts, which has been joined by 11 other states, 3 cities and 13 environmental groups, will argue that federal agency has shirked its legal responsibility to protect public and ignored requirements of Clean Air Act; federal lawyers, in tandem with those of automobile industry, argue that existing law is inadequate to support far-reaching regulation and that Congress or foreign policy arena, or both, are appropriate places to produce new domestic global warming policies (M)

Title: Romney Shifted Right on Energy as Presidential Politics Beckoned
Abstrace: Mitt Romney is more apt today to talk about his support for oil drilling than about the environmental policies that he advocated while governor of Massachusetts.

Title: States Plan Suit to Prod U.S. on Global Warming
Abstrace: California plans to sue Environmental Protection Agency over Bush administration's recent decision that agency lacked authority to regulate greenhouse gas emissions from tailpipes and other sources; nine other states, including New York, Massachusetts and Oregon, as well as environmental groups like Sierra Club and Natural Resources Defense Council, are expected to join suit; legal strategy, effort to prod federal action on global warming, sets up battle between Bush administration and states over policy on climate change; California suit is also seen as effort to stave off challenges to state's plan to regulate automotive emissions of greenhouse gases; Gov Gray Davis says issue is vital to future of state; EPA spokesman Mark Merchant comments (M)

Title: A Heavy Toll From Disease Fuels Suspicion and Anger
Abstrace: A federal study could reveal whether pollution caused a cluster of cases of Lou Gehrig’s disease centered around a downtown industrial area in Middleborough, Mass.

Title: Auto Emission Rules in California Are Forcing Changes
Abstrace: California's decade-old mandate to create zero-emission vehicles could soon force auto makers to sell more than 100,000 electric cars and other fuel-efficient vehicles in state each year; companies are spending billions of dollars developing technologies to cut harmful tailpipe emissions and are starting to promote and sell electric vehicles; New York and Massachusetts plan their own versions of mandate, and if they are put into effect, almost one-fifth of American auto market would be convered by mandate; photo (M)

Title: Helping Out, 794 Species at a Time
Abstrace: Drs Walter A Neves and Mark Hubbe of University of Sao Paulo examine 81 skulls found in central Brazil and confirm that 7,000-to 12,000-year-old skulls are similar to Australian-Melanesian peoples; research, which is published in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, suggests that people from South Pacific region may have migrated to South America using same route as Asian peoples found in North America; Chalmers University of Technology, Sweden, researchers find elevated levels of platinum and similar metals in Boston air samples; hold that they are byproducts of catalytic converters; research described in journal Environmental Science and Technology; coalition of conservation groups, led by Dr Taylor H Ricketts of World Wildlife Fund, compiles list of 595 places and 794 endangered species believed to be on brink of extinction; species designated on list are found at only one location in world; map (M)

Title: State Governments Overreach in Taking on Problems Best Solved at the National Level
Abstrace: Robert H Frank Economic Scene column on state and local governments in United States governing issues of public policy that should be handled on national level; Massachusetts becomes first state to enact legislation to ensure that all citizens have access to health care; at least 19 other states are considering similar legislation; eight states adopt new rules similar to those implemented by California Air Resources Board calling for 30 percent reduction in carbon dioxide emissions; Maryland becomes fifth state to authorize spending for basic stem cell research; proposal in Ithaca, NY, calls for local income tax to finance single-payer health care system for local residents (M)

Title: Celebrating A River's Artful Revival
Abstrace: Article on day trips to events this summer celebrating revival of upper Housatonic River between Pittsfield, Mass, and New Milford, Conn; photo (M)

Title: California Adopts Plan for Electric Cars
Abstrace: California Air Resources Board approves scaled-down plan requiring that 2 percent of cars offered for sale in state by major manufacturers be battery-powered starting in 2003; board's decision, made over last-minute objections by automobile companies, is exected to lead to adoption of similar plans in New York, Massachusets and Vermont; auto industry representatives cautioned against encouraging shift to electric cars during power shortage (M)

Title: New Emails Show How Energy Industry Moved Fast to Undo Curbs
Abstrace: The messages, made public in a lawsuit, suggest the E.P.A. rescinded a requirement on methane at the behest of an executive just weeks after President Trump took office.

Title: Voter Group Flexes Muscle in Ads Aimed at Senators
Abstrace: The League of Women Voters, known for candidate debates and voter guides, took a more activist approach in ads aimed at two senators facing elections next year.

Title: National Briefing
Abstrace: WEST

Title: Romney Defends Massachusetts Health Plan, but Concedes Flaws
Abstrace: Mitt Romney addressed the health care law he once championed in his own home state by calling for a repeal of the health care law President Obama signed last year.

Title: Obama Weighs Paring Goals for Health Bill
Abstrace: With Democrats reeling from a Senate loss in Massachusetts, President Obama signaled that he might be willing to set aside his goal of achieving near-universal health care.

Title: Gay Marriage Opponents Keep Low Profile for Now
Abstrace: Main opponents of same-sex marriage in Massachusetts, most of them conservative Christians, say they plan to keep quiet and stay out of way as gay people begin celebrating their first marriages; say they will distance themselves from any unseemly or violent protests, but will keep up fight for amendments to both state and federal constitutions banning practice; photo (M)

Title: Where ‘Made in America’ Made Its Debut
Abstrace: With its tree-lined shores and trout-filled waters, central New England’s Blackstone River shrugs off its grimy past as a major player in the American Industrial Revolution.

Title: Several States Likely to Follow California on Car Emissions
Abstrace: California's plan for sharp cuts in automotive emissions of global warming gases could eventually lead much of coastal US to turn to vehicles that are substantially cleaner, and by extension more fuel efficient, than those in rest of nation; New Jersey, Rhode Island and Connecticut have said they intend to start following California's car rules instead of those of federal government; New York, Massachusetts, Vermont and Maine already do so; photo (M)

Title: Some Noise Relief for Concord (and Its History)
Abstrace: National Trust for Historic Preservation names Minute Man National Historical Park and its environs in Massachusetts among 11 most endangered historic places in United States; airplane noise from nearby Hanscom Field has been subject of long battle, with preservationists saying it is taking toll on park and other historic sites in Lexington, Lincoln and Concord area; designation provides no money, but has potential to earn national attention and can galvanize public pressure; map of historic sites in Concord area; map of National Trust's 11 most endangered places; photo (M)

Title: That Light in Yonder Sky Is Running Up a Huge Bill
Abstrace: Article on nighttime bus trip through Bright Nights Festival holiday light show in Forest Park in Springfield, Mass; photos (M)

Title: The Not-So United States
Abstrace: Pam Belluck article notes that states like Massachusetts and South Dakota are proceeding on their own on issues like health care, abortion and gay marriage, and discusses whether America is destined to balkanize into patchwork of polar-opposite policies; map; photos (M)

Title: Offshore Harvest of Wind Is Proposed for Cape Cod
Abstrace: Article on plan by Cape Wind Associates, joint venture between Energy Management Inc and Wind Management Inc, to build array of 170 slender turbines in Nantucket Sound that it says would generate nearly half of electrical supply for Cape Cod, Martha's Vineyard and Nantucket; critics say turbines would disturb birds, harm fisheries and scare away tourists; maps; graph; drawing; photo (M)

Title: Rising Seas
Abstrace: Some areas of the globe are especially vulnerable to rising sea levels and inhabitants are being forced to make stark changes in their lives.

Title: Redrawing the Electric Power Grid
Abstrace: Central issue in power industry and among alternative power advocates is how best to eliminate bottlenecks in transmission grid: by building more long-distance transmission lines or by generating more power in small quantities close to where it is needed; aging transmission grid prevents much of power from flowing easily into areas where it is most needed during summer consumption spikes; traditional solution--to build more and bigger transmission lines--has few fans outside industry; many utility executives and regulators believe building more long-distance transmission lines and finding alternatives to long-distance transmission are both necessary; United Technologies is developing fuel cells and wants to adapt them to use with other local forms of power generation; chairman-chief executive George David comments; how Connecticut Valley Electric Exchange, or Convex, tracks movement of power in Connecticut and western Massachusetts discussed; photos (M)

Title: New England’s Forests Are Sick. They Need More Tree Doctors.
Abstrace: Climate change is taking a toll on woodlands in the Northeast.

Title: America’s Disaster Recovery System Is a Disaster
Abstrace: The help Americans receive after disasters isn’t just inadequate; it’s complicated to navigate and painfully slow to arrive.

Title: U.S. Fines Mine Owner $20 Million for Pollution
Abstrace: The nation’s fourth-largest coal producer, the Massey Energy Company, was fined $20 million for a pollution violation under the Clean Water Act.

Title: National Briefing | South: Governors Discuss Pollution Reduction
Abstrace: Four Southeastern governors meet with environmentalists and agree to work to curb pollution in Great Smoky Mountains (S)

Title: National Briefing | Washington: Government Sues Coal Plant
Abstrace: Justice Dept files civil lawsuit contending that East Kentucky Power Cooperative did not comply with clean-air rule that typically requires coal-burning power plants to make pollution-control upgrades after major modernization projects (S)

Title: Clean Mining a Deception in Kentucky, Groups Say
Abstrace: Environmental activists are again accusing the coal company Frasure Creek Mining of simply duplicating pollution reports to steer clear of regulators.

Title: New Strategy on Clean Air
Abstrace: Editorial holds that erosion of nation's clean air laws under Bush administration has inspired North Carolina Atty Gen Roy Cooper to adopt unusual legal strategy to force out-of-state power plants to stop sending air pollution into his state; notes that Cooper asked federal court to order Tennessee Valley Authority to install up-to-date emissions controls in 11 power plants in Alabama, Tennessee and Kentucky; maintains that some legal experts give Cooper's unorthodox strategy good chance, and this suggests that TVA would do well to reach amicable agreement

Title: Fighting the Whiskey Fungus
Abstrace: Melena Ryzik talks to residents around Louisville, Ky., who filed a lawsuit to stem the growth of a black mold that was recently linked to whiskey production.

Title: Coal Firm to Pay Record Penalty and Spend Millions on Water Cleanup in 5 States
Abstrace: Alpha Natural Resources and 66 of its subsidiaries agreed to reduce pollution from coal mines in Kentucky, Pennsylvania, Tennessee, Virginia and West Virginia.

Title: National Briefing: South
Abstrace: KENTUCKY: Waste Taints Streams; FLORIDA: Pollution Tax Applies To All.

Title: Mitch McConnell’s Drive to Keep the Coal Fires Burning
Abstrace: The Senate majority leader calls the Obama administration’s pending emissions regulations a “war on coal.”

Title: My Polluted Kentucky Home
Abstrace: Mountaintop removal ruins lives as well as the environment.

Title: A.E.P. Backs Down on Coal Plant Retrofit
Abstrace: American Electric Power withdrew its application to refit Big Sandy, a plant in eastern Kentucky, with pollution controls.

Title: A Push Away From Burning Coal as an Energy Source
Abstrace: The Tennessee Valley Authority planned to close a total of eight electricity-generating units at three plants in Alabama and Kentucky, significantly cutting the emissions of greenhouse gases.

Title: Appalachia’s Sacrifice
Abstrace: We give the country cheap energy. We get poisoned water in return.

Title: Though Not Quietly, Kentucky Moves to Cut Reliance on Coal
Abstrace: Despite cries of a “war on coal” that echo through mining country in eastern Kentucky, the region is already taking hardheaded steps toward a post-coal economy.

Title: Republicans Vow to Fight E.P.A. and Approve Keystone Pipeline
Abstrace: Republicans aim to use their new powers to subvert regulations aimed at curbing carbon pollution. They also see greater leverage in pushing President Obama to approve the Keystone XL pipeline.

Title: In Debate Over Coal, Looking to Lessons of ’90s Tobacco Fight
Abstrace: The so-called War on Coal is reminiscent of the War on Tobacco, in which a truce took hold in large part because the states dependent on the product were compensated.

Title: Obama Adviser During Recession Is Given New Challenge: Climate Change
Abstrace: As a senior adviser on climate policy, Brian Deese is pushing the president’s environmental agenda to governors while under attack by Congress and a hostile coal industry.

Title: Even in Coal Country, the Fight for an Industry
Abstrace: With the coal industry under siege across the country, an announcement that the operator of the Big Sandy power plant near Louisa, Ky., planned to switch to natural gas prompted an uproar.

Title: Retired Coal Miners Losing Their Safety Net
Abstrace: Mitch McConnell should help retirees who worked in a dangerous industry and deserve what was promised by contract.

Title: Bluegrass Blues
Abstrace: Horse racing and coal mining are linked in a deadly circle in Kentucky. And the turf on this track is the bluegrass itself.

Title: Humble Paddlefish Fulfills Southerners' Caviar Dreams
Abstrace: Domestic caviar accounts for 60 percent of American market and Lewis Shuckman is one of several southern fishermen and seafood sellers in Missouri, Arkansas, Kentucky, Georgia and Tennessee who have carved out places for themselves peddling paddlefish roe; roe sells for $10 to $20 per ounce compared with $50 for least expensive imports; seafood industry newsletter The Wave says it is among fastest growing sectors of seafood market as it gains wider acceptance; converts say taste is similar to more expensive Russian caviar, term which is reserved only for roe from sturgeon; Armen Petrossian, president of International Caviar Importers Assn in Paris, disdains paddlefish, but some caviar snobs are easily fooled; photos; chart compares caviar with paddlefish roe (L)

Title: Bluegrass Blues
Abstrace: Author Bobbie Ann Mason Op-Ed article holds that with Barbaro's injury and five coal-mining deaths all on same day, this spring has been time for soul-searching in Kentucky; says horse racing and coal mining are linked in deadly circle, and Kentucky-born Barbaro's fragile bones may be omen; notes that Lexington is adding more than 1,700 houses a year, and bluegrass is already disappearing; photo (M)

Title: Coal, an Outlaw Enterprise
Abstrace: The outsize influence and campaign donations of King Coal subvert democracy in Appalachia.

Title: Kentuckians Take Distilleries to Court Over Black Gunk
Abstrace: A class-action lawsuit takes aim at five bourbon distilleries in and around Louisville, where a tenacious black mold that feeds on ethanol blankets properties nearby.

Title: Democrats in Coal Country Run From E.P.A.
Abstrace: President Obama’s proposal to cut emissions from coal-fired power plants could become a key election issue in some battleground states.

Title: For Manufacturers, a Complex Mix Can Determine Location
Abstrace: While rural areas offer manufacturers some advantages, they can no longer count on lower salaries for workers or finding employees with the skills they need.

Title: Kentucky Challenger Sets Sights on Senate G.O.P. Heavyweight
Abstrace: Democrats are coalescing around Alison Lundergan Grimes, Kentucky’s secretary of state, who is seeking to unseat Mitch McConnell, the Senate minority leader.

Title: How Did Democrats Lose Control of State Agriculture Policy?
Abstrace: Democrats once dominated statewide elections for the influential post of agriculture commissioner. Now they’re hoping to win just one.

Title: A Park in Kentucky That Shines Brightest Below Ground
Abstrace: Mammoth Cave National Park, one of the largest underground systems in the country, contains as much local history as it does natural history.

Title: In Praise Of Follies
Abstrace: Douglas Brenner article on late Clay Lancaster, pioneering historian of American architecture and founding father of historic preservation; describes Lancaster's home in his native Kentucky, where original 1811 house sits comfortably with Lancaster's eccentric additions; photos (special section, Home Design) (part 2 of 2-part section) (M)

Title: Gas Prices Surge as Supply Drops
Abstrace: Gasoline lines reappear in some corners of United States for first time since 1970's, three days after Hurricane Katrina deals devastating blow to nation's largest energy hub; gasoline prices surge well above $3 a gallon after sudden drop in oil supplies; shortages and gasoline lines are reported in parts of South Carolina, Dakotas, Arkansas and Kentucky; White House says it would release oil from nation's emergency stockpiles to meet shortages and would relax environmental standards nationwide so refiners could produce more--but dirtier--gasoline; analysts do not expect such moves to produce much gasoline in short term or bring prices down anytime soon; they see problem not in any immediate shortage of crude oil but rather in fact that crucial oil product pipelines and refineries in gulf region are unable to operate; photo (M)

Title: Obama’s Remarks in Des Moines
Abstrace: The following is a transcript of Senator Barack Obama’s remarks to supporters on the night of the Kentucky and Oregon primaries, as provided by CQ Transcriptions.

Title: ‘The Coal Industry Is Back,’ Trump Proclaimed. It Wasn’t.
Abstrace: The demise of coal-fired power plants in Arizona and Kentucky shows how the president, despite promises to restore jobs, failed to counter the forces decimating the industry.

Title: A Nobel Laureate’s View of a Senator’s Energy Choices
Abstrace: Burton Richter, a Nobel laureate, urges Senator Mitch McConnell to look out for the interests of both his state and his country.

Title: National Briefing | South: Governors Discuss Pollution Reduction
Abstrace: Four Southeastern governors meet with environmentalists and agree to work to curb pollution in Great Smoky Mountains (S)

Title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Embattled Road Projects Approved
Abstrace: Federal judge approves $400 million worth of road projects for Atlanta area, ruling against environmentalists who had blocked construction since 1998, concerned about air pollution (S)0

Title: Georgia Judge Cites Carbon Dioxide in Denying Coal Plant Permit
Abstrace: Both opponents of coal use and the company that wants to build the plant said it was the first time a court decision had linked carbon dioxide to an air pollution permit.

Title: ENGELHARD TO REDUCE OPERATIONS IN GEORGIA
Abstrace: Engelhard Corp, maker of pollution-control devices for autos, will consolidate its manufacturing operations in Georgia to cut costs; change will reduce number of workers and result in fourth-quarter expense of $1.5 million for severance payments (S)

Title: ENGELHARD WILL ELIMINATE JOBS AND TAKE A CHARGE
Abstrace: Engelhard Corp, maker of catalysts that reduce emissions from vehicles and industrial processes, will cut 200 jobs, mostly in Georgia, as part of plan to increase its petroleum-refining catalyst business (S)

Title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Court Orders Review Of Power Plan
Abstrace: US Court of Appeals issues decision on whether power company that violates Clean Air Act can receive permit to build new plant; Sierra Club had filed suit in Georgia (S)

Title: A Plea for Southern Treasures
Abstrace: From highway construction to mountaintop mining to pollution runoff, a group documents threats to mountains, waterways and forests.

Title: After a Giant Ship Goes Belly Up, Many Fear a Shoreline Is Next
Abstrace: The 656-foot vessel started capsizing in September, stirring concerns about the pollution creeping into the waterways.

Title: Collapse of Atlanta Talks Keeps Road Builders Idle
Abstrace: Tentative accord between environmental groups and Georgia on reducing air pollution that would have allow road building to resume in Atlanta area after two years of legal delays collapses over environmentalists insistence on court supervision to ensure state compliance; accord was aimed at ending cutoff of federal highway money for 13 metropolitan area counties; map (M)

Title: National Briefing
Abstrace: WEST</b

Title: How an Electric Truck Factory Became a Lightning Rod in Georgia
Abstrace: The governor hailed the factory as an economic boon that would put Georgia at the vanguard of the green economy. Not everyone liked the idea.

Title: Swarms of Dying Mayflies Bring Good News
Abstrace: School and government officials say wave of immigrants over past 10 years, particularly in rural areas far from traditional immigrant hubs, has left school districts nationwide desperately short of people qualified to teach them English; number of students with limited English skills, most Hispanic, has doubled to five million in last decade, or more than four times rate for general student population; number of qualified teachers for English-as-a-second-language classes, already in chronic short supply, has not kept pace; estimated 50,000 such teachers exist, or one for every 100 students with limited English skills; demand for them has grown most rapidly in school districts in South, Midwest and Northwest; North Carolina has had fastest growth, with number quintupling from 1993, to 52,500 from 8,900; populations of such students in Idaho, Nebraska, Alabama, Tennessee, South Carolina and Georgia have at least tripled since 1993; map; photos (L)

Title: Algae Can Poison Your Dog
Abstrace: Dogs have become fatally ill after frolicking in water infused with the toxic algae, owners said.

Title: Pruitt Is Wrong on Burning Forests for Energy
Abstrace: Doing so will worsen the consequences of climate change.

Title: Overcoming a Taboo, Buses Will Now Serve Suburban Atlanta
Abstrace: Ten suburban Atlanta counties agree to join regional bus system for first time, after three decades of essentially refusing to join debate about how to deal with loss of mobility and fresh air caused by their swift growth; until now they shunned any regional solutions; chairman of Atlanta's transit authority said in 1987 that race was the issue: fear that black people from Atlanta would take buses to mostly white suburban regions; photo (M)

Title: Drive Carts, Not Cars
Abstrace: In Peachtree City, Ga., whether they golf or not, people go for carts.

Title: National Briefing
Abstrace: NORTHWEST</b

Title: A Mimosa-Flavored Limoncello Recipe, Straight Out of Georgia
Abstrace: In this series, the photographer Rinne Allen documents harvests across the South, exploring the many uses of nature’s seasonal yield.

Title: Florida’s Vulnerability Tested as Hurricane Matthew Hugs Coast
Abstrace: Hurricane Matthew will test Floridians’ level of “disaster amnesia” given the 11 years that have passed since the state was struck by a major hurricane.

Title: Humble Paddlefish Fulfills Southerners' Caviar Dreams
Abstrace: Domestic caviar accounts for 60 percent of American market and Lewis Shuckman is one of several southern fishermen and seafood sellers in Missouri, Arkansas, Kentucky, Georgia and Tennessee who have carved out places for themselves peddling paddlefish roe; roe sells for $10 to $20 per ounce compared with $50 for least expensive imports; seafood industry newsletter The Wave says it is among fastest growing sectors of seafood market as it gains wider acceptance; converts say taste is similar to more expensive Russian caviar, term which is reserved only for roe from sturgeon; Armen Petrossian, president of International Caviar Importers Assn in Paris, disdains paddlefish, but some caviar snobs are easily fooled; photos; chart compares caviar with paddlefish roe (L)

Title: When Calling an Uber Can Pay Off for Cities and States
Abstrace: New taxes and fees on ride-hailing services have raised millions of dollars for transportation, infrastructure and even public schools.

Title: Amid Campaign Revamp, Herschel Walker Stumps Without a Stumble
Abstrace: After a string of damaging reports, and briefly shunning publicity, the Republican Senate candidate was out on the trail again in rural Georgia.

Title: Not Just the Links Are Green
Abstrace: More golf communities are turning their grounds into eco-friendly spaces.

Title: Jeffrey Clark Was Considered Unassuming. Then He Plotted With Trump.
Abstrace: Justice Department colleagues said they were shocked by Mr. Clark’s embrace of the president’s falsehoods and plan to oust the acting attorney general in an effort to overturn Georgia’s election results.

Title: Behind the Quiet State-by-State Fight Over Electric Vehicles
Abstrace: While the battle in Washington gets much of the attention, the most direct attack against electric vehicles is being waged in statehouses.

Title: Coronavirus Live Updates: Summer Is Coming. Some States Are Reopening. Can We Keep Our Distance?
Abstrace: Nevada is one especially thorny example because of its dependence on tourism. But everywhere, faster and more widespread testing will be vital.

Title: The Unique U.S. Failure to Control the Virus
Abstrace: Slowing the coronavirus has been especially difficult for the United States because of its tradition of prioritizing individualism and missteps by the Trump administration.

Title: Cooking Can Be Deadly
Abstrace: Two chefs discuss lack of access to clean, modern cooking in much of the world, leading to dangerous air pollution from open fires. Also: Georgia’s Senate runoffs.

Title: Sunday Dialogue: Nuclear Energy, Pro and Con
Abstrace: A letter arguing for nuclear power touched off a lively debate among readers. Here is a sampling.

Title: Canadian Wildfire Smoke Reaches New Areas in the Southern U.S.
Abstrace: North Carolina and Georgia reported higher concentrations of smoke in new places.

Title: Utility Cited for Violating Pollution Law in North Carolina
Abstrace: Duke Energy was charged with failing to obtain storm-water permits; it faces a similar action against its plant in Eden, N.C., where 39,000 tons of coal ash fouled the Dan River last month.

Title: A Leader in the War on Poverty Opens a New Front: Pollution
Abstrace: A pastor is resurrecting the Poor People’s Campaign, a movement started by Martin Luther King Jr. He sees the climate and environment as issues on par with poverty and racism.

Title: National Briefing | South: Governors Discuss Pollution Reduction
Abstrace: Four Southeastern governors meet with environmentalists and agree to work to curb pollution in Great Smoky Mountains (S)

Title: North Carolina Asks E.P.A. To Force Others to Clean Air
Abstrace: North Carolina petitions Environmental Protection Agency to crack down on pollution that it says is seeping across its borders from power plants in 13 other states; if petition works, states as far away as Michigan would have to cut power plant pollution by more than 50 percent, while states nearer North Carolina would face reductions of 70 percent to 80 percent (M)

Title: Emails Link Duke Energy and North Carolina
Abstrace: Emails indicate that environmental regulators consulted Duke Energy before seeking to exclude citizen activists from talks to settle charges over groundwater pollution.

Title: New Strategy on Clean Air
Abstrace: Editorial holds that erosion of nation's clean air laws under Bush administration has inspired North Carolina Atty Gen Roy Cooper to adopt unusual legal strategy to force out-of-state power plants to stop sending air pollution into his state; notes that Cooper asked federal court to order Tennessee Valley Authority to install up-to-date emissions controls in 11 power plants in Alabama, Tennessee and Kentucky; maintains that some legal experts give Cooper's unorthodox strategy good chance, and this suggests that TVA would do well to reach amicable agreement

Title: North Carolina Floodwaters Breach Dam
Abstrace: Flooding in the aftermath of Hurricane Florence has led to the shutdown of the L.V. Sutton plant, spilling toxic coal ash into the nearby Cape Fear River.

Title: Duke Energy to Pay Fine Over Power Plant Violations
Abstrace: The settlement requires the company, the nation’s largest electric utility, to pay a $975,000 fine and spend $4.4 million on environmental programs.

Title: Regulatory Favoritism in North Carolina
Abstrace: The state’s largest utility gets a wrist slap for coal ash pollution, while federal regulators dawdle.

Title: National Briefing: South
Abstrace: NORTH CAROLINA: Ban On Snakehead Fish; FLORIDA: End To Search Restrictions Sought; COAL PLANTS BLAMED FOR POLLUTION;.

Title: National Briefing: South
Abstrace: NORTH CAROLINA: Widow Accused Of Murder; KENTUCKY: Tax Amnesty; FLORIDA: Pollution Guilty Plea; MISSISSIPPI: Dispute On Prisons;.

Title: Critics Say Clean-Air Plan May Be a Setback for Parks
Abstrace: Lush Appalachian mountains of Tennessee, which Cherokee called land of blue smoke, have famous summertime haze that rises from valleys of Great Smoky Mountains National Park, but air at high elevations today is often more polluted than in cities, as sulfates scatter light and small particles and nitrogen oxide cooks in sun to form ozone pollution; photos; EPA's dual strategy involves interstate drift of pollutants and haze rule requiring states to regulate power plants, with goal of improving air in national parks; environmentalists say plants may gain 14-year free pass on haze if they comply with interstate directives, that EPA approach is regulatory bait-and-switch; Smokies are also threatened by invasive pests, shortage of maintenance funds and proposed highway along northern edge in North Carolina (M)

Title: A Plea for Southern Treasures
Abstrace: From highway construction to mountaintop mining to pollution runoff, a group documents threats to mountains, waterways and forests.

Title: E.P.A. Agrees to Join North Carolina in Reviewing Spill
Abstrace: The federal Environmental Protection Agency will join North Carolina regulators in addressing potential violations of the Clean Water Act at Duke Energy power plants in that state.

Title: North Carolina Says Utility Pumped Millions of Gallons of Wastewater in River
Abstrace: Duke Energy illegally pumped as much as 61 million gallons of coal-ash wastewater into a river from September to last week, North Carolina regulators said.

Title: Questions as More Wastewater Flows in North Carolina
Abstrace: State regulators said Duke Energy, a utility already under a federal investigation for pollution, may have illegally released wastewater last week from a second site near of Raleigh.

Title: North Carolina’s Noxious Pig Farms
Abstrace: Lagoons of animal waste flooded by Hurricane Matthew are a public health danger that may be repeated over and over again.

Title: North Carolina Fines Duke Energy $25.1 Million
Abstrace: State officials say the fine against Duke Energy over coal ash contamination of groundwater is the largest in state history.

Title: Supreme Court Rules in Favor of Electronics Plant in Poisoned Water Case
Abstrace: The decision found that North Carolina landowners who sued CTS Corporation over the poisoning of their drinking water had missed a filing deadline.

Title: Ash Spill Shows How Watchdog Was Defanged
Abstrace: North Carolina regulators say that under Gov. Pat McCrory, a weakened Department of Environment and Natural Resources has abandoned its regulatory role.

Title: A Cancer Cluster Is Tough to Prove
Abstrace: The genetic mutations that cause cancer can take decades to manifest themselves but the laws we cobble together often trump those of science.

Title: Duke Energy Agrees to Pay $102 Million for Breaches
Abstrace: The company pleaded guilty to criminal violations of the federal Clean Water Act in connection with a large coal-ash spill in 2014 and the failure to maintain equipment.

Title: Duke Energy Is Charged in Huge Coal Ash Leak
Abstrace: Federal prosecutors accused the nation’s largest electric utility of violating the federal Clean Water Act in a spill last year in North Carolina.

Title: National Briefing: South

Title: Islands Apart
Abstrace: An unfamiliar but highly appealing side of President Bush showed itself at the White House yesterday. It was Mr. Bush the compassionate conservationist, friend of green sea turtles, seabirds and Hawaiian monk seals, savior of coral reefs and spiny lobsters, creator of the largest ocean sanctuary on the planet.      Mr. Bush has made the Northwestern Hawaiian Islands a national monument, putting them under some of the strictest environmental protections the law provides. It was an act of wilderness preservation that, acre for acre, instantly put him into the same league as the conservation-minded presidents Theodore Roosevelt, Jimmy Carter and Bill Clinton.

Title: Treasure Islands
Abstrace: PRESIDENT Bush is expected to declare the northwestern Hawaiian Islands a national monument today, thereby creating the largest marine reserve on earth. The president's decision caps a century of protection efforts by both Republican and Democratic presidents beginning with Theodore Roosevelt and including Lyndon Johnson, Ronald Reagan and Bill Clinton. But none ever proposed the sweeping level of protection for these islands that is being put in place by the Bush administration.      While we and others in the conservation community have not always agreed with President Bush's environmental policies, we believe it is important to acknowledge a significant policy achievement when it occurs -- and one is about to occur.

A winch lifts the poles until tongs with metal claws open. Mixed in with empty shells, muck and rocks lies the catch: a few dozen Chesapeake oysters.

Title: Mayors Seek Regional Plan on Power Plant Gas Emissions
Abstrace: The mayors of more than 40 cities in the Northeast have urged the governors of New York and eight other states to quickly adopt a regional plan to regulate greenhouse gases that contribute to global warming, saying in a letter yesterday that climate change ''poses significant threat to the people and communities of the Northeast.''      Officials in the nine states released a general outline of the plan, called the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative. While state officials have given it preliminary approval, some specifics are still unresolved, especially those involving the eventual cost to consumers. They need to be ironed out before the plan can go back to the individual states for legislative or regulatory approval, a process that could begin early next year.
