Abstrace: Though it has helped the natural gas industry reduce its wastewater, recycling has not eliminated all the hazards.

Title: Do Natural Paths from Deep Shale to Shallow Rock Pose Gas Drilling Risk?
Abstrace: Scientists explore evidence that fluids from gas-rich zones have naturally migrated toward the surface in the past, with potential implications for gas drilling.

Title: Regulation Lax as Gas Wells’ Tainted Water Hits Rivers
Abstrace: A method to extract more natural gas often produces wastewater laced with toxic substances.

Title: The Do-It-Yourself Approach to Tracking Gas Drilling
Abstrace: The public is taking charge of the tough task of tracking gas fracking trends.

Title: Shocking Trout to Protect Them
Abstrace: Fisheries biologists are stepping up the exploration and cataloging of  wild trout streams in Pennsylvania to give the species maximum habitat protection against mining, development and natural gas extraction.

Title: With Unresolved Health Risks and Few Signs of an Economic Boon, Cuomo to Ban Gas Fracking
Abstrace: A look at the mix of economic, political and environmental factors that prompted Gov. Cuomo to bar fracking.

Title: Justices Bow to Legislators In Political Gerrymander Case
Abstrace: Supreme Court upholds boundaries of Congressional districts in Pennsylvania against Democratic charges of unconstitutional political gerrymandering; court leaves open possibility that future case might fare differently; several other redistricting cases now in process may end up before Supreme Court (M)

Title: Born by a River, Watching the Change
Abstrace: For some, Braddock, Pa., embodies the decline of the small Rust Belt town. For LaToya Ruby Frazier, it is home, which she explores in a series of elegiac images.

Title: They Couldn’t Drink Their Water. And Still, They Stayed Quiet.
Abstrace: In a Pennsylvania town, fracking, contamination and a community unbound.

Title: Great Idea For Trash, If It Works, Most Say
Abstrace: Bloomberg administration's solution to New York City's $1 billion-a-year trash problem is to deliver garbage in sealed containers to local railyards or shipyards that can move it to landfill anywhere east of Mississippi instead of sending trash to Fresh Kills landfill each day, as barges once did; no one, including Bloomberg's own staff, is quite sure plan would work; since Fresh Kills closed last year, thousands of trucks each day have been carrying garbage across bridges and tunnels to New Jersey, where it was either burned at incinerators or put onto tractor-trailers and then hauled to landfills mostly in Pennsylvania, Ohio and Virginia (M)

Title: This Deadly Chemical Should Be Banned
Abstrace: The cancer-causing chemical vinyl chloride was vented and burned after the Ohio train crash to avoid an explosion. The United States should phase it out.

Title: Panel Seeks Stiffer Rules for Drilling of Gas Wells
Abstrace: An Energy Department subcommittee has called for better tracking and more careful disposal of waste, among other measures.

Title: When a Rig Moves In Next Door
Abstrace: In states accustomed to its risks, drilling for natural gas is seen as an economic lifeline. But in the Northeast, some residents fear the long-term environmental impact.

Title: New Tool for Building and Fixing Roads and Bridges: Artificial Intelligence
Abstrace: In Pennsylvania and elsewhere, A.I. is being applied to the nation’s aging infrastructure. Is that wise?

Title: Pennsylvania Honors the Snot Otter. It’s Not Even the Strangest State Animal.
Abstrace: From parasitic wasps to shark look-alikes, states have honored many distinctive creatures. Often, students were the driving force.

Title: Gas Drillers Invade Hunters’ Pennsylvania Paradise
Abstrace: An area of abundant deer, turkey and bear, known to hunters as “God’s Country,” lies atop vast reserves of natural gas.

Title: Shell Sees New Role for Former Steel Region: Plastics
Abstrace: The oil and gas company is returning to the polyethylene market, building a 386-acre plant on the site of a long-shuttered zinc smelter on the Ohio River.

Title: Drowsy Truckers Find No Room for Their Rigs
Abstrace: Overcrowding at interstate rest areas only adds to nationwide safety problem caused by sleepy truck drivers; study conducted by University of Tennessee finds that along Tennessee highways on any given night, more than 500 trucks are parked illegally; related problem is that 18 states limit amount of time trucker can remain in rest area, with two hours being limit in Pennsylvania, New York, Virginia and parts of New Jersey; Federal Highway Administration is conducting study of extent of aggregate space shortage at rest areas and truck stops; photo (M)

Title: Economic Scene; The curbs on steel trade demonstrate the faults of courting special interests.
Abstrace: Virginia Postrel 'Economic Scene' column on Pres Bush's support for trade barriers against imported steel; says free-trade president has adopted blatantly protectionist position that will raise prices for everyone who buys or makes anything that uses steel; holds action will please two steel-making states, West Virginia and Pennsylvania; says Bush's action is example of democracy failure because citizens are being treated unequally; contends steel companies and steel workers who get big benefits from higher prices have more influence than does general public, each member of which will be hurt only little; chart (M)

Title: With Gas Drilling Next Door, County in New York Gets an Economic Lift
Abstrace: Residents of Chemung County, N.Y., across the border from hydrofracking sites in Pennsylvania, are getting a taste of how life might change if New York gives the green light to drilling.

Title: For Manufacturers, a Complex Mix Can Determine Location
Abstrace: While rural areas offer manufacturers some advantages, they can no longer count on lower salaries for workers or finding employees with the skills they need.

Title: Slag Heaps Into Gardens
Abstrace: Interview with landscape architect Julie Bargmann on her efforts to turn polluted industrial and mining wastelands into parks without erasing their history; projects use plants to absorb and break down toxins, eventually creating clean soil and water; do not cover up treatment ponds or hide outflow pipes; current project is reclamation of abandoned Pennsylvania coal mine; photos (M)

Title: The Fracturing of Pennsylvania
Abstrace: In Amwell Township, Pa., the dividing line is between those who are getting rich and those who are paying the price.

Title: In Crucial Pennsylvania, Democrats Worry a Fracking Ban Could Sink Them
Abstrace: The fracking ban pushed by Senators Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders  epitomizes a Democratic quandary: Appeal to swing voters or energize a liberal movement?

Title: A Deeper Look at a Study Finding High Leak Rates From Gas Drilling
Abstrace: A closer look at a hot study on high gas leak rates in Pennsylvania’s fracking zone raises coal questions.

Title: Natural Gas Drilling, in the Spotlight
Abstrace: Readers respond to a recent article on drilling for natural gas.

Title: A Dire Outlook as Climate Action Falls Short
Abstrace: Readers discuss an article about how nations fail to live up to climate pledges. Also: Political ads; an ex-Republican; big lie lawyers; protests in Brazil.

Title: Canadian Wildfire Smoke Reaches New Areas in the Southern U.S.
Abstrace: North Carolina and Georgia reported higher concentrations of smoke in new places.

Title: University Pulls Back on Pollution Study That Supported Its Benefactor
Abstrace: The president of Tennessee Technological University wrote to the E.P.A. saying the accuracy of the emissions study had been called into question.

Title: National Briefing | South: Governors Discuss Pollution Reduction
Abstrace: Four Southeastern governors meet with environmentalists and agree to work to curb pollution in Great Smoky Mountains (S)

Title: How $225,000 Can Help Secure a Pollution Loophole at Trump’s E.P.A.
Abstrace: A Tennessee truck dealership lavished a local Republican congresswoman with campaign donations. It also sells “Make Trucks Great Again” caps.

Title: New Strategy on Clean Air
Abstrace: Editorial holds that erosion of nation's clean air laws under Bush administration has inspired North Carolina Atty Gen Roy Cooper to adopt unusual legal strategy to force out-of-state power plants to stop sending air pollution into his state; notes that Cooper asked federal court to order Tennessee Valley Authority to install up-to-date emissions controls in 11 power plants in Alabama, Tennessee and Kentucky; maintains that some legal experts give Cooper's unorthodox strategy good chance, and this suggests that TVA would do well to reach amicable agreement

Title: Coal Firm to Pay Record Penalty and Spend Millions on Water Cleanup in 5 States
Abstrace: Alpha Natural Resources and 66 of its subsidiaries agreed to reduce pollution from coal mines in Kentucky, Pennsylvania, Tennessee, Virginia and West Virginia.

Title: Critics Say Clean-Air Plan May Be a Setback for Parks
Abstrace: Lush Appalachian mountains of Tennessee, which Cherokee called land of blue smoke, have famous summertime haze that rises from valleys of Great Smoky Mountains National Park, but air at high elevations today is often more polluted than in cities, as sulfates scatter light and small particles and nitrogen oxide cooks in sun to form ozone pollution; photos; EPA's dual strategy involves interstate drift of pollutants and haze rule requiring states to regulate power plants, with goal of improving air in national parks; environmentalists say plants may gain 14-year free pass on haze if they comply with interstate directives, that EPA approach is regulatory bait-and-switch; Smokies are also threatened by invasive pests, shortage of maintenance funds and proposed highway along northern edge in North Carolina (M)

Title: A Plea for Southern Treasures
Abstrace: From highway construction to mountaintop mining to pollution runoff, a group documents threats to mountains, waterways and forests.

Title: Sewage Holding Tank Bursts, and Two Men Are Killed
Abstrace: Millions of gallons of largely untreated sewage and water burst from a holding tank at a treatment plant serving the tourist town of Gatlinburg, Tenn.

Title: Administration Plans New Regulations on Coal-Ash Ponds
Abstrace: The Obama administration will propose new regulations by the end of the year after a coal-ash spill in December smothered 300 acres of eastern Tennessee.

Title: A Push Away From Burning Coal as an Energy Source
Abstrace: The Tennessee Valley Authority planned to close a total of eight electricity-generating units at three plants in Alabama and Kentucky, significantly cutting the emissions of greenhouse gases.

Title: Poisoned on Eno Road
Abstrace: The world of environmental racism is a subject that doesn’t get nearly enough attention.

Title: Swarms of Dying Mayflies Bring Good News
Abstrace: School and government officials say wave of immigrants over past 10 years, particularly in rural areas far from traditional immigrant hubs, has left school districts nationwide desperately short of people qualified to teach them English; number of students with limited English skills, most Hispanic, has doubled to five million in last decade, or more than four times rate for general student population; number of qualified teachers for English-as-a-second-language classes, already in chronic short supply, has not kept pace; estimated 50,000 such teachers exist, or one for every 100 students with limited English skills; demand for them has grown most rapidly in school districts in South, Midwest and Northwest; North Carolina has had fastest growth, with number quintupling from 1993, to 52,500 from 8,900; populations of such students in Idaho, Nebraska, Alabama, Tennessee, South Carolina and Georgia have at least tripled since 1993; map; photos (L)

Title: Poisoned on Eno Road
Abstrace: Bob Herbert Op-Ed column says racism led Dickson, Tenn, to locate its garbage dumps, landfills, transfer stations and toxic waste sites in area where blacks have historically lived, drawing their water from wells; says well of one black family in area has been polluted for years with trichloroethylene, which is associated with variety of cancers, heart disease, impairment of nervous system and other serious disorders; says that while federal government assured family that water was was safe, it warned white families that it was not and provided them with alternative source of drinking water

Title: 2 Tennessee Cases Bring Coal’s Hidden Hazard to Light
Abstrace: Coal ash, a largely unseen byproduct of electricity production, is leaking from storage ponds, two lawsuits contend, and could be threatening the drinking water of more than a million people.

Title: West Virginia Coal Miners’ Group Urges Tennessee Boycott
Abstrace: A Tennessee senator’s support of a ban on a type of coal mining has led miners in West Virginia to call for a boycott of Tennessee.

Title: The Agency That Brought Appalachia Electricity Must Focus on the Climate
Abstrace: The Tennessee Valley Authority could do a lot in short order, if it chose to.

Title: The Boring Bill in Tennessee That Everyone Should Be Watching
Abstrace: Republicans are about freedom and small government only when they’re not the ones in control of the government.

Title: Metal Levels Found High in Tributary After Spill
Abstrace: Tests of river water near the site of a coal ash spill in Tennessee showed levels of arsenic, lead and other metals at 2 to 300 times higher than drinking water standards.

Title: Humble Paddlefish Fulfills Southerners' Caviar Dreams
Abstrace: Domestic caviar accounts for 60 percent of American market and Lewis Shuckman is one of several southern fishermen and seafood sellers in Missouri, Arkansas, Kentucky, Georgia and Tennessee who have carved out places for themselves peddling paddlefish roe; roe sells for $10 to $20 per ounce compared with $50 for least expensive imports; seafood industry newsletter The Wave says it is among fastest growing sectors of seafood market as it gains wider acceptance; converts say taste is similar to more expensive Russian caviar, term which is reserved only for roe from sturgeon; Armen Petrossian, president of International Caviar Importers Assn in Paris, disdains paddlefish, but some caviar snobs are easily fooled; photos; chart compares caviar with paddlefish roe (L)

Title: Marquita Bradshaw on Her Tennessee Primary Victory: ‘I Could See the Momentum’
Abstrace: Ms. Bradshaw, an environmental justice advocate, is the first Black woman to be nominated for the Senate by a major party in Tennessee. “Working people showed that my viability was different,” she said.

Title: How to Prevent the Worst Case Extinction Scenario
Abstrace: People on both sides of the aisle can work together to prevent future calamities from unfolding.

Title: Drowsy Truckers Find No Room for Their Rigs
Abstrace: Overcrowding at interstate rest areas only adds to nationwide safety problem caused by sleepy truck drivers; study conducted by University of Tennessee finds that along Tennessee highways on any given night, more than 500 trucks are parked illegally; related problem is that 18 states limit amount of time trucker can remain in rest area, with two hours being limit in Pennsylvania, New York, Virginia and parts of New Jersey; Federal Highway Administration is conducting study of extent of aggregate space shortage at rest areas and truck stops; photo (M)

Title: Hundreds of Coal Ash Dumps Lack Regulation
Abstrace: Most coal byproduct dumps in the U.S. are unregulated, but they contain chemicals that threaten health.

Title: A Ray of Hope in a Slimy Southern Cave
Abstrace: Residents in the South are coming together to protect their underground ecosystems.

Title: The Climate Crisis Is Raging, but We Are Not Powerless
Abstrace: Our collective efforts can make a huge difference.

Title: Coal Ash Spill Revives Issue of Its Hazards
Abstrace: The Tennessee Valley Authority has played down the risks of what may be the nation’s largest spill of coal ash, but there are questions about its potential toxicity.

Title: Howard H. Baker Jr., ‘Great Conciliator’ of the Senate, Dies at 88
Abstrace: Mr. Baker, the Senate Republican leader for eight years, was a forceful figure on the chamber’s Watergate committee and helped President Ronald Reagan weather the Iran-Contra scandal.

Title: Pipe Company Faces Pollution Indictment
Abstrace: McWane Inc, one of world's largest pipe manufacturers, is indicted in Utah, accused of six-year conspiracy to violate Clean Air Act and falsify tests to cover up emissions of dangerous air pollutant; indictment charges McWane with misleading regulatory officials into believing that its pipe foundry in Utah, Pacific States Cast Iron Pipe, was in compliance with air-pollution laws (S)

Title: Booming Utah’s Weak Link: Surging Air Pollution
Abstrace: A red-hot economy, wildfire smoke from California and the shriveling of the Great Salt Lake are making Utah’s alarming pollution even worse.

Title: I Am Haunted by What I Have Seen at Great Salt Lake
Abstrace: The Latter-day Saints church has the moral authority and political sway to save the Great Salt Lake.

Title: End of an Era in Coal Country, Utah
Abstrace: The Carbon Power Plant, the state’s oldest coal-fired power plant, is set to close by April 2015, a result of new stricter federal pollution regulations.

Title: Seen as Nature Lovers’ Paradise, Utah Struggles With Air Quality
Abstrace: Topographic and meteorological factors combine to trap auto emissions and other air pollutants in the region, a problem with no easy solution.

Title: Will Oil Extraction Harm Western Parks?
Abstrace: The government is considering whether to open roughly 2.3 million acres of land in Colorado, Utah, and Wyoming to two controversial types of energy development.

Title: Unusual Alliance Is Formed to Clean Up Mine Runoff
Abstrace: US Forest Service, environmental group Trout Unlimited, ski resort owners Snowbird Corp and Tiffany & Co form partnership to clean acidic mine runoff from American Fork watershed in Utah; unusual alliance is intended to overcome two hurdles that have slowed mine cleanups: intermingling of public and private land in most affected areas and provisions of Superfund law that make those who work at mine waste sites, whether to re-mine them or clean them, potentially liable for their pollution; photos; map (M)

Title: A Plan to Unlock Billions of Barrels of Oil From Utah’s Sands
Abstrace: Backers say their method will avoid the environmental toll incurred in Canada’s oil sands — some others aren’t so sure — and will yield profits at half the current price of crude.

Title: Utah’s ‘Environmental Nuclear Bomb’
Abstrace: As the Great Salt Lake dries up, toxic dust threatens to poison the air in one of the United States’ fastest-growing metro areas.

Title: National Briefing | Rockies: Utah: Group Suspected In Lumberyard Fire
Abstrace: Fire causes $1.5 million worth of damage at lumberyard in West Jordan, Utah; authorities suspect Earth Liberation Front (S)

Title: U.S. Blocks Oil Drilling at 60 Sites in Utah
Abstrace: Faulting the Bush administration, the Interior Department barred oil and gas development at eight of the sites and said 52 others would be subjected to further study.

Title: A Part of Utah Built on Coal Wonders What Comes Next
Abstrace: The Carbon Power Plant, the state’s oldest coal-fired power plant, is set to close by April 2015, a result of stricter new federal pollution regulations.

Title: Presidential Ecospeak
Abstrace: Editorial on Mike Leavitt, Pres George W Bush's nominee to run Environmental Protection Agency; notes that Leavitt won committee approval but not without criticism from some senators who were exasperated by his hiding behind ecofriendly phrases when asked about environmental record as Utah governor; asserts that Leavitt is following Bush's lead in oversimplifying solutions to complex environmental issues (M)

Title: This Land Was Your Land
Abstrace: Federal agencies have been captured by the very industries they should be regulating.

Title: JOURNEYS: Exploring the West By Night; Rediscovering The Brilliance Of the Stars
Abstrace: Article on star-gazing trip to Bryce Point in Utah's Bryce Canyon National Park; photos; map (M)

Title: Bush Nominates Utah Governor To Lead Environmental Agency
Abstrace: Pres Bush nominates Gov Michael O Leavitt of Utah as new administrator of Environmental Protection Agency; nomination draws praise from business and Republican Party groups and mixed reviews from environmental activists, who commend him for working for clean air in Grand Canyon and fault him for helping to open public lands in Utah to industry and roadbuilding; Leavitt, Republican, is in his third term as governor; if confirmed by Senate he would succeed Christie Whitman, whose credentials as political moderate failed to satisfy environmentalists and raised suspicions among White House officials; Leavitt says his 'very clear environmental philosophy' is based on balance; Sens John Kerry and Joseph I Lieberman, both seeking Democratic presidential nomination, say they will use Leavitt's confirmation hearings to denounce Bush on environment; photo (M)

Title: The Cautious U.S. Boom in Oil Shale
Abstrace: Shell Oil, Chevron and little-known private Texas company named EGL Resources are experimenting and planning to process organic material in shale into form of oil so it can be pumped to surface; Bush administration last month opened up five large parcels of land in Piceance Creek Basin in Colorado for oil shale research and development projects; EGL Resources oil shale projects manager R Glenn Vawter will begin pilot tests early in 2007; government estimates of recoverable shale oil in Colorado, Utah and Wyoming put reserves at 800 billion barrels; RAND Corp estimates size of oil resource in three states to range from 1.5 trillion to 1.8 trillion barrels, vastly more than proven oil reserves of Saudi Arabia; map; photos (L)

Title: National Briefing
Abstrace: WEST

Title: As the Great Salt Lake Dries Up, Utah Faces an ‘Environmental Nuclear Bomb’
Abstrace: Climate change and rapid population growth are shrinking the lake, creating a bowl of toxic dust that could poison the air around Salt Lake City.

Title: Pennsylvania Honors the Snot Otter. It’s Not Even the Strangest State Animal.
Abstrace: From parasitic wasps to shark look-alikes, states have honored many distinctive creatures. Often, students were the driving force.

Title: Drillers in Utah Have a Friend in a U.S. Land Agency
Abstrace: An obscure branch of the Bureau of Land Management wields great influence on local land-use decisions in the state, usually to the benefit of the energy industry.

Title: Outdoors Is the Way Up in Ogden, Utah
Abstrace: With hiking, water skiing, kayaking and biking, the town is hoping to be America’s capital of extreme sports.

Title: 9 Northeast States File Suit Over New Rules on Pollution
Abstrace: Nine Northastern states file legal challenge to new air-pollution rules for power plants and other industries just hours after Bush administration publishes rules; say rules constitute most serious effort at rolling back landmark Clean Air Act since it was enacted more than 30 years ago; changes would allow thousands of aging coal-fired power plants and other industrial sites to upgrade without having to install costly anti-pollution devices (M)

Title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Ford Focus PZEV; A Stealthy Operative In the War on Pollution
Abstrace: Behind the Wheel column assesses Ford Focus PZEV, which meets emissions standards in California, Maine, Massachusetts, New York and Vermont; chart compares so-called clean cars; photo (M)

Title: Eastern States Introduce a Plan to Cap Tailpipe Pollution
Abstrace: Twelve states and the District of Columbia released a draft plan for an ambitious cap-and-trade program to curb planet-warming emissions on the region’s roads.

Title: States Sue E.P.A. Over Delayed Soot Rules
Abstrace: Eleven states argue that drafting new rules is vital to public health. But the Obama administration faces pressure from Republican critics who say that tighter air pollution rules could hurt the economy.

Title: Electric Cars May Lose Push In Northeast
Abstrace: New York, Massachusetts and Vermont may postpone until 2007 requirement that electric cars be sold, and may promote use of other emission-reduction technologies instead; state officials claim change could actually produce deeper cut in tailpipe pollution in first few years, while giving car companies needed flexibility; environmental groups question that claim and say retreat by Northeast states would damage efforts to make electric cars commonplace and economicaly viable; move leaves California as only state requiring sales of electric cars over next several years, cutting market for them in half; New York's environmental conservation commissioner, Erin Crotty, says postponing electric car mandate is state's recognition that automakers are not yet ready to produce them; automakers have said they would be unable to make commercially viable electric cars in time to meet California mandate that begins with 2003 model year (M)

Title: E.P.A. Sued Over Mercury in the Air
Abstrace: New Jersey and eight other states file lawsuit challenging Environmental Protection Agency rule that they claim does not do enough to control dangerous mercury emissions from coal-fired power plants (M)

Title: New York City and 8 States Plan to Sue Power Plants
Abstrace: Eight states and New York City will file federal lawsuit demanding 'substantial cuts' in carbon dioxide emissions by five major utility companies that operate 174 power plants (M)

Title: Contest Aims for a Cleaner-Burning Wood Stove
Abstrace: Twelve teams are competing in Washington to find ways to get twice as much heat out of a log of firewood while producing cleaner smoke.

Title: 9 States in Plan to Cut Emissions by Power Plants
Abstrace: Nine Northeastern states reportedly reach preliminary agreement to freeze power plant emissions at current levels and then reduce them by ten percent by 2020; photo; first such cooperative action follows Bush administration not to regulate greenhouse gases and would require legislation in each state; initiative would set up market-driven system to control carbon dioxide emissions from more than 600 electric generators, and could spur action nationally; California, Washington and Oregon explore similar agreement; Northeast states were brought together by New York Gov George Pataki, who broke sharply with administration on issue; spokesman declines comment on leaked draft; environmentalists say region's carbon dioxide emissions are about those of Germany, but that real significance of accord is example for other states (M)

Title: Vermont Power Plant Continues to Leak Radiation
Abstrace: Levels found in the groundwater near the Vermont Yankee plant are three times greater than were found last week.

Title: Radiation Levels Cloud Vermont Reactor’s Fate
Abstrace: Longtime supporters and foes of the state’s only atomic power plant are questioning whether its operating license will be extended past 2012.

Title: U.S. Court Backs States’ Measures to Cut Emissions
Abstrace: A federal judge in Vermont gave the first legal endorsement to rules in California, being copied in 13 other states, that intend to reduce greenhouse gases emitted by automobiles.

Title: Can Efficiency Counter a Loss of Nuclear Power?
Abstrace: When Japan shut down some nuclear power plants after the Fukushima Daiichi disaster, carbon dioxide emissions rose significantly, a group found.

Title: Biting the Bullet, Vermont Yankee Orders Fuel
Abstrace: With a nuclear plant’s future in doubt, its owner orders $50 million worth of fuel for a reactor, betting that things will go its way in court.

Title: Tainted-Water Worries Spread to Vermont Village
Abstrace: North Bennington joined a list of communities, including nearby Hoosick Falls, N.Y., that face water-supply problems after private wells near a closed plant tested positive for a chemical, PFOA.

Title: Even ‘Safe’ Places Are Experiencing Climate Chaos in America
Abstrace: In Vermont, the climate is jumping the banks and blowing past the guardrails.

Title: Jim Jeffords's Long Goodbye
Abstrace: Op-Ed article by Garrison Nelson, political science professor, says Sen James Jeffords has history of thwarting conservative Republican leaders, but his political independence has not been as easily countenanced since George W Bush won White House with less than plurality of popular vote; says White House staffers do not understand traditions of individualism in Senate and political independence in Vermont; says combination of overeager White House and heedless Sen Trent Lott cost Republicans James Jeffords and with him any effective control of Senate, in what may mark end of Bush's conservative legislative agenda (M)

Title: National Spotlight For Vermont Paper
Abstrace: Rutland Herald is candidate for Pulitzer Prize for series of editorials written by David R Moats urging Vermont to legalize gay unions; photos (M)

Title: Climate Enters Debate Over Nuclear Power
Abstrace: Environmental groups want to shut down Vermont’s only nuclear power plant, but closing it might mean the state would probably have to derive extra power from suppliers that use fossil fuels.

Title: How Your Child’s School Bus Might Prevent Blackouts
Abstrace: When not driving around, electric buses and other vehicles could help utilities by storing their solar and wind energy and releasing it to meet surges in demand.

Title: How Your Child’s School Bus Might Prevent Blackouts
Abstrace: When not driving around, electric buses and other vehicles could help utilities by storing their solar and wind energy and releasing it to meet surges in demand.

Title: How to View the Northern Lights From New England and the Midwest
Abstrace: With careful planning, timing and luck, witnessing the aurora borealis in the Lower 48 is one of the greatest yet most rarely seen spectacles for anyone willing to sacrifice a bit of sleep.

Title: Wanted: Cleaner Cars
Abstrace: To the Editor:.

Title: Corrections
Abstrace: Correction of Jan 13 article about New Jersey's new auto emissions standards; Vermont has similar law

Title: Eastern States Introduce a Plan to Cap Tailpipe Pollution
Abstrace: Twelve states and the District of Columbia released a draft plan for an ambitious cap-and-trade program to curb planet-warming emissions on the region’s roads.

Title: National Briefing | The Environment: Efforts To Clean Up Chesapeake Bay
Abstrace: Leaders from Maryland, Virginia, Pennsylvania and Washington, DC, agree to steps to reduce flow of pollutants from urban sites into Chesapeake Bay; accord calls for cutting storm water runoff, fastest-growing source of bay pollution, on state and federal lands by 30 percent by 2008 (S)

Title: Coal Firm to Pay Record Penalty and Spend Millions on Water Cleanup in 5 States
Abstrace: Alpha Natural Resources and 66 of its subsidiaries agreed to reduce pollution from coal mines in Kentucky, Pennsylvania, Tennessee, Virginia and West Virginia.

Title: Utility to Spend $1.2 Billion to Cut Emissions
Abstrace: Dominion Virginia Power Co, in largest settlement ever under Clean Air Act, reaches accord with Environmental Protection Agency and five states to spend $1.2 billion to install pollution-reducing technology in eight coal-burning power plants in Virgina and West Virginia by 2013; New York, New Jersey and Connecticut have long complained that emissions from plants were polluting their air; company also agrees to pay $5.3 million in federal penalties and $14 million for various states' environmental projects; new controls will curb emissions of sulfur dioxide, which causes acid rain, and nitrogen oxide, which causes smog; Admr Christie Whitman holds settlement shows Bush administration's commitment to fully enforcing environmental laws (M)

Title: A Plea for Southern Treasures
Abstrace: From highway construction to mountaintop mining to pollution runoff, a group documents threats to mountains, waterways and forests.

Title: ‘Environmental Justice Is Not Merely a Box to Be Checked’
Abstrace: When concerns about a pipeline were dismissed by regulators, a rural black enclave went to court — and won.

Title: The Road to Hell Is Clogged With Righteous Hybrids
Abstrace: John Tierney Op-Ed column says giving drivers of fuel-efficient and hybrid cars new privileges, such as car pool lanes, will result in dirtier air and more gasoline comsumption, because it will encourage more of them to drive; notes that in Virginia, car pool lanes have become so clogged that advisory panel recommends their banishment; says one change that could speed up traffic and help environment is to convert car pool lanes into high-occupancy toll lanes, reserved for those in car pools, jitneys and buses (M)

Title: Corrections
Abstrace: Afront-page picture caption on Sunday about Palestinians who walked on the beach in Gaza after Israeli bulldozers severed the main road misstated the direction in which most were moving. It was north, not south.

Title: Duke Energy Is Charged in Huge Coal Ash Leak
Abstrace: Federal prosecutors accused the nation’s largest electric utility of violating the federal Clean Water Act in a spill last year in North Carolina.

Title: City Trash Follows Long and Winding Road
Abstrace: Article traces path of New York City garbage now that Fresh Kills is closed and trash must be trucked to destinations as distant as Virginia and Pennsylvania through transfer stations in New Jersey; tolls, truck repair and fuel costs make it expensive proposition to dispose of 12,000 tons of city garbage each day; photo; diagram (M)

Title: In a Corner of Virginia’s ‘Switzerland,’ a Division Over a Planned Wind Farm
Abstrace: A proposed wind farm has divided the  2,500 residents of Highland County, Va.

Title: Albany Encouraging Use of Diesel Generators to Avert Blackouts
Abstrace: ALBANY, March 20 — Concerned about the potential for power shortages, the Pataki administration and the managers of the state's power grid are taking steps to encourage businesses to run their backup diesel generators at times during the summer when electricity use is at its highest. The proposals have raised concerns among environmentalists because diesel generators pollute much more than even coal-burning power plants.

Title: A Big Uranium Deposit, and a Big Debate on Mining It
Abstrace: A proposed uranium mine has thrust Virginia into a national debate over energy security, nuclear power and the environment.

Title: Virginia Democrats Aim to Block Trump’s E.P.A. Chief From State Agency
Abstrace: In Virginia, cabinet nominees are rarely blocked. But the Republican governor-elect’s choice of Andrew Wheeler to be natural resources secretary has alarmed Democrats.

Title: Rift Widens Over Mining of Uranium in Virginia
Abstrace: Bills introduced to the General Assembly would lift a moratorium on uranium mining at a site in southern Virginia, but the issue has divided the region.

Title: On a Postindustrial Potomac, an Old Plant Gives Way
Abstrace: The development has been aided by a nonprofit group’s proposal to convert a coal-fired plant to a mixed-use project and an agreement to close the plant.

Title: There’s Something in the Water in Virginia. Before You Say ‘Yuck,’ Wait.
Abstrace: A crucial aquifer is running low, so officials are pumping in treated sewage. It’s an increasingly common strategy as heavy demand and climate change strain water supplies.

Title: Biden Administration Approves Biggest Offshore Wind Farm Yet, in Virginia
Abstrace: The decision comes as other projects to build wind farms along the Atlantic Coast have run into trouble.

Title: Introduction of Nonnative Oysters Into Bay Should Wait, Study Says
Abstrace: National Academy of Sciences issues report recommending that Maryland and Virginia conduct more extensive studies of species of Asian oyster before introducing them in large numbers into Chesapeake Bay for breeding; Asian oysters are resistant to parasites that have ravaged native oyster beds, but environmental groups warn that nonnative species can bring their own problems (M)

Title: Great Idea For Trash, If It Works, Most Say
Abstrace: Bloomberg administration's solution to New York City's $1 billion-a-year trash problem is to deliver garbage in sealed containers to local railyards or shipyards that can move it to landfill anywhere east of Mississippi instead of sending trash to Fresh Kills landfill each day, as barges once did; no one, including Bloomberg's own staff, is quite sure plan would work; since Fresh Kills closed last year, thousands of trucks each day have been carrying garbage across bridges and tunnels to New Jersey, where it was either burned at incinerators or put onto tractor-trailers and then hauled to landfills mostly in Pennsylvania, Ohio and Virginia (M)

Title: Bernard Cohen, Lawyer in Landmark Mixed-Marriage Case, Dies at 86
Abstrace: With Philip J. Hirschkop, he brought Loving v. Virginia to the Supreme Court, which struck down laws against interracial marriages.

Title: Are There Better Places to Put Large Solar Farms Than These Forests?
Abstrace: For the great promise of renewable energy to be realized, states like Virginia must create an environment where solar, nature and people can peaceably coexist.

Title: Pennsylvania Honors the Snot Otter. It’s Not Even the Strangest State Animal.

Title: Chesapeake Oystermen, in Decline, Place Hopes in an Asian Import
Abstrace: Ice glazes the 39-foot Tracie Leigh, the wind blowing stiff and cold, as Tom Lagana harvests oysters the old-fashioned way.     Standing on a square of deck covered with rock salt to keep it from freezing, he clutches 20-foot poles that work like giant chopsticks, spreading his arms wide, then pulling them back toward his chest. A winch lifts the poles until tongs with metal claws open. Mixed in with empty shells, muck and rocks lies the catch: a few dozen Chesapeake oysters.

Title: Local Elections to Test the Nation's Mood
Abstrace: Voters, in first broad test of nation's political mood since September 11 terrorist attacks, will go to polls on November 6 to elect governors and legislatures in New Jersey and Virginia and mayors in dozen or so major cities; subtext of many campaigns, and main text of few, has been deteriorating economy and need for strong security and strong leaders in attacks' aftermath; gubernatorial campaigns in Virginia between Democrat Mark Warner and Republican Mark L Earley and in New Jersey between Democrat James E McGreevey and Bret D Schundler discussed; other contests noted; photos (M)

Title: A Powerful Climate Solution Just Below the Ocean’s Surface
Abstrace: Restoring seagrass meadows is one tool that coastal communities can use to address climate change, both by capturing emissions and mitigating their effects.

Title: Drowsy Truckers Find No Room for Their Rigs
Abstrace: Overcrowding at interstate rest areas only adds to nationwide safety problem caused by sleepy truck drivers; study conducted by University of Tennessee finds that along Tennessee highways on any given night, more than 500 trucks are parked illegally; related problem is that 18 states limit amount of time trucker can remain in rest area, with two hours being limit in Pennsylvania, New York, Virginia and parts of New Jersey; Federal Highway Administration is conducting study of extent of aggregate space shortage at rest areas and truck stops; photo (M)

Title: Democrats in Split-Screen: The Base Wants It All. The Party Wants to Win.

Title: Corzine Prevails in a Nasty Governor's Campaign in New Jersey
Abstrace: Jon S Corzine, liberal Democrat who parlayed Wall Street wealth and experience into US Senate seat, is elected governor of New Jersey, defeating fellow multimillionaire Douglas R Forrester in nasty campaign that was costliest in state history; Corzine wins 53 percent, Forrester 44 percent; Democrat Timothy M Kaine wins governorship in Virginia, sending powerful message that Pres Bush's standing has fallen in reliably Republican state; Kaine wins 51 percent to 46 percent for Republican Jerry W Kilgore; Corzine, flanked by his three children, talks to cheering supporters in East Brunswick after Forrester concedes; photos; noxious campaign that disgusted voters reviewed (M)

Title: Americana, Salted, Smoked and Sliced Thin
Abstrace: R W Apple Jr article on Smithfield ham, granddaddy of dry-cured country hams produced in half-dozen Southern states; reports on his visit to Smithfield, Va; notes that even with modern technology, producing Smithfield hams is finicky process; list of some Smithfield ham sources; photos (L)

Title: Town of Worn Bootstraps Lifts Itself Up
Abstrace: Twelve families in Bayview, Va, will soon leave behind ramshackle homes and move into new development of 80 free-standing houses across from old town; new homes have heat, flush toilets and running water, conveniences that were not commonplace in Bayview until now; development stems from relentless work by residents who lobbied to block plans to build prison where new houses are going up; homes are financed with federal and state money; people of Bayview are descended from freed slaves; town profiled; prices of new homes noted; map; photos (L)

Title: The Cautious U.S. Boom in Oil Shale
Abstrace: Shell Oil, Chevron and little-known private Texas company named EGL Resources are experimenting and planning to process organic material in shale into form of oil so it can be pumped to surface; Bush administration last month opened up five large parcels of land in Piceance Creek Basin in Colorado for oil shale research and development projects; EGL Resources oil shale projects manager R Glenn Vawter will begin pilot tests early in 2007; government estimates of recoverable shale oil in Colorado, Utah and Wyoming put reserves at 800 billion barrels; RAND Corp estimates size of oil resource in three states to range from 1.5 trillion to 1.8 trillion barrels, vastly more than proven oil reserves of Saudi Arabia; map; photos (L)

Title: Committed to Coal, and in a Hurry, Too
Abstrace: TXU Corp is embarking on nation's single largest coal-oriented construction campaign, with plan to add more than 9,000 megawatts of new capacity, equivalent of 3.5 percent of nation's current coal-fired capacity; capacity is enough to power millions of homes, using coal from other giant pits like one in Fairfield, Tex, and still more in Wyoming; TXU is spending $10 billion on 11 new coal power plants that will produce copious amounts of global warming gases for decades to come; TXU says it is considering 7,000 to 14,000 more megawatts of capacity in other parts of country, possibly including Northeast and Midwest; whatever coal-burning plants cost to ecosystem, it could be immensely profitable bet; company executives say plants will provide cheap electricity for Texas, make lots of money for shareholders, conserve more valuable natural gas and reduce pollutants that make smog; outside groups, including Public Citizen, Pew Center for Global Climate Change and Natural Resources Defense Council say TXU is embarking on its immense construction campaign without taking account of its role in emerging environmental catastrophe; TXU chief executive Mike McCall comments; graph; map; photos (L)

Title: U.S. to Limit Petroleum Drilling on Habitat of Greater Sage Grouse

Title: With Energy-Tax Bonanza, Wyoming Schools Enjoy Windfall
Abstrace: Forget the bucking bronco. A clattering cash register has become the more apt symbol of Wyoming in the energy rush.     Over the past four years, as natural gas prices have spiked and drillers have descended here on the nation's least-populous state, Wyoming has collected about $65 million a month more in energy taxes than the government can spend. The numbers, in their cumulative power and duration, are starting to change the state's vision of what it could be and how to get there.

Title: Coal Firm to Pay Record Penalty and Spend Millions on Water Cleanup in 5 States

Title: Utility to Spend $1.2 Billion to Cut Emissions
Abstrace: Dominion Virginia Power Co, in largest settlement ever under Clean Air Act, reaches accord with Environmental Protection Agency and five states to spend $1.2 billion to install pollution-reducing technology in eight coal-burning power plants in Virgina and West Virginia by 2013; New York, New Jersey and Connecticut have long complained that emissions from plants were polluting their air; company also agrees to pay $5.3 million in federal penalties and $14 million for various states' environmental projects; new controls will curb emissions of sulfur dioxide, which causes acid rain, and nitrogen oxide, which causes smog; Admr Christie Whitman holds settlement shows Bush administration's commitment to fully enforcing environmental laws (M)

Title: Just How Far Can Trading Of Emissions Be Extended?

Title: Economic Scene; The curbs on steel trade demonstrate the faults of courting special interests.

Title: Biden will allow summertime sales of higher-ethanol gas.
